It has already set up new standards for the conduct of nations in the Declaration of Human Rights and the Convention on Genocide. It is moving ahead to give meaning to the concept of world brotherhood through a wide variety of cultural
column2: economic
column3: and technical activities.

column1: The events of the past year again showed the value of the United Nations in bringing about the peaceful adjustment of tense international controversies. In Indonesia and in Palestine the efforts of the United Nations have put a stop to bloodshed and paved the way to peaceful settlements.
We are working toward the time when the United Nations will control weapons of mass destruction and will have the forces to preserve international law and order. While the world remains unsettled
column2: however
column3: and as long as our own security and the security of the free world require
column4: we will maintain a strong and well-balanced defense organization. The Selective Service System is an essential part of our defense plans
column5: and it must be continued.

column1: Under the principles of the United Nations Charter we must continue to share in the common defense of free nations against aggression. At the last session this Congress laid the basis for this joint effort. We now must put into effect the common defense plans that are being worked out.
We shall continue our efforts for world economic recovery
column2: because world prosperity is the only sure foundation of a permanent peace.

column1: As an immediate means to this end we must continue our support of the European recovery program. This program has achieved great success in the first 2 years of its operation
column2: but it has not yet been completed. If we were to stop this program now
column3: or cripple it
column4: just because it is succeeding
column5: we should be doing exactly what the enemies of democracy want us to do. We should be just as foolish as a man who
column6: for reasons of false economy
column7: failed to put a roof on his house after building the foundation and the walls.

column1: World prosperity also requires that we do all we can to expand world trade. As a major step in this direction we should promptly join the International Trade Organization. The purpose of this organization
column2: which the United States has been foremost in creating
column3: is to establish a code of fair practice
column4: and an international authority for adjusting differences in international commercial relations. It is an effort to prevent the kind of anarchy and irresponsibility in world trade which did so much to bring about the world depression of the 1930's.

column1: An expanding world economy requires the improvement of living standards and the development of resources in areas where human poverty and misery now prevail. Without such improvement the recovery of Europe and the future of our own economy will not be secure. I urge that the Congress adopt the legislation now before it to provide for increasing the flow of technical assistance and capital investment in underdeveloped regions.
It is more essential now than ever
column2: if the ideals of freedom and representative government are to prevail in these areas
column3: and particularly in the Far East
column4: that their peoples experience
column5: in their own lives
column6: the benefits of scientific and economic advances. This program will require the movement of large amounts of capital from the industrial nations
column7: and particularly from the United States
column8: to productive uses in the underdeveloped areas of the world. Recent world events make prompt action imperative.

column1: This program is in the interest of all peoples-and has nothing in common with either the old imperialism of the last century or the new imperialism of the Communists.
Our aim for a peaceful
column2: democratic world of free peoples will be achieved in the long run
column3: not by force of arms
column4: but by an appeal to the minds and hearts of men. If the peace policy of the democratic nations is to be successful
column5: they must demonstrate that the benefits of their way of life can be increased and extended to all nations and all races.

column1: In the world today we are confronted with the danger that the rising demand of people everywhere for freedom and a better life may be corrupted and betrayed by the false promises of communism. In its ruthless struggle for power
column2: communism seizes upon our imperfections
column3: and takes advantage of the delays and setbacks which the democratic nations experience in their effort to secure a better life for their citizens. This challenge to us is more than a military challenge. It is a challenge to the honesty of our profession of the democratic faith; it is a challenge to the efficiency and stability of our economic system; it is a challenge to the willingness to work with other peoples for world peace and for world prosperity.

column1: For my part I welcome that challenge. I believe that our country
column2: at this crucial point in world history
column3: will meet that challenge successfully. I believe that
column4: in cooperation with the other free nations of the world
column5: we shall extend the full benefits of the democratic way of life to millions who do not now enjoy them
column6: and preserve mankind from dictatorship and tyranny.

column1: I believe that we shall succeed in our struggle for this peace
column2: because I have seen the success we have had in our own country in following the principles of freedom. Over the last 50 years
column3: the ideals of liberty and equal opportunity to which this Nation is dedicated have been increasingly realized in the lives of our people.

column1: The ideal of equal opportunity no longer means simply the opportunity which a man has to advance beyond his fellows. Some of our citizens do achieve greater success than others as a reward for individual merit and effort
column2: and this is as it should be. At the same time our country must be more than a land of opportunity for a select few. It must be a land of opportunity for all of us. In such a land we can grow and prosper together.

column1: The simple truth that we can all go forward together is often questioned by selfish or shortsighted persons. It is strange that this is so
column2: for this proposition is so clearly demonstrated by our national history. During the last 50 years
column3: for example
column4: our Nation has grown enormously in material wellbeing. This growth has come about
column5: not by concentrating the benefits of our progress in the hands of a few
column6: but by increasing the wealth of the great body of our Nation and our citizens.

column1: In the last 50 years the income of the average family has increased so greatly that its buying power has doubled. The average hours of work have declined from 60 to 40 a week
column2: the whole hourly production of the average worker has tripled. Average wages
column3: allowing for price changes
column4: have increased from about 45 cents an hour to $I.40 an hour.

column1: We have accomplished what to earlier ages of mankind would have been a miracle-we work shorter hours
column2: we produce more
column3: and we live better.

column1: Increasing freedom from poverty and drudgery has given a fuller meaning to American life. Our people are better educated; we have more opportunities for travel and recreation and enjoyment of the arts. We enjoy more personal liberty in the United States today than ever before.
If we can continue in the spirit of cooperative adventure which has marked the recent years of our progress
column2: we can expect further scientific advances
column3: further increases in our standard of living
column4: and a still wider enjoyment of democratic freedom.

column1: No one
column2: of course
column3: can foretell the future exactly. However
column4: if we assume that we shall grow as fast in the future as we have grown in the past
column5: we can get a good idea of how much our country should grow in the next 50 years.

column1: At present our total national production is $255 billion a year. Our working population and our output per worker are increasing. If our productive power continues to increase at the same rate as it has increased over the past 50 years
column2: our total national production 50 years from now will be nearly four times as much as it is today. Allowing for the expected growth in population
column3: this would mean that the real income of the average family in the year 2000 A.D. would be ahout three times what it is today.

column1: These are estimates of what we can do in the future
column2: but we can reach these heights only if we follow the right policies. We have learned by bitter experience that progress is not automatic-that wrong policies lead to depression and disaster. We cannot achieve these gains unless we have a stable economy and avoid the catastrophes of boom and bust that have set us back in the past.

column1: These gains cannot be achieved unless our businessmen maintain their spirit of initiative and enterprise and operate in a competitive economy. They cannot be achieved unless our workingmen and women and their unions help to increase productivity and obtain for labor a fair share of the benefits of our economic system. They cannot be achieved unless we have a stable and prosperous agriculture. They cannot be achieved unless we conserve and develop our natural resources in the public interest. Our system will not work unless our people are healthy
column2: well-educated
column3: and confident of the future. It will not work unless all citizens can participate fully in our national life.

column1: In achieving these gains the Government has a special responsibility to help create and maintain the conditions which will permit the growth we know is possible. Foremost among these conditions is the need for a fair distribution of our increasing prosperity among all the great groups of our population who help to bring it about - labor
column2: business
column3: agriculture.

column1: Businessmen must continue to have the incentives necessary for investment and for the development of new lines of enterprise. In the future growth of this country
column2: lie possibilities for hundreds of thousands of new and independent businesses. As our national production increases
column3: as it doubles and redoubles in the next 50 years
column4: the number of independent and competing enterprises should also increase. If the number does not increase
column5: our constantly growing economy will fall under the control of a few dominant economic groups whose powers will be so great that they will be a challenge to democratic institutions.

column1: To avoid this danger
column2: we must curb monopoly and provide aids to independent business so that it may have the credit and capital to compete in a system of free enterprise. I recommend that the Congress complete action at this session on the pending bill to close the loopholes in the Clayton Act which now permit monopolistic mergers. I also hope before this session is over to transmit to the Congress a series of proposals to strengthen the antimonopoly laws
column3: to assist small business
column4: and to encourage the growth of new enterprises.

column1: In the case of labor
column2: free collective bargaining must be protected and encouraged. Collective bargaining is not only a fundamental economic freedom for labor. It is also a strengthening and stabilizing influence for our whole economy.

column1: The Federal statute now governing labor relations is punitive in purpose and onesided in operation. This statute is
column2: and always has been
column3: inconsistent with the practice of true and effective collective bargaining. It should be repealed and replaced by a law that is fair to all and in harmony with our democratic ideals.

column1: A full understanding of the problems of modern labor relations is of such importance that I recommend the establishment of a labor extension service to encourage educational activities in this field.

Another essential for our continued growth is a stable and prosperous agriculture. For many years we have been building a program to give the farmer a reasonable measure of protection against the special hazards to which he is exposed. That program was improved at the last session of the Congress. However
column2: our farm legislation is still not adequate.

column1: Although the Congress has properly declared as a matter of national policy that safeguards must be maintained against slumps in farm prices
column2: there are serious shortcomings in the methods now available for carrying out this policy. Mandatory price supports should be provided for the commodities not now covered which are major sources of farm income.

column1: Moreover
column2: we should provide a method of supporting farm income at fair levels which will
column3: at the same time
column4: avoid piling up unmanageable surpluses and allow consumers to obtain the full benefit of our abundant agricultural production. A system of production payments gives the greatest promise of accomplishing this purpose. I recommend that the use of such a system be authorized.

column1: One of the most important factors in our continued growth is the construction of more good
column2: up-to-date housing. In a country such as ours there is no reason why decent homes should not be within the reach of all. With the help of various Government programs we have made great progress in the last few years in increasing the number of homes.

column1: Despite this increase
column2: there is still an acute shortage of housing for the lower and middle-income groups
column3: especially in large metropolitan areas. We have laid the groundwork for relieving the plight of lower-income families in the Housing Act of 1949. To aid the middle-income families
column4: I recommend that the Congress enact new legislation authorizing a vigorous program to help co-operatives and other nonprofit groups build housing which these families can afford.

column1: Rent control has done a great deal to prevent the housing shortage from having had worse effects during this postwar period of adjustment. Rent control is still necessary to prevent widespread hardship and sharp curtailment of the buying power of millions of consumers in metropolitan areas. I recommend
column2: therefore
column3: that rent control be continued for another year.

column1: If we are to achieve a better life for all
column2: the natural resources of the country must be regarded as a public trust. We must use our precious assets of soil
column3: water
column4: and forest
column5: and grassland in such a way that they become constantly more productive and more valuable. Government investment in the conservation and development of our resources is necessary to the future economic expansion of the country.

column1: We need to enlarge the production and transmission of public power. That is true not only in those regions which have already received great benefits from Federal power projects
column2: but also in regions such as New England where the benefits of large-scale public power development have not yet been experienced.

column1: In our hydroelectric and irrigation undertakings
column2: as well as in our other resource programs
column3: we must continue policies to assure that their benefits will be spread among the many and not restricted to the favored few.

column1: Important resource legislation which should be passed at this session includes the authorization of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project and the establishment of the Columbia Valley Administration - the establishment of the Columbia Valley Administration
column2: I don't want you to miss that.

column1: Through wise Government policies and Government expenditures for the conservation and development of our natural resources
column2: we can be sure of transmitting to our children and our children's children a country far richer and more productive than the one we know today.

column1: The value of our natural resources is constantly being increased by the progress of science. Research is finding new ways of using such natural assets as minerals
column2: sea water
column3: and plant life. In the peaceful development of atomic energy
column4: particularly
column5: we stand on the threshold of new wonders. The first experimental machines for producing useful power from atomic energy are now under construction. We have made only the first beginnings in this field
column6: but in the perspective of history they may loom larger than the first airplane
column7: or even the first tools that started man on the road to civilization.

column1: To take full advantage of the increasing possibilities of nature we must equip ourselves with increasing knowledge. Government has a responsibility to see that our country maintains its position in the advance of science. As a step toward this end
column2: the Congress should complete action on the measure to create a National Science Foundation.

column1: Another duty of the Government is to promote the economic security
column2: the health
column3: and the education of its citizens. By so doing
column4: we strengthen both our economy and the structure of our society. In a nation as rich as ours
column5: all citizens should be able to live in decency and health.

column1: Our Social Security System should be developed into the main reliance of our people for basic protection against the economic hazards of old-age
column2: unemployment
column3: and illness. I earnestly hope that the Congress will complete action at this session on legislation to increase the benefits and extend the coverage of old-age and survivors insurance. The widespread movement to provide pensions in private industry dramatizes the need for improvements in the public insurance system.

column1: I also urge that the Congress strengthen our unemployment compensation law to meet present-day needs more adequately. The economic downturn of the past year was the first real test that our system of unemployment insurance has had to meet. That test has proved the wisdom of the system
column2: but it has also made strikingly apparent the need for improving its operation and increasing its coverage and its benefits.

column1: In the field of health there are immense opportunities to extend to more of our people the benefits of the amazing advances in medical science. We have made a good beginning in expanding our hospitals
column2: but we must also go on to remedy the shortages of doctors
column3: nurses
column4: and public health services
column5: and to establish a system of medical insurance which will enable all Americans to afford good medical care.

column1: We must take immediate steps to strengthen our educational system. In many parts of our country
column2: young people are being handicapped for life because of a poor education. The rapidly increasing number of children of school age
column3: coupled with the shortage of qualified teachers
column4: makes this problem more critical each year. I believe that the Congress should no longer delay in providing Federal assistance to the States so that they can maintain adequate schools.

column1: As we go forward in achieving greater economic security and greater opportunity for all our people
column2: we should make every effort to extend the benefits of our democratic institutions to every citizen. The religious ideals which we profess
column3: and the heritage of freedom which we have received from the past
column4: clearly place that duty upon us. I again urge the Congress to enact the civil rights proposals I made in February 1948. These proposals are for the enactment of Federal statutes which will protect all our people in the exercise of their democratic rights and their search for economic opportunity
column5: grant statehood to Alaska and Hawaii
column6: provide a greater measure of self-government for our island possessions
column7: and accord home rule to the District of Columbia. Some of those proposals have been before the Congress for a long time. Those who oppose them
column8: as well as those who favor them
column9: should recognize that it is the duty of the elected representatives of the people to let these proposals come to a vote.

column1: Our democratic ideals
column2: as well as our best interests
column3: require that we do our fair share in providing homes for the unfortunate victims of war and tyranny. In so doing
column4: we shall add strength to our democracy through the abilities and skills which these men and women will bring here. I urge the prompt enactment by the Congress of the legislation now before it to extend and broaden the existing displaced persons law and remove its discriminatory features.

column1: The measures I am recommending to the Congress concerning both our foreign and our domestic policies represent a carefully considered program to meet our national needs. It is a program which necessarily requires large expenditures of funds. More than 70 percent of the Government's expenditures are required to meet the costs of past wars and to work for world peace. This is the dominant factor in our fiscal policy. At the same time
column2: the Government must make substantial expenditures which are necessary to the growth and expansion of the domestic economy.

column1: At present
column2: largely because of the ill-considered tax reduction of the 80th Congress
column3: the Government is not receiving enough revenue to meet its necessary expenditures.

column1: To meet this situation
column2: I am proposing that Federal expenditures be held to the lowest levels consistent with our international requirements and the essential needs of economic growth
column3: and the well-being of our people. I think I had better read that over; you interrupted me in the middle.

column1: To meet this situation
column2: I am proposing that Federal expenditures be held to the lowest levels consistent with our international requirements and the essential needs of ceonomic growth
column3: and the well-being of our people. Don't forget that last phrase. At the same time
column4: we must guard against the folly of attempting budget slashes which would impair our prospects for peace or cripple the programs essential to our national strength.

column1: The budget recommendations I shall shortly transmit to the Congress show that we can expect a substantial improvement in our fiscal position over the next few years
column2: as the cost of some of our extraordinary postwar programs declines
column3: and as the Government revenue rises as a result of growth in employment and national income. To further improve our fiscal outlook
column4: we should make some changes in our tax system which will reduce present inequities
column5: stimulate business activity
column6: and yield a moderate amount of additional revenue. I expect to transmit specific recommendations to the Congress on this subject at a very early date.

column1: The fiscal policy I am recommending is the quickest and safest way of achieving a balanced budget.
As we move forward into the second half of the 20th century
column2: we must always bear in mind the central purpose of our national life. We do not seek material prosperity for ourselves because we love luxury; we do not aid other nations because we wish to increase our power. We have not devised programs for the security and well-being of our people because we are afraid or unwilling to take risks. This is not the meaning of our past history or our present course.

column1: We work for a better life for all
column2: so that all men may put to good use the great gifts with which they have been endowed by their Creator. We seek to establish those material conditions of life in which
column3: without exception
column4: men may live in dignity
column5: perform useful work
column6: serve their communities
column7: and worship God as they see fit.

column1: These may seem simple goals
column2: but they are not little ones. They are worth a great deal more than all the empires and conquests of history. They are not to be achieved by military aggression or political fanaticism. They are to be achieved by humbler means---by hard work
column3: by a spirit of self-restraint in our dealings with one another
column4: and by a deep devotion to the principles of justice and equality.

column1: It should make us truly thankful
column2: as we look back to the beginnings of this country
column3: that we have come so far along the road to a better life for all. It should make us humble to think
column4: as we look ahead
column5: how much farther we have to go to accomplish
column6: at home and abroad
column7: the objectives that were set out for us at the founding of this great Nation. As we approach the halfway mark of the 20th century
column8: we should ask for continued strength and guidance from that Almighty Power who has placed before us such great opportunities for the good of mankind in the years to come.@

column1: Harry S. Truman|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1951-01-08|@Mr. President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members Of the Congress:

column1: This 82d Congress faces as grave a task as any Congress in the history of our Republic. The actions you take will be watched by the whole world. These actions will measure the ability of a free people
column2: acting through their chosen representatives and their free institutions
column3: to meet a deadly challenge to their way of life.

column1: We can meet this challenge foolishly or wisely. We can meet it timidly or bravely
column2: shamefully or honorably.

column1: I know that the 82d Congress will meet this challenge in a way worthy of our great heritage. I know that your debates will be earnest
column2: responsible
column3: constructive
column4: and to the point. I know that from these debates there will come the great decisions needed to carry us forward.

column1: At this critical time
column2: I am glad to say that our country is in a healthy condition. Our democratic institutions are sound and strong. We have more men and women at work than ever before. We are able to produce more than ever before in fact
column3: far more than any country ever produced in the history of the world.

column1: I am confident that we can succeed in the great task that lies before us.
We will succeed
column2: but we must all do our part. We must all act together as citizens of this great Republic.

column1: As we meet here today
column2: American soldiers are fighting a bitter campaign in Korea. We pay tribute to their courage
column3: devotion
column4: and gallantry.

column1: Our men are fighting
column2: alongside their United Nations allies
column3: because they know
column4: as we do
column5: that the aggression in Korea is part of the attempt of the Russian Communist dictatorship to take over the world
column6: step by step.

column1: Our men are fighting a long way from home
column2: but they are fighting for our lives and our liberties. They are fighting to protect our right to meet here today-our right to govern ourselves as a free nation.

column1: The threat of world conquest by Soviet Russia endangers our liberty and endangers the kind of world in which the free spirit of man can survive. This threat is aimed at all peoples who strive to win or defend their own freedom and national independence.
Indeed
column2: the state of our Nation is in great part the state of our friends and allies throughout the world. The gun that points at them points at us
column3: also. The threat is a total threat and the danger is a common danger.

column1: All free nations are exposed and all are in peril. Their only security lies in banding together. No one nation can find protection in a selfish search for a safe haven from the storm.
The free nations do not have any aggressive purpose. We want only peace in the world-peace for all countries. No threat to the security of any nation is concealed in our plans and programs.
We had hoped that the Soviet Union
column2: with its security assured by the Charter of the United Nations
column3: would be willing to live and let live. But I am sorry to say that has not been the case.

column1: The imperialism of the czars has been replaced by the even more ambitious
column2: more crafty
column3: and more menacing imperialism of the rulers of the Soviet Union.

column1: This new imperialism has powerful military forces. It is keeping millions of men under arms. It has a large air force and a strong submarine force. It has complete control of the men and equipment of its satellites. It has kept its subject peoples and i ts economy in a state of perpetual mobilization.
The present rulers of the Soviet Union have shown that they are willing to use this power to destroy the free nations and win domination over the whole world.
The Soviet imperialists have two ways of going about their destructive work. They use the method of subversion and internal revolution
column2: and they use the method of external aggression. In preparation for either of these methods of attack
column3: they stir up cl ass strife and disorder. They encourage sabotage. They put out poisonous propaganda. They deliberately try to prevent economic improvement.

column1: If their efforts are successful
column2: they foment a revolution
column3: as they did in Czechoslovakia and China
column4: and as they tried
column5: unsuccessfully
column6: to do in Greece. If their methods of subversion are blocked
column7: and if they think they can get away with outright warfare
column8: they resort to external aggression. This is what they did when they loosed the armies of their puppet states against the Republic of Korea
column9: in an evil war by proxy.

column1: We of the free world must be ready to meet both of these methods of Soviet action. We must not neglect one or the other.
The free world has power and resources to meet these two forms of aggression resources that are far greater than those of the Soviet dictatorship. We have skilled and vigorous peoples
column2: great industrial strength
column3: and abundant sources of raw materials. And above all
column4: we cherish liberty. Our common ideals are a great part of our strength. These ideals are the driving force of human progress.

column1: The free nations believe in the dignity and the worth of man.
We believe in independence for all nations.
We believe that free and independent nations can band together into a world order based on law. We have laid the cornerstone of such a peaceful world in the United Nations.
We believe that such a world order can and should spread the benefits of modern science and industry
column2: better health and education
column3: more food and rising standards of living-throughout the world.

column1: These ideals give our cause a power and vitality that Russian communism can never command.
The free nations
column2: however
column3: are bound together by more than ideals. They are a real community bound together also by the ties of self-interest and self-preservation. If they should fall apart
column4: the results would be fatal to human freedom.

column1: Our own national security is deeply involved with that of the other free nations. While they need our support
column2: we equally need theirs. Our national safety would be gravely prejudiced if the Soviet Union were to succeed in harnessing to its war machine th e resources and the manpower of the free nations on the borders of its empire.

column1: If Western Europe were to fall to Soviet Russia
column2: it would double the Soviet supply of coal and triple the Soviet supply of steel. If the free countries of Asia and Africa should fall to Soviet Russia
column3: we would lose the sources of many of our most vital r aw materials
column4: including uranium
column5: which is the basis of our atomic power. And Soviet command of the manpower of the free nations of Europe and Asia would confront us with military forces which we could never hope to equal.

column1: In such a situation
column2: the Soviet Union could impose its demands on the world
column3: without resort to conflict
column4: simply through the preponderance of its economic and military power. The Soviet Union does not have to attack the United States to secure domination of the world. It can achieve its ends by isolating us and swallowing up all our allies. Therefore
column5: even if we were craven enough-I do not believe we could be-but
column6: I say
column7: even if we were craven enough to aband on our ideals
column8: it would be disastrous for us to withdraw from the community of free nations.

column1: We are the most powerful single member of this community
column2: and we have a special responsibility. We must take the leadership in meeting the challenge to freedom and in helping to protect the rights of independent nations.

column1: This country has a practical
column2: realistic protect gram of action for meeting this challenge.

column1: First
column2: we shall have to extend economic assistance
column3: where it can be effective. The best way to stop subversion by the Kremlin is to strike at the roots of social injustice and economic disorder. People who have jobs
column4: homes
column5: and hopes for the future will defend themselves against the underground agents of the Kremlin. Our programs of economic aid have done much to turn back communism.

column1: In Europe the Marshall plan has had an electrifying result. As European recovery progressed
column2: the strikes led by the Kremlin's agents in Italy and France failed. All over Western Europe the Communist Party took worse and worse beatings at the polls.

column1: The countries which have received Marshall Plan aid have been able
column2: through hard work
column3: to expand their productive strength in many cases
column4: to levels higher than ever before in their history. Without this strength they would be completely incapable of def ending themselves today. They are now ready to use this strength in helping to build a strong combined defense against aggression.

column1: We shall need to continue some economic aid to European countries. This aid should now be specifically related to the building of their defenses.
In other parts of the world our economic assistance will need to be more broadly directed toward economic development. In the Near East
column2: in Africa
column3: in Asia
column4: we must do what we can to help people who are striving to advance from misery
column5: poverty
column6: and hung er. We must also continue to help the economic growth of our good neighbors in this hemisphere. These actions will bring greater strength for the free world. They will give many people a real stake in the future and reason to defend their freedom. They will mean increased production of goods they need and materials we need.

column1: Second
column2: we shall need to continue our military assistance to countries which want to defend themselves.

column1: The heart of our common defense effort is the North Atlantic community. The defense of Europe is the basis for the defense of the whole free world-ourselves included. Next to the United States
column2: Europe is the largest workshop in the world. It is also a ho meland of the great religious beliefs shared by many of our citizens-beliefs which are now threatened by the tide of atheistic communism.

column1: Strategically
column2: economically
column3: and morally
column4: the defense of Europe is a part of our own defense. That is why we have joined with the countries of Europe in the North Atlantic Treaty
column5: pledging ourselves to work with them.

column1: There has been much discussion recently over whether the European countries are willing to defend themselves. Their actions are answering this question.

Our North Atlantic Treaty partners have strict systems of universal military training. Several have recently increased the term of service. All have taken measures to improve the quality of training. Forces are being trained and expanded as rapidly as th e necessary arms and equipment can be supplied from their factories and ours. Our North Atlantic Treaty partners
column2: together
column3: are building armies bigger than our own.

column1: None of the North Atlantic Treaty countries
column2: including our own country
column3: has done enough yet. But real progress is being made. Together
column4: we have worked out defense plans. The military leaders of our own country took part in working out these plans
column5: and a re agreed that they are sound and within our capabilities.

column1: To put these plans into action
column2: we sent to Europe last week one of our greatest military commanders
column3: General Dwight D. Eisenhower.

column1: General Eisenhower went to Europe to assume command of the united forces of the North Atlantic Treaty countries
column2: including our own forces in Germany.

column1: The people of Europe have confidence in General Eisenhower. They know his ability to put together a fighting force of allies. His mission is vital to our security. We should all stand behind him
column2: and give him every bit of help we can.

column1: Part of our job will be to reinforce the military strength of our European partners by sending them weapons and equipment as our military production expands.
Our program of military assistance extends to the nations in the Near East and the Far East which are trying to defend their freedom. Soviet communism is trying to make these nations into colonies
column2: and to use their people as cannon fodder in new wars of conquest. We want their people to be free men and to enjoy peace.

column1: Our country has always stood for freedom for the peoples of Asia. Long
column2: long ago it stood for the freedom of the peoples of Asia. Our history shows this. We have demonstrated it in the Philippines. We have demonstrated it in our relations with Indonesia
column3: India
column4: and with China. We hope to join in restoring the people of Japan to membership in the community of free nations.

column1: It is in the Far East that we have taken up arms
column2: under the United Nations
column3: to preserve the principle of independence for free nations. We are fighting to keep the forces of Communist aggression from making a slave state out of Korea.

column1: Korea has tremendous significance for the world. It means that free nations
column2: acting through the United Nations
column3: are fighting together against aggression.

column1: We will understand the importance of this best if we look back into history. If the democracies had stood up against the invasion of Manchuria in 1931
column2: or the attack on Ethiopia in 1935
column3: or the seizure of Austria in 1938
column4: if they had stood together again st aggression on those occasions as the United Nations has done in Korea
column5: the whole history of our time would have been different.

column1: The principles for which we are fighting in Korea are right and just. They are the foundations of collective security and of the future of free nations. Korea is not only a country undergoing the torment of aggression; it is also a symbol. It stands for right and justice in the world against oppression and slavery. The free world must always stand for these principles-and we will stand with the free world.
As the third part of our program
column2: we will continue to work for peaceful settlements in international disputes. We will support the United Nations and remain loyal to the great principles of international cooperation laid down in its charter.

column1: We are willing
column2: as we have always been
column3: to negotiate honorable settlements with the Soviet Union. But we will not engage in appeasement.

column1: The Soviet rulers have made it clear that we must have strength as well as right on our side. If we build our strength-and we are building it-the Soviet rulers may face the facts and lay aside their plans to take over the world.
That is what we hope will happen
column2: and that is what we are trying to bring about. That is the only realistic road to peace.

column1: These are the main elements of the course our Nation must follow as a member of the community of free nations. These are the things we must do to preserve our security and help create a peaceful world. But they will be successful only if we increase the strength of our own country.
Here at home we have some very big jobs to do. We are building much stronger military forces-and we are building them fast. We are preparing for full wartime mobilization
column2: if that should be necessary. And we are continuing to build a strong and growing economy
column3: able to maintain whatever effort may be required for as long as necessary.

column1: We are building our own Army
column2: Navy
column3: and Air Force to an active strength of nearly 3 1/2 million men and women. We are stepping up the training of the reserve forces
column4: and establishing more training facilities
column5: so that we can rapidly increase our active fo rces far more on short notice.

column1: We are going to produce all the weapons and equipment that such an armed force will need. Furthermore
column2: we will make weapons for our allies
column3: and weapons for our own reserve supplies. On top of this
column4: we will build the capacity to turn out on short notice arms and supplies that may be needed for a full-scale war.

column1: Fortunately
column2: we have a good start on this because of our enormous plant capacity and because of the equipment on hand from the last war. For example
column3: many combat ships are being returned to active duty from the "mothball fleet" and many others can be put into service on very short notice. We have large reserves of arms and ammunition and thousands of workers skilled in arms production.

column1: In many cases
column2: however
column3: our stocks of weapons are low. In other cases
column4: those on hand are not the most modern. We have made remarkable technical advances. We have developed new types of jet planes and powerful new tanks. We are concentrating on producing the newest types of weapons and producing them as fast as we can.

column1: This production drive is more selective than the one we had during World War II
column2: but it is just as urgent and intense. It is a big program and it is a costly one.

column1: Let me give you two concrete examples. Our present program calls for expanding the aircraft industry so that it will have the capacity to produce 50
column2: 000 modern military planes a year. We are preparing the capacity to produce 35
column3: 000 tanks a year. We are not now ordering that many planes or that many tanks
column4: and we hope that we never have to
column5: but we mean to be able to turn them out if we need them.

column1: The planes we are producing now are much bigger
column2: much better
column3: and much more expensive than the planes we had during the last war.

column1: We used to think that the B-17 was a huge plane
column2: and the blockbuster it carried a huge load. But the B-36 can carry five of these blockbusters in its belly
column3: and it can carry them five times as far. Of course
column4: the B-36 is much more complicated to build than the B-17
column5: and far more expensive. One B-17 costs $275
column7: while now one B-36 costs 3 million.

column1: I ask you to remember that what we are doing is to provide the best and most modern military equipment in the world for our fighting forces.

This kind of defense production program has two parts. The first part is to get our defense protect production going as fast as possible. We have to convert plants and channel materials to defense production. This means heavy cuts in civilian uses of copper
column2: aluminum
column3: rubber
column4: and other essential materials. It means shortages in various consumer goods.

column1: The second part is to increase our capacity to produce and to keep our economy strong for the long pull. We do not know how long Communist aggression will threaten the world.
Only by increasing our output can we carry the burden of preparedness for an indefinite period in the future. This means that we will have to build more power plants and more steel mills
column2: grow more cotton
column3: mine more copper
column4: and expand our capacity in many other ways.

column1: The Congress will need to consider legislation
column2: at this session
column3: affecting all the aspects of our mobilization job. The main subjects on which legislation will be needed are:

column1: First
column2: appropriations for our military buildup.

column1: Second
column2: extension and revision of the Selective Service Act.

column1: Third
column2: military and economic aid to help build up the strength of the free world.

column1: Fourth
column2: revision and extension of the authority to expand production and to stabilize prices
column3: wages
column4: and rents.

column1: Fifth
column2: improvement of our agricultural laws to help obtain the kinds of farm products we need for the defense effort.

column1: Sixth
column2: improvement of our labor laws to help provide stable labor-management relations and to make sure that we have steady production in this emergency.

column1: Seventh
column2: housing and training of defense workers and the full use of all our manpower resources.

column1: Eighth
column2: means for increasing the supply of doctors
column3: nurses
column4: and other trained medical personnel critically needed for the defense effort.

column1: Ninth
column2: aid to the States to meet the most urgent needs of our elementary and secondary schools. Some of our plans will have to be deferred for the time being. But we should do all we can to make sure our children are being trained as good and useful citizens in the critical times ahead.

column1: Tenth
column2: a major increase in taxes to meet the cost of the defense effort.

column1: The Economic Report and the Budget Message will discuss these subjects further. In addition
column2: I shall send to the Congress special messages containing detailed recommendations on legislation needed at this session.

column1: In the months ahead the Government must give priority to activities that are urgent-like military procurement and atomic energy and power development. It must practice rigid economy in its non defense activities. Many of the things we would normally do must be curtailed or postponed.
But in a long-term defense effort like this one
column2: we cannot neglect the measures needed to maintain a strong economy and a healthy democratic society.

column1: The Congress
column2: therefore
column3: should give continued attention to the measures which our country will need for the long pull. And it should act upon such legislation as promptly as circumstances permit.

column1: To take just one example-we need to continue and complete the work of rounding out our system of social insurance. We still need to improve our protection against unemployment and old age. We still need to provide insurance against the loss of earnings through sickness
column2: and against the high costs of modern medical care.

column1: And above all
column2: we must remember that the fundamentals of our strength rest upon the freedoms of our people. We must continue our efforts to achieve the full realization of our democratic ideals. We must uphold the freedom of speech and the freedom of conscience in our land. We must assure equal rights and equal opportunities to all our citizens.

column1: As we go forward this year in the defense of freedom
column2: let us keep clearly before us the nature of our present effort.

column1: We are building up our strength
column2: in concert with other free nations
column3: to meet the danger of aggression that has been turned loose on the world. The strength of the free nations is the world's best hope of peace.

column1: I ask the Congress for unity in these crucial days.
Make no mistake about my meaning. I do not ask
column2: or expect
column3: unanimity. I do not ask for an end to debate. Only by debate can we arrive at decisions which are wise
column4: and which reflect the desires of the American people. We do not have a dictatorship in this country
column5: and we never will have one in this country.

column1: When I request unity
column2: what I am really asking for is a sense of responsibility on the part of every Member of this Congress. Let us debate the issues
column3: but let every man among us weigh his words and his deeds. There is a sharp difference between harmful criticism and constructive criticism. If we are truly responsible as individuals
column4: I am sure that we will be unified as a government.

column1: Let us keep our eyes on the issues and work for the things we all believe in.
Let each of us put our country ahead of our party
column2: and ahead of our own personal interests.

column1: I had the honor to be a Member of the Senate during World War II
column2: and I know from experience that unity of purpose and of effort is possible in the Congress without any lessening of the vitality of our two party system.

column1: Let us all stand together as Americans. Let us stand together with all men every where who believe in human liberty.
Peace is precious to us. It is the way of life we strive for with all the strength and wisdom we possess. But more precious than peace are freedom and justice. We will fight
column2: if fight we must
column3: to keep our freedom and to prevent justice from being destroyed.

column1: These are the things that give meaning to our lives
column2: and which we acknowledge to be greater than ourselves.

column1: This is our cause-peace
column2: freedom
column3: justice. We will pursue this cause with determination and humility
column4: asking divine guidance that in all we do we may follow the will of God.@

column1: Harry S. Truman|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1952-01-09|@Mr. President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members of the Congress:

column1: I have the honor to report to the Congress on the state of the Union.
At the outset
column2: I should like to speak of the necessity for putting first things first as we work together this year for the good of our country.

column1: The United States and the whole free world are passing through a period of grave danger. Every action you take here in Congress
column2: and every action that I take as President
column3: must be measured against the test of whether it helps to meet that danger.

column1: This will be a presidential election year-the year in which politics plays a large part in our lives--a larger part than usual. That is perfectly proper. But we have a greater responsibility to conduct our political fights in a manner that does not harm the national interest.
We can find plenty of things to differ about without destroying our free institutions and without abandoning our bipartisan foreign policy for peace.
When everything is said and done
column2: all of us--Republicans and Democrats alike--all of us are Americans; and we are all going to sink or swim together.

column1: We are moving through a perilous time. Faced with a terrible threat of aggression
column2: our Nation has embarked upon a great effort to help establish the kind of world in which peace shall be secure. Peace is our goal-not peace at any price
column3: but a peace based on freedom and justice. We are now in the midst of our effort to reach that goal. On the whole
column4: we have been doing very well.

column1: Last year
column3: was a year in which we threw back aggression
column4: added greatly to our military strength
column5: and improved the chances for peace and freedom in many parts of the world.

column1: This year
column3: is a critical year in the defense effort of the whole free world. If we falter we can lose all the gains we have made. If we drive ahead
column4: with courage and vigor and determination
column5: we can by the end of 1952 be in a position of much greater security. The way will be dangerous for the years ahead
column6: but if we put forth our best efforts this year--and next year--we can be "over the hump" in our effort to build strong defenses.

column1: When we look at the record of the past year
column3: we find important things on both the credit and the debit side of the ledger. We have made great advances. At the same time we have run into new problems which must be overcome.

column1: Now let us look at the credit side first.
Peace depends upon the free nations sticking together
column2: and making a combined effort to check aggression and prevent war. In this respect
column3: 1951 was a year of great achievement.

column1: In Korea the forces of the United Nations turned back the Chinese Communist invasion-and did it without widening the area of conflict. The action of the United Nations in Korea has been a powerful deterrent to a third world war. However
column2: the situation in Korea remains very hazardous. The outcome of the armistice negotiation still remains uncertain.

column1: In Indochina and Malaya
column2: our aid has helped our allies to hold back the Communist advance
column3: although there are signs of further trouble in that area.

column1: In 1951 we strengthened the chances of peace in the Pacific region by the treaties with Japan and the defense arrangements with Australia
column2: New Zealand
column3: and the Philippines.

column1: In Europe combined defense has become a reality. The free nations have created a real fighting force. This force is not yet as strong as it needs to be; but it is already a real obstacle to any attempt by hostile forces to sweep across Europe to the Atlantic.
In 1951 we also moved to strengthen the security of Europe by the agreement to bring Greece and Turkey into the North Atlantic Treaty.
The United Nations
column2: the world's greatest hope for peace
column3: has come through a year of trial stronger and more useful than ever. The free nations have stood together in blocking Communist attempts to tear up the charter.

column1: At the present session of the United Nations in Paris
column2: we
column3: together with the British and the French
column4: offered a plan to reduce and control all armaments under a foolproof inspection system. This is a concrete
column5: practical proposal for disarmament.

column1: But what happened ? Vishinsky laughed at it. Listen to what he said: "I could hardly sleep at all last night .... I could not sleep because I kept laughing." The world will be a long time forgetting the spectacle of that fellow laughing at disarmament.
Disarmament is not a joke. Vishinsky's laughter met with shock and anger from the people all over the world. And
column2: as a result
column3: Mr. Stalin's representative received orders to stop laughing and start talking.

column1: If the Soviet leaders were to accept this proposal
column2: it would lighten the burden of armaments
column3: and permit the resources of the earth to be devoted to the good of mankind. But until the Soviet Union accepts a sound disarmament proposal
column4: and joins in peaceful settlements
column5: we have no choice except to build up our defenses.

column1: During this past year we added more than a million men and women to our Armed Forces. The total is now nearly 3 and a half million. We have made rapid progress in the field of atomic weapons. We have turned out billion worth of military supplies and equipment
column2: three times as much as the year before.

column1: Economic conditions in the country are good. There are 61 million people on the job; wages
column2: farm incomes
column3: and business profits are at high levels. Total production of goods and services in our country has increased 8 percent over last year--about twice the normal rate of growth.

column1: Perhaps the most amazing thing about our economic progress is the way we are increasing our basic capacity to produce. For example
column2: we are now in the second year of a 3-year program which will double our output of aluminum
column3: increase our electric power supply by 40 percent
column4: and increase our steelmaking capacity by 15 percent. We can then produce 120 million tons of steel a year
column5: as much as all the rest of the world put together.

column1: This expansion will mean more jobs and higher standards of living for all of us in the years ahead. At the present time it means greater strength for us and for the rest of the free world in the fight for peace.
Now
column2: I must turn to the debit side of the ledger for the past year.

column1: The outstanding fact to note on the debit side of the ledger is that the Soviet Union
column3: continued to expand its military production and increase its already excessive military power.

column1: It is true that the Soviets have run into increasing difficulties. Their hostile policies have awakened stern resistance among free men throughout the world. And behind the Iron Curtain the Soviet rule of force has created growing political and economic stresses in the satellite nations.
Nevertheless
column2: the grim fact remains that the Soviet Union is increasing its armed might. It is still producing more war planes than the free nations. It has set off two more atomic explosions. The world still walks in the shadow of another world war.

column1: And here at home
column2: our defense preparations are far from complete.

column1: During 1951 we did not make adequate progress in building up civil defense against atomic attack. This is a major weakness in our plans for peace
column2: since inadequate civilian defense is an open invitation to a surprise attack. Failure to provide adequate civilian defense has the same effect as adding to the enemy's supply of atomic bombs.

column1: In the field of defense production we have run into difficulties and delays in designing and producing the latest types of airplanes and tanks. Some machine tools and metals are still in extremely short supply.
In other free countries the defense buildup has created severe economic problems. It has increased inflation in Europe and has endangered the continued recovery of our allies.
In the Middle East political tensions and the oil controversy in Iran are keeping the region in a turmoil. In the Far East the dark threat of Communist imperialism still hangs over many nations.
This
column2: very briefly
column3: is the good side and the bad side of the picture.

column1: Taking the good and bad together
column2: we have made real progress this last year along the road to peace. We have increased the power and unity of the free world. And while we were doing this
column3: we have avoided world war on the one hand
column4: and appeasement on the other. This is a hard road to follow
column5: but the events of the last year show that it is the right road to peace.

column1: We cannot expect to complete the job overnight. The free nations may have to maintain for years the larger military forces needed to deter aggression. We must build steadily
column2: over a period of years
column3: toward political solidarity and economic progress among the free nations in all parts of the world.

column1: Our task will not be easy; but if we go at it with a will
column2: we can look forward to steady progress. On our side are all the great resources of freedom--the ideals of religion and democracy
column3: the aspiration of people for a better life
column4: and the industrial and technical power of a free civilization.

column1: These advantages outweigh anything the slave world can produce. The only thing that can defeat us is our own state of mind. We can lose if we falter.
The middle period of a great national effort like this is a very difficult time. The way seems long and hard. The goal seems far distant. Some people get discouraged. That is only natural.
But if there are any among us who think we ought to ease up in the fight for peace
column2: I want to remind them of three things--just three things.

column1: First: The threat of world war is still very real. We had one Pearl Harbor--let's not get caught off guard again. If you don't think the threat of Communist armies is real
column2: talk to some of our men back from Korea.

column1: Second: If the United States had to try to stand alone against a Soviet-dominated world
column2: it would destroy the life we know and the ideals we hold dear. Our allies are essential to us
column3: just as we are essential to them. The more shoulders there are to bear the burden the lighter that burden will be.

column1: Third: The things we believe in most deeply are under relentless attack. We have the great responsibility of saving the basic moral and spiritual values of our civilization. We have started out well--with a program for peace that is unparalleled in history. If we believe in ourselves and the faith we profess
column2: we will stick to that job until it is victoriously finished.

column1: This is a time for courage
column2: not for grumbling and mumbling.

column1: Now
column2: let us take a look at the things we have to do.

column1: The thing that is uppermost in the minds of all of us is the situation in Korea. We must
column2: and we will
column3: keep up the fight there until we get the kind of armistice that will put an end to the aggression and protect the safety of our forces and the security of the Republic of Korea. Beyond that we shall continue to work for a settlement in Korea that upholds the principles of the United Nations.

column1: We went into Korea because we knew that Communist aggression had to be met firmly if freedom was to be preserved in the world. We went into the fight to save the Republic of Korea
column2: a free country
column3: established under the United Nations. These are our aims. We will not give up until we attain them.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: we must continue to strengthen the forces of freedom throughout the world.

column1: I hope the Senate will take early and favorable action on the Japanese peace treaty
column2: on our security pacts with the Pacific countries
column3: and on the agreement to bring Greece and Turkey into the North Atlantic Treaty.

column1: We are also negotiating an agreement with the German Federal Republic under which it can play an honorable and equal part among nations and take its place in the defense of Western Europe.
But treaties and plans are only the skeleton of our defense structure. The sinew and muscle of defense are the forces and equipment which must be provided.

In Europe we must go on helping our friends and allies to build up their military forces. This means we must send weapons in large volume to our European allies. I have directed that weapons for Europe be given a very high priority. Economic aid is necessary
column2: too
column3: to supply the margin of difference between success and failure in making Europe a strong partner in our joint defense.

column1: In the long run we want to see Europe freed from any dependence on our aid. Our European allies want that just as bad as we do. The steps that are now being taken to build European unity should help bring that about. Six European countries are pooling their coal and steel production under the Schuman plan. Work is going forward on the merger of European national forces on the Continent into a single army. These great projects should become realities in 1952.
We should do all we can to help and encourage the move toward a strong and united Europe.

In Asia the new Communist empire is a daily threat to millions of people. The peoples of Asia want to be free to follow their own way of life. They want to preserve their culture and their traditions against communism
column2: just as much as we want to preserve ours. They are laboring under terrific handicaps--poverty
column3: ill health
column4: feudal systems of land ownership
column5: and the threat of internal subversion or external attack. We can and we must increase our help to them.

column1: This means military aid
column2: especially to those places like Indochina which might be hardest hit by some new Communist attack.

column1: It also means economic aid
column2: both technical know-how and capital investment.

column1: This last year we made available millions of bushels of wheat to relieve famine in India. But far more important
column2: in the long run
column3: is the work Americans are doing in India to help the Indian farmers themselves raise more grain. With the help of our technicians
column4: Indian farmers
column5: using simple
column6: inexpensive means
column7: have been able since 1948 to double the crops in one area in India. One farmer there raised 63 bushels of wheat to the acre
column8: where 13 bushels had been the average before.

column1: This is point 4--our point 4 program at work. It is working--not only in India but in Iran
column2: Paraguay
column3: Liberia--in 33 countries around the globe. Our technical missionaries are out there. We need more of them. We need more funds to speed their efforts
column4: because there is nothing of greater importance in all our foreign policy. There is nothing that shows more clearly what we stand for
column5: and what we want to achieve.

column1: My friends of the Congress
column2: less than one-third of the expenditure for the cost of World War II would have created the developments necessary to feed the whole world so we wouldn't have to stomach communism. That is what we have got to fight
column3: and unless we fight that battle and win it
column4: we can't win the cold war or a hot one either.

column1: We have recently lost a great public servant who was leading this effort to bring opportunity and hope to the people of half the world. Dr. Henry Bennett and his associates died in line of duty on a point 4 mission. It is up to us to carry on the great work for which they gave their lives.
During the coming year we must not forget the suffering of the people who live behind the Iron Curtain. In those areas minorities are being oppressed
column2: human rights violated
column3: religions persecuted. We should continue to expose those wrongs. We should continue and expand the activities of the Voice of America
column4: which brings our message of hope and truth to those peoples and other peoples throughout the world.

column1: I have just had an opportunity to discuss many of these world problems with Prime Minister Churchill. We have had a most satisfactory series of meetings. We thoroughly reviewed the situation in Europe
column2: the Middle East
column3: and the Far East. We both look forward to steady progress toward peace through the cooperative action and teamwork of the free nations.

column1: Turning from our foreign policies
column2: let us consider the jobs we have here at home as a part of our program for peace.

column1: The first of these jobs is to move ahead full steam on the defense program.

Our objective is to have a well-equipped active defense force large enough--in concert with the forces of our allies--to deter aggression and to inflict punishing losses on the enemy immediately if we should be attacked. This active force must be backed by adequate reserves
column2: and by the plants and tools to turn out the tremendous quantities of new weapons that would be needed if war came. We are not building an active force adequate to carry on full scale war
column3: but we are putting ourselves in a position to mobilize very rapidly if we have to.

column1: This year I shall recommend some increases in the size of the active force we are building
column2: with particular emphasis on air power. This means we shall have to continue large-scale production of planes and other equipment for a longer period of time than we had originally planned.

column1: Planes and tanks and other weapons-what the military call "hard goods"--are now beginning to come off the production lines in volume. Deliveries of hard goods now amount to about a billion and a half dollars worth a month. A year from now
column2: we expect that rate to be doubled.

column1: We shall have to hold to a high rate of military output for about a year after that. In 1954 we hope to have enough equipment so that we can reduce the production of most military items substantially. The next 2 years should therefore be the peak period of defense production.
Defense needs will take a lot of steel
column2: aluminum
column3: copper
column4: nickel
column5: and other scarce materials. This means smaller production of some civilian goods. The cutbacks will be nothing like those during World War II
column6: when most civilian production was completely stopped. But there will be considerably less of some goods than we have been used to these past 2 or 3 years.

column1: The very critical part of our defense job this year is to keep down inflation.
We can control inflation if we make up our minds to do it.
On the executive side of the Government
column2: we intend to hold the line on prices just as tightly as the law allows. We will permit only those wage increases which are clearly justified under sound stabilization policies; and we will see to it that industries absorb cost increases out of earnings wherever feasible
column3: before they are authorized to raise prices. We will do that
column4: at any rate
column5: except where the recent amendments to the law specifically require us to give further price increases.

column1: Congress has a tremendous responsibility in this matter. Our stabilization law was shot full of holes at the last session. This year
column2: it will be one of the main tasks before the Congress to repair the damage and enact a strong anti-inflation law.

column1: As a part of our program to keep our country strong
column2: we are determined to preserve the financial strength of the Government. This means high taxes over the next few years. We must see to it that these taxes are shared among the people as fairly as possible. I expect to discuss these matters in the Economic Report and the Budget Message which will soon be presented to the Congress.

column1: Our tax laws must be fair. And we must make absolutely certain they are administered fairly
column2: without fear or favor of any kind for anybody. To this end
column3: steps have already been taken to remedy weaknesses which have been disclosed in the administration of the tax laws. In addition
column4: I hope the Congress will approve my reorganization plan for the Bureau of Internal Revenue. We must do everything necessary in order to make just as certain as is humanly possible that every taxpayer receives equal treatment under the law.

column1: To carry the burden of defense we must have a strong
column2: productive
column3: and expanding economy here at home. We cannot neglect those things that have made us the great and powerful nation we are today.

column1: Our strength depends upon the health
column2: the morale
column3: the freedom of our people. We can take on the burden of leadership in the fight for world peace because
column4: for nearly 20 years
column5: the Government and the people have been working together for the general welfare. We have given more and more of out citizens a fair chance at decent
column6: useful
column7: productive lives. That is the reason we are as strong as we are today.

column1: This Government of ours--the Congress and the executive both--must keep on working to bring about a fair deal for all the American people. Some people will say that we haven't the time or the money this year for measures for the welfare of the people. But if we want to win the fight for peace
column2: this is a part of the job we cannot ignore.

column1: We will have to give up some things
column2: we will have to go forward on others at a slower pace. But
column3: so far as I am concerned
column4: I do not think we can give up the things that are vital to our national strength.

column1: I believe most people in this country will agree with me on that.
I think most farmers understand that soil conservation and rural electrification and agricultural research are not frills or luxuries
column2: but real necessities in order to boost our farm production.

column1: I think most workers understand that decent housing and good working conditions are not luxuries
column2: but necessities if the working men and women of this country are to continue to out-produce the rest of the world.

column1: I think our businessmen know that scientific research and transportation services and more steel mills and power projects are not luxuries
column2: but necessities to keep our business and our industry in the forefront of industrial progress.

column1: I think everybody knows that social insurance and better schools and health services are not frills
column2: but necessities in helping all Americans to be useful and productive citizens
column3: who can contribute their full share in the national effort to protect and advance our way of life.

column1: We cannot do all we want to in times like these--we have to choose the things that will contribute most to defense--but we must continue to make progress if we are to be a strong nation in the years ahead.
Let me give you some examples.
We are going right ahead with the urgently needed work to develop our natural resources
column2: to conserve our soil
column3: and to prevent floods. We are going to produce essential power and build the lines that are necessary and that we have to have to transmit it to our farms and factories. We are going to encourage exploration for new mineral deposits.

column1: We are going to keep on building essential highways and taking any other steps that will assure the Nation an adequate transportation system--on land
column2: on the sea
column3: and in the air.

column1: We must move right ahead this year to see that defense workers and soldiers' families get decent housing at rents they can afford to pay.

We must begin our long deferred program of Federal aid to education--to help the States meet the present crisis in the operation of our schools. And we must help with the construction of schools in areas where they are critically needed because of the defense effort.
We urgently need to train more doctors and other health personnel
column2: through aid to medical education. We also urgently need to expand the basic public health services in our home communities--especially in defense areas. The Congress should go ahead with these two measures immediately.

column1: I have set up an impartial commission to make a thorough study of the Nation's health needs. One of the things this commission is looking into is how to bring the cost of modern medical care within the reach of all the people. I have repeatedly recommended national health insurance as the best way to do this. So far as I know
column2: it is still the best way. If there are any better answers
column3: I hope this commission will find them. But of one thing I am sure: something must be done
column4: and done soon.

column1: This year we ought to make a number of urgently needed improvements in our social security law. For one thing
column2: benefits under old-age and survivors insurance should be raised $5 a month above the present average of $42. For another thing
column3: the States should be given special aid to help them increase public assistance payments. By doing these things now
column4: we can ease the pressure of living costs for people who depend on those fixed payments.

column1: We should also make some cost-of-living adjustments for those receiving veterans' compensation for death or disability incurred in the service of our country. In addition
column2: now is the time to start a sensible program of readjustment benefits for our veterans who have seen service since the fighting broke out in Korea.

column1: Another thing the Congress should do at this session is to strengthen our system of farm price supports to meet the defense emergency. The "sliding scale" in the price support law should not be allowed to penalize farmers for increasing production to meet defense needs. We should also find a new and less costly method for supporting perishable commodities than the law now provides.

We need to act promptly to improve our labor law. The Taft-Hartley Act has many serious and far-reaching defects. Experience has demonstrated this so clearly that even the sponsors of the act now admit that it needs to be changed. A fair law
column2: fair to both management and labor
column3: is indispensable to sound labor relations and to full
column4: uninterrupted production. I intend to keep on working for a fair law until we get one.

column1: As we build our strength to defend the freedom in the world
column2: we ourselves must extend the benefits of freedom more widely among all our own people. We need to take action toward the wider enjoyment of civil rights. Freedom is the birthright of every American.

column1: The executive branch has been making real progress toward full equality of treatment and opportunity--in the Armed Forces
column2: in the civil service
column3: and in private firms working for the Government. Further advances require action by Congress
column4: and I hope that means will be provided to give the Members of the Senate and the House a chance to vote on them.

column1: I am glad to hear that home rule for the District of Columbia will be the first item of business before the Senate. I hope that it
column2: as well as statehood for Hawaii and Alaska
column3: will be adopted promptly.

column1: All these measures I have been talking about--measures to advance the well-being of our people--demonstrate to the world the forward movement of our free society.

This demonstration of the way free men govern themselves has a more powerful influence on the people of the world--on both sides of the Iron Curtain--than all the trick slogans and pie-in-the-sky promises of the Communists.
But our shortcomings
column2: as well as our progress
column3: are watched from abroad. And there is one shortcoming I want to speak about plainly.

column1: Our kind of government above all others cannot tolerate dishonesty among public servants.
Some dishonest people worm themselves into almost every human organization. It is all the more shocking
column2: however
column3: when they make their way into a Government such as ours
column4: which is based on the principle of justice for all. Such unworthy public servants must be weeded out. I intend to see to it that Federal employees who have been guilty of misconduct are punished for it. I also intend to see to it that the honest and hard-working great majority of our Federal employees are protected against partisan slander and malicious attack.

column1: I have already made some recommendations to the Congress to help accomplish these purposes. I intend to submit further recommendations to this end. I will welcome the wholehearted cooperation of the Congress in this effort.
I also think that the Congress can do a great deal to strengthen confidence in our institutions by applying rigorous standards of moral integrity to its own operations
column2: and by finding an effective way to control campaign expenditures
column3: and by protecting the rights of individuals in congressional investigations.

column1: To meet the crisis which now hangs over the world
