column6: I also recommend that the Congress create a permanent commission to establish fair and reasonable postal rates from time to time in the future.

column1: III. HUMAN PROBLEMS
Along with the protection of freedom and maintenance of a strong and growing economy
column2: this Administration recognizes a third great purpose of government: concern for the human problems of our citizens. In a modern industrial society
column3: banishment of destitution and cushioning the shock of personal disaster on the individual are proper concerns of all levels of government
column4: including the federal government. This is especially true where remedy and prevention alike are beyond the individual's capacity.

column1: LABOR AND WELFARE
Of the many problems in this area
column2: those I shall first discuss are of particular concern to the members of our great labor force
column3: who with their heads
column4: hearts and hands produce so much of the wealth of our country.

column1: Protection against the hazards of temporary unemployment should be extended to some 6?millions of workers
column2: including civilian Federal workers
column3: who now lack this safeguard. Moreover
column4: the Secretary of Labor is making available to the states studies and recommendations in the fields of weekly benefits
column5: periods of protection and extension of coverage. The Economic Report will consider the related matter of minimum wages and their coverage.

column1: The Labor Management Relations Act of 3947 is basically a sound law. However
column2: six years of experience have revealed that in some respects it can be improved. On January 11
column3: I shall forward to the Congress suggestions for changes designed to reinforce the basic objectives of the Act.

column1: Our basic social security program
column2: the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance system
column3: to which individuals contribute during their productive years and receive benefits based on previous earnings
column4: is designed to shield them from destitution. Last year I recommended extension of the social insurance system to include more than 10
column6: 000 additional persons. I ask that this extension soon be accomplished. This and other major improvements in the insurance system will bring substantial benefit increases and broaden the membership of the insurance system
column7: thus diminishing the need for Federal grants-in-aid for such purposes. A new formula will therefore be proposed
column8: permitting progressive reduction in such grants as the need for them declines.

column1: Federal grant-in-aid welfare programs
column2: now based on widely varying formulas
column3: should be simplified. Concrete proposals on fourteen of them will be suggested to the appropriate Committees.

column2: this program presently returns each year some 60
column3: 000 handicapped individuals to productive work. Far more disabled people can be saved each year from idleness and dependence if this program is gradually increased. My more detailed recommendations on this and the other social insurance problems I have mentioned will be sent to the Congress on January 14th.

column1: HEALTH

I am flatly opposed to the socialization of medicine. The great need for hospital and medical services can best be met by the initiative of private plans. But it is unfortunately a fact that medical costs are rising and already impose severe hardships on many families. The Federal Government can do many helpful things and still carefully avoid the socialization of medicine.
The Federal Government should encourage medical research in its battle with such mortal diseases as cancer and heart ailments
column2: and should continue to help the states in their health and rehabilitation programs. The present Hospital Survey and Construction Act should be broadened in order to assist in the development of adequate facilities for the chronically ill
column3: and to encourage the construction of diagnostic centers
column4: rehabilitation facilities
column5: and nursing homes. The war on disease also needs a better working relationship between Government and private initiative. Private and non-profit hospital and medical insurance plans are already in the field
column6: soundly based on the experience and initiative of the people in their various communities.

column1: A limited Government reinsurance service would permit the private and non-profit insurance companies to offer broader protection to more of the many families which want and should have it. On January 18 I shall forward to the Congress a special message presenting this Administration's health program in its detail.
EDUCATION

Youth--our greatest resource--is being seriously neglected in a vital respect. The nation as a whole is not preparing teachers or building schools fast enough to keep up with the increase in our population.
The preparation of teachers as
column2: indeed
column3: the control and direction of public education policy
column4: is a state and local responsibility. However
column5: the Federal Government should stand ready to assist states which demonstrably cannot provide sufficient school buildings. In order to appraise the needs
column6: I hope that this year a conference on education will be held in each state
column7: culminating in a national conference. From these conferences on education
column8: every level of government--from the Federal Government to each local school board--should gain the information with which to attack this serious problem.

column1: HOUSING
The details of a program to enlarge and improve the opportunities for our people to acquire good homes will be presented to the Congress by special message on January.
This program will include:
Modernization of the home mortgage insurance program of the Federal Government;
Redirection of the present system of loans and grants-in-aid to cities for slum clearance and redevelopment;
Extension of the advantages of insured lending to private credit engaged in this task of rehabilitating obsolete neighborhoods;
Insurance of long-term
column2: mortgage loans
column3: with small down payment for low-income families; and
column4: until alternative programs prove more effective

column1: Continuation of the public housing program adopted in the Housing Act of 1949.
If the individual
column2: the community
column3: the State and federal governments will alike apply themselves
column4: every American family can have a decent home.

column1: VETERANS ADMINISTRATION
The internal reorganization of the Veterans Administration is proceeding with my full approval. When completed
column2: it will afford a single agency whose services
column3: including medical facilities
column4: will be better adapted to the needs of those 20
column6: 000 veterans to whom this Nation owes so much.

column1: SUFFRAGE
My few remaining recommendations all relate to a basic right of our citizens--that of being represented in the decisions of the government.
I hope that the States will cooperate with the Congress in adopting uniform standards in their voting laws that will make it possible for our citizens in the armed forces overseas to vote.

In the District of Columbia the time is long overdue for granting national suffrage to its citizens and also applying the principle of local self-government to the Nation's Capital. I urge the Congress to move promptly in this direction and also to revise District revenue measures to provide needed public works improvements.

The people of Hawaii are ready for statehood. I renew my request for this legislation in order that Hawaii may elect its State officials and its representatives in Washington along with the rest of the country this fall.
For years our citizens between the ages of 18 and 21 have
column2: in time of peril
column3: been summoned to fight for America. They should participate in the political process that produces this fateful summons. I urge Congress to propose to the States a constitutional amendment permitting citizens to vote when they reach the age of 18.

column1: CONCLUSION
I want to add one final word about the general purport of these many recommendations.
Our government's powers are wisely limited by the Constitution; but quite apart from those limitations
column2: there are things which no government can do or should try to do.

column1: A government can strive
column2: as ours is striving
column3: to maintain an economic system whose doors are open to enterprise and ambition--those personal qualities on which economic growth largely depends. But enterprise and ambition are qualities which no government can supply. Fortunately no American government need concern itself on this score; our people have these qualities in good measure.

column1: A government can sincerely strive for peace
column2: as ours is striving
column3: and ask its people to make sacrifices for the sake of peace. But no government can place peace in the hearts of foreign rulers. It is our duty then to ourselves and to freedom itself to remain strong in all those ways--spiritual
column4: economic
column5: military--that will give us maximum safety against the possibility of aggressive action by others.

column1: No government can inoculate its people against the fatal materialism that plagues our age. Happily
column2: our people
column3: though blessed with more material goods than any people in history
column4: have always reserved their first allegiance to the kingdom of the spirit
column5: which is the true source of that freedom we value above all material things.

column1: But a government can try
column2: as ours tries
column3: to sense the deepest aspirations of the people
column4: and to express them in political action at home and abroad. So long as action and aspiration humbly and earnestly seek favor in the sight of the Almighty
column5: there is no end to America's forward road; there is no obstacle on it she will not surmount in her march toward a lasting peace in a free and prosperous world.@

column1: Dwight D. Eisenhower|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1955-01-06|@Mr. President
column2: Mr. Speaker
column3: Members of the Congress:

column1: First
column2: I extend cordial greetings to the 84th Congress. We shall have much to do together; I am sure that we shall get it done and
column3: that we shall do it in harmony and good will. At the outset
column4: I believe it would be well to remind ourselves of this great fundamental in our national life: our common belief that every human being is divinely endowed with dignity and worth and inalienable rights. This faith
column5: with its corollary that to grow and flourish people must be free shapes the interests and aspirations of every American. From this deep faith have evolved three main purposes of our Federal Government:

column1: First
column2: to maintain justice and freedom among ourselves and to champion them for others so that we may work effectively for enduring peace; Second
column3: to help keep our economy vigorous and expanding
column4: thus sustaining our international strength and assuring better jobs
column5: better living
column6: better opportunities for every citizen; And third
column7: to concern ourselves with the human problems of our people so that every American may have the opportunity to lead a healthy
column8: productive and rewarding life. Foremost among these broad purposes of government is our support of freedom
column9: justice and peace.

column1: It is of the utmost importance
column2: that each of us understands the true nature of the struggle now taking place in the world. It is not a struggle merely of economic theories
column3: or of forms of government
column4: or of military power. At issue is the true nature of man. Either man is the creature whom the Psalmist described as "a little lower than the angels
column5: crowned with glory and honor, holding dominion over the works" of his Creator; or man is a soulless
column6: animated machine to be enslaved
column7: used and consumed by the state for its own glorification.

column1: It is
column2: therefore
column3: a struggle which goes to the roots of the human spirit
column4: and its shadow falls across the long sweep of man's destiny. This prize
column5: so precious
column6: so fraught with ultimate meaning
column7: is the true object of the contending forces in the world. In the past year
column8: there has been progress justifying hope
column9: both for continuing peace and for the ultimate rule of freedom and justice in the world. Free nations are collectively stronger than at any time in recent years. Just as nations of this Hemisphere
column10: in the historic Caracas and Rio conferences
column11: have closed ranks against imperialistic Communism and strengthened their economic ties
column12: so free nations elsewhere have forged new bonds of unity.

column1: Recent agreements between Turkey and Pakistan have laid a foundation for increased strength in the Middle East. With our understanding support
column2: Egypt and Britain
column3: Yugoslavia and Italy
column4: Britain and Iran have resolved dangerous differences. The security of the Mediterranean has been enhanced by an alliance among Greece
column5: Turkey and Yugoslavia. Agreements in Western Europe have paved the way for unity to replace past divisions which have undermined Europe's economic and military vitality. The defense of the West appears likely at last to include a free
column6: democratic Germany participating as an equal in the councils of NATO.

column1: In Asia and the Pacific
column2: the pending Manila Pact supplements our treaties with Australia
column3: New Zealand
column4: the Philippines
column5: Korea and Japan and our prospective treaty with the Republic of China. These pacts stand as solemn warning that future military aggression and subversion against the free nations of Asia will meet united response. The Pacific Charter
column6: also adopted at Manila
column7: is a milestone in the development of human freedom and self-government in the Pacific area. Under the auspices of the United Nations
column8: there is promise of progress in our country's plan for the peaceful use of atomic energy.

column1: Finally
column2: today the world is at peace. It is
column3: to be sure
column4: a secure peace. Yet all humanity finds hope in the simple fact that for an appreciable time there has been no active major battlefield on earth. This same fact inspires us to work all the more effectively with other nations for the well being
column5: the freedom
column6: the dignity
column7: of every human on earth. These developments are heartening indeed
column8: and we are hopeful of continuing progress. But sobering problems remain.

column1: The massive military machines and ambitions of the Soviet-Communist bloc still create uneasiness in the world. All of us are aware of the continuing reliance of the Soviet Communists on military force
column2: of the power of their weapons
column3: of their present resistance to realistic armament limitation
column4: and of their continuing effort to dominate or intimidate free nations on their periphery. Their steadily growing power includes an increasing strength in nuclear weapons. This power
column5: combined with the proclaimed intentions of the Communist leaders to communize the world
column6: is the threat confronting us today.

column1: To protect our nations and our peoples from the catastrophe of a nuclear holocaust
column2: free nations must maintain countervailing military power to persuade the Communists of the futility of seeking their ends through aggression. If Communist rulers understand that America's response to aggression will be swift and decisive--that never shall we buy peace at the expense of honor or faith--they will be powerfully deterred from launching a military venture engulfing their own peoples and many others in disaster. This
column3: of course
column4: is merely world stalemate. But in this stalemate each of us may and must exercise his high duty to strive in every honorable way for enduring peace.

column1: The military threat is but one menace to our freedom and security. We must not only deter aggression; we must also frustrate the effort of Communists to gain their goals by subversion. To this end
column2: free nations must maintain and reinforce their cohesion
column3: their internal security
column4: their political and economic vitality
column5: and their faith in freedom. In such a world
column6: America's course is dear: We must tirelessly labor to make the peace more just and durable. We must strengthen the collective defense under the United Nations Charter and gird ourselves with sufficient military strength and productive capacity to discourage resort to war and protect our nation's vital interests.

column1: We must continue to support and strengthen the United Nations. At this very moment
column2: by vote of the United Nations General Assembly
column3: its Secretary-General is in Communist China on a mission of deepest concern to all Americans: seeking the release of our never-to-be-forgotten American aviators and all other United Nations prisoners wrongfully detained by the Communist regime. We must also encourage the efforts being made in the United Nations to limit armaments and to harness the atom to peaceful rise. We must expand international trade and investment and assist friendly nations whose own best efforts are still insufficient to provide the strength essential to the security of the free world.We must be willing to use the processes of negotiation whenever they will advance the cause of just and secure peace to which the United States and other free nations are dedicated.

column1: In respect to all these matters
column2: we must
column3: through a vigorous information program
column4: keep the peoples of the world truthfully advised of our actions and purposes. This problem has been attacked with new vigor during the past months. I urge that the Congress give its earnest consideration to the great advantages that can accrue to our country through the successful operations of this program.

column1: We must also carry forward our educational exchange program. This sharing of knowledge and experience between our citizens and those of free countries is a powerful factor in the development and maintenance of true partnership among free peoples. To advance these many efforts
column2: the Congress must act in this session on appropriations
column3: legislation
column4: and treaties. Today I shall mention especially our foreign economic and military programs.

column1: The recent economic progress in many free nations has been most heartening. The productivity of labor and the production of goods and services are increasing in ever-widening areas. There is a growing will to improve the living standards of all men. This progress is important to all our people. It promises us allies who are strong and self-reliant; it promises a growing world market for the products of our mines
column2: our factories
column3: and our farms.

column1: But only through steady effort can we hope to continue this progress. Barriers still impede trade and the flow of capital needed to develop each nation's human and material resources. Wise reduction of these barriers is a long-term objective of our foreign economic policy--a policy of an evolutionary and selective nature
column2: assuring broad benefits to our own and other peoples.

column1: We must gradually reduce certain tariff obstacles to trade. These actions should
column2: of course
column3: be accompanied by a similar lowering of trade barriers by other nations
column4: so that we may move steadily toward greater economic advantage for all. We must further simplify customs administration and procedures. We must facilitate the flow of capital and continue technical assistance
column5: both directly and through the United Nations
column6: to less developed countries to strengthen their independence and raise their living standards. Many another step must be taken in and among the nations of the free world to release forces of private initiative. In our own nation
column7: these forces have brought strength and prosperity; once released
column8: they will generate rising incomes in these other countries with which to buy the products of American industry
column9: labor and agriculture.

column1: On January 10
column2: by special message
column3: I shall submit specific recommendations for carrying forward the legislative phases of our foreign economic policy. Our many efforts to build a better world include the maintenance of our military strength. This is a vast undertaking. Major national security programs consume two-thirds of the entire Federal budget. Over four million Americans--servicemen and civilians--are on the rolls of the defense establishment. During the past two years
column4: by eliminating duplication and over staffing
column5: by improved procurement and inventory controls
column6: and by concentrating on the essentials
column7: many billions of dollars have been saved in our defense activities. I should like to mention certain fundamentals underlying this vast program.

column1: First
column2: a realistic limitation of armaments and an enduring
column3: just peace remain our national goals; we maintain powerful military forces because there is no present alternative--forces designed for deterrent and defensive purposes alone but able instantly to strike back with destructive power in response to an attack.

column1: Second
column2: we must stay alert to the fact that undue reliance on one weapon or preparation for only one kind of warfare simply invites an enemy to resort to another. We must
column3: therefore
column4: keep in our armed forces balance and flexibility adequate for our purposes and objectives.

column1: Third
column2: to keep our armed forces abreast of the advances of science
column3: our military planning must be flexible enough to utilize the new weapons and techniques which flow ever more speedily from our research and development programs. The forthcoming military budget therefore emphasizes modern air power in the Air Force
column4: Navy and Marine Corps and increases the emphasis on new weapons
column5: especially those of rapid and destructive striking power. It assures the maintenance of effective
column6: retaliatory force as the principal deterrent to overt aggression. It accelerates the continental defense program and the build-up of ready military reserve forces. It continues a vigorous program of stockpiling strategic and critical materials and strengthening our mobilization base. The budget also contemplates the strategic concentration of our strength through redeployment of certain forces. It provides for reduction of forces in certain categories and their expansion in others
column7: to fit them to the military realities of our time. These emphases in our defense planning have been made at my personal direction after long and thoughtful study. In my judgment
column8: they will give our nation a defense accurately adjusted to the national need.

column1: Fourth
column2: pending a world agreement on armament limitation
column3: we must continue to improve and expand our supplies of nuclear weapons for our land
column4: naval and air forces
column5: while
column6: at the same time
column7: continuing our encouraging progress in the peaceful use of atomic power.

column1: And fifth
column2: in the administration of these costly programs
column3: we must demand the utmost in efficiency and ingenuity. We must assure our people not only of adequate protection but also of a defense that can be carried forward from year to year until the threat of aggression has disappeared.

column1: To help maintain this kind of armed strength and improve its efficiency
column2: I must urge the enactment of several important measures in this session. The first concerns the selective service act which expires next June 30th. For the foreseeable future
column3: our standing forces must remain much larger than voluntary methods can sustain. We must
column4: therefore
column5: extend the statutory authority to induct men for two years of military service.

column1: The second kind of measure concerns the rapid turnover of our most experienced servicemen. This process seriously weakens the combat readiness of our armed forces and is exorbitantly expensive. To encourage more trained servicemen to remain in uniform
column2: I shall
column3: on the thirteenth of this month
column4: propose a number of measures to increase the attractions of a military career. These measures will include more adequate medical care for dependents
column5: survivors' benefits
column6: more and better housing
column7: and selective adjustments in military pay and other allowances.

column1: And third--also on January 13--I shall present a program to rebuild and strengthen the civilian components of our armed forces. This is a comprehensive program
column2: designed to make better use of our manpower of military age. Because it will go far in assuring fair and equitable participation in military training and service
column3: it is of particular importance to our combat veterans. In keeping with the historic military policy of our Republic
column4: this program is designed to build and maintain powerful civilian reserves immediately capable of effective military service in an emergency in lieu of maintaining active duty forces in excess of the nation's immediate need.

column1: Maintenance of an effective defense requires continuance of our aggressive attack on subversion at home. In this effort we have
column2: in the past two years
column3: made excellent progress. FBI investigations have been powerfully reinforced by a new Internal Security Division in the Department of Justice; the security activities of the Immigration and Naturalization Service have been revitalized; an improved and strengthened security system is in effect throughout the government; the Department of Justice and the FBI have been armed with effective new legal weapons forged by the 83rd Congress.

column1: We shall continue to ferret out and to destroy Communist subversion. We shall
column2: in the process
column3: carefully preserve our traditions and the basic rights of our citizens. Our civil defense program is also a key element in the protection of our country. We are developing cooperative methods with State Governors
column4: Mayors
column5: and voluntary citizen groups
column6: as well as among Federal agencies
column7: in building the civil defense organization. Its significance in time of war is obvious; its swift assistance in disaster areas last year proved its importance in time of peace.

column1: An industry capable of rapid expansion and essential materials and facilities swiftly available in time of emergency are indispensable to our defense. I urge
column2: therefore
column3: a two-year extension of the Defense Production Act and Title II of the First War Powers Act of 1941. These are cornerstones of our program for the development and maintenance of an adequate mobilization base. At this point
column4: I should like to make this additional observation. Our quest for peace and freedom necessarily presumes that we who hold positions of public trust must rise above self and section--that we must subordinate to the general good our partisan
column5: our personal pride and prejudice. Tirelessly
column6: with united purpose
column7: we must fortify the material and spiritual foundations of this land of freedom and of free nations throughout the world. As never before
column8: there is need for unhesitating cooperation among the branches of our government.

column1: At this time the executive and legislative branches are under the management of different political parties. This fact places both parties on trial before the American people. In less perilous days of the past
column2: division of governmental responsibility among our great parties has produced a paralyzing indecision. We must not let this happen in our time. We must avoid a paralysis of the will for peace and international security.

column1: In the traditionally bipartisan areas--military security and foreign relations--I can report to you that I have already
column2: with the leaders of this Congress
column3: expressed assurances of unreserved cooperation. Yet
column4: the strength of our country requires more than mere maintenance of military strength and success in foreign affairs; these vital matters are in turn dependent upon concerted and vigorous action in a number of supporting programs. I say
column5: therefore
column6: to the 84th Congress:

column1: In all areas basic to the strength of America
column2: there will be--to the extent I can insure them--cooperative
column3: constructive relations between the Executive and Legislative Branches of this government. Let the general good be our yardstick on every great issue of our time.

column1: Our efforts to defend our freedom and to secure a just peace are
column2: of course
column3: inseparable from the second great purpose of our government: to help maintain a strong
column4: growing economy--an economy vigorous and free
column5: in which there are ever-increasing opportunities
column6: just rewards for effort
column7: and a stable prosperity that is widely shared.

column1: In the past two years
column2: many important governmental Actions helped our economy adjust to conditions of peace; these and other actions created a climate for renewed economic growth. Controls were removed from wages
column3: prices and materials. Tax revisions encouraged increased private spending and employment. Federal expenditures were sharply reduced
column4: making possible a record tax cut. These actions
column5: together with flexible monetary and debt management policies
column6: helped to halt inflation and stabilize the value of the dollar. A program of cooperation and partnership in resource development was begun. Social security and unemployment insurance laws were broadened and strengthened. New laws started the long process of balancing farm production with farm markets. Expanded shipbuilding and stockpiling programs strengthened key sectors of the economy
column7: while improving our mobilization base. A comprehensive new housing law brought impressive progress in an area fundamental to our economic strength and closed loopholes in the old laws permitting dishonest manipulation. Many of these programs are just beginning to exert their main stimulating effect upon the economy generally and upon specific communities and industries throughout the country.

column1: The past year--1954--was one of the most prosperous years in our history. Business activity now surges with new strength. Production is rising. Employment is high. Toward the end of last year average weekly wages in manufacturing were higher than ever before. Personal income after taxes is at a record level. So is consumer spending. Construction activity is reaching new peaks. Export demand for our goods is strong. State and local government expenditures on public works are rising. Savings are high
column2: and credit is readily available.

column1: So
column2: today
column3: the transition to a peacetime economy is largely behind us. The economic outlook is good. The many promising factors I have mentioned do not guarantee sustained economic expansion; however
column4: they do give us a strong position from which to carry forward our economic growth. If we as a people act wisely
column5: within ten years our annual national output can rise from its present level of about $360 billion to $500 billion
column6: measured in dollars of stable buying power.

column1: My Budget Message on January 17
column2: the Economic Report on the 20th of this month
column3: and several special messages will set forth in detail major programs to foster the growth of our economy and to protect the integrity of the people's money. Today I shall discuss these programs only in general terms.

column1: Government efficiency and economy remain essential to steady progress toward a balanced budget. More than ten billion dollars were cut from the spending program proposed in the budget of January 9
column2: 1953. Expenditures of that year were six and a half billion below those of the previous year. In the current fiscal year
column3: government spending will be nearly four and a half billion dollars less than in the fiscal year which ended last June 30. New spending authority has been held below expenditures
column4: reducing government obligations accumulated over the years.

column1: Last year we had a large tax cut and
column2: for the first time in seventy-five years a basic revision of Federal tax laws. It is now clear that defense and other essential government costs must remain at a level precluding further tax reductions this year. Although excise and corporation income taxes must
column3: therefore
column4: be continued at their present rates
column5: further tax cuts will be possible when justified by lower expenditures and by revenue increases arising from the nation's economic growth. I am hopeful that such reductions can be made next year.

column1: At the foundation of our economic growth are the raw materials and energy produced from our minerals and fuels
column2: lands and forests
column3: and water resources. With respect to them
column4: I believe that the nation must adhere to three fundamental policies: first
column5: to develop
column6: wisely use and conserve basic resources from generation to generation; second
column7: to follow the historic pattern of developing these resources primarily by private citizens under fair provisions of law
column8: including restraints for proper conservation; and third
column9: to treat resource development as a partnership undertaking--a partnership in which the participation of private citizens and State and local governments is as necessary as Federal participation.

column1: This policy of partnership and cooperation is producing good results
column2: most immediately noticeable in respect to water resources. First
column3: it has encouraged local public bodies and private citizens to plan their own power sources. Increasing numbers of applications to the Federal Power Commission to conduct surveys and prepare plans for power development
column4: notably in the Columbia River Basin
column5: are evidence of local response.

column1: Second
column2: the Federal Government and local and private organizations have been encouraged to coordinate their developments. This is important because Federal hydroelectric developments supply but a small fraction of the nation's power needs. Such partnership projects as Priest Rapids in Washington
column3: the Coosa River development in Alabama
column4: and Markham Ferry in Oklahoma already have the approval of the Congress. This year justifiable projects of a similar nature will again have Administration support.

column1: Third
column2: the Federal Government must shoulder its own partnership obligations by undertaking projects of such complexity and size that their success requires Federal development. In keeping with this principle
column3: I again urge the Congress to approve the development of the Upper Colorado River Basin to conserve and assure better use of precious water essential to the future of the West.

column1: In addition
column2: the 1956 budget will recommend appropriations to start six new reclamation and more than thirty new Corps of Engineers projects of varying size. Going projects and investigations of potential new resource developments will be continued.

column1: Although this partnership approach is producing encouraging results
column2: its full success requires a nation-wide comprehensive water resources policy firmly based in law. Such a policy is under preparation and when completed will be submitted to the Congress.

column1: In the interest of their proper conservation
column2: development and use
column3: continued vigilance will be maintained over our fisheries
column4: wildlife resources
column5: the national parks and forests
column6: and the public lands; and we shall continue to encourage an orderly development of the nation's mineral resources.

column1: A modern
column2: efficient highway system is essential to meet the needs of our growing population
column3: our expanding economy
column4: and our national security. We are accelerating our highway improvement program as rapidly as possible under existing State and Federal laws and authorizations. However
column5: this effort will not in itself assure our people of an adequate highway system. On my recommendation
column6: this problem has been carefully considered by the Conference of State Governors and by a special Advisory Committee on a National Highway Program
column7: composed of leading private citizens. I have received the recommendations of the Governors' Conference and will shortly receive the views of the special Advisory Committee. Aided by their findings
column8: I shall submit on January 27th detailed recommendations which will meet our most pressing national highway needs.

column1: In further recognition of the importance of transportation to our economic strength and security
column2: the Administration
column3: through a Cabinet committee
column4: is thoroughly examining existing Federal transportation policies to determine their effect on the adequacy of transportation services. This is the first such comprehensive review directly undertaken by the Executive Branch of the government in modern times. We are not only examining major problems facing the various modes of transport; we are also studying closely the inter-relationships of civilian and government requirements for transportation. Legislation will be recommended to correct policy deficiencies which we may find.

column1: The nation's public works activities are tremendous in scope. It is expected that more than $ 12 billion will be expended in 1955 for the development of land
column2: water and other resources; control of floods
column3: and navigation and harbor improvements; construction of roads
column4: schools
column5: and municipal water supplies
column6: and disposal of domestic and industrial wastes. Many of the Federal
column7: State and local agencies responsible for this work are
column8: in their separate capacities
column9: highly efficient. But public works activities are closely inter-related and have a substantial influence on the growth of the country. Moreover
column10: in times of threatening economic contraction
column11: they may become a valuable sustaining force. To these ends
column12: efficient planning and execution of the nation's public works require both the coordination of Federal activities and effective cooperation with State and local governments.

column1: The Council of Economic Advisers
column2: through its public works planning section
column3: has made important advances during the past year in effecting this coordination and cooperation. In view of the success of these initial efforts
column4: and to give more emphasis and continuity to this essential coordination
column5: I shall request the Congress to appropriate funds for the support of an Office of Coordinator of Public Works in the Executive Office of the President.

column1: A most significant element in our growing economy is an agriculture that is stable
column2: prosperous and free. The problems of our agriculture have evolved over many years and cannot be solved overnight; nevertheless
column3: governmental actions last year hold great promise of fostering a better balance between production and markets and
column4: consequently
column5: a better and more stable income for our farmers.

column1: Through vigorous administration and through new authority provided by the 83rd Congress
column2: surplus farm products are now moving into consumption. From February 1953 through November 1954
column3: the rate of increase of government-held surpluses has been reduced by our moving into use more than 2.3 billion dollars' worth of government-owned farm commodities; this amount is equal to more than seven percent of a year's production of all our farms and ranches. Domestic consumption remains high
column4: and farm exports will be higher than last year. As a result of the flexibility provided by the Agricultural Act of 1954
column5: we can move toward less restrictive acreage controls.

column1: Thus
column2: farm production is gradually adjusting to markets
column3: markets are being expanded
column4: and stocks are moving into use. We can now look forward to an easing of the influences depressing farm prices
column5: to reduced government expenditures for purchase of surplus products
column6: and to less Federal intrusion into the lives and plans of our farm people. Agricultural programs have been redirected toward better balance
column7: greater stability and sustained prosperity. We are headed in the right direction. I urgently recommend to the Congress that we continue resolutely on this road.

column1: Greater attention must be directed to the needs of low-income farm families. Twenty-eight per cent of our farm-operator families have net cash incomes of less than $1
column2: 000 per year. Last year
column3: at my request
column4: careful studies were made of the problems of these farm people. I shall later submit recommendations designed to assure the steady alleviation of their most pressing concerns.

column1: Because drought also remains a serious agricultural problem
column2: I shall recommend legislation to strengthen Federal disaster assistance programs. This legislation will prescribe an improved appraisal of need
column3: better adjustment of the various programs to local conditions
column4: and a more equitable sharing of costs between the States and the Federal Government.

column1: The prosperity of our small business enterprises is an indispensable element in the maintenance of our economic strength. Creation of the Small Business Administration and recently enacted tax laws facilitating small business expansion are but two of many important steps we have taken to encourage our smaller enterprises. I recommend that the Congress extend the Small Business Act of 1953 which is due to expire next June. We come now to the third great purpose of our government-its concern for the health
column2: productivity and well-being of all our people.

column1: Every citizen wants to give full expression to his God-given talents and abilities and to have the recognition and respect accorded under our religious and political traditions. Americans also want a good material standard of living--not simply to accumulate possessions
column2: but to fulfill a legitimate aspiration for an environment in which their families may live meaningful and happy lives. Our people are committed
column3: therefore
column4: to the creation and preservation of opportunity for every citizen to lead a more rewarding life. They are equally committed to the alleviation of misfortune and distress among their fellow citizens.

column1: The aspirations of most of our people can best be fulfilled through their own enterprise and initiative
column2: without government interference. This Administration
column3: therefore
column4: follows two simple rules: first
column5: the Federal Government should perform an essential task only when it cannot otherwise be adequately performed; and second
column6: in performing that task
column7: our government must not impair the self-respect
column8: freedom and incentive of the individual. So long as these two rules are observed
column9: the government can fully meet its obligation without creating a dependent population or a domineering bureaucracy.

column1: During the past two years
column2: notable advances were made in these functions of government. Protection of old-age and survivors' insurance was extended to an additional ten million of our people
column3: and the benefits were substantially increased. Legislation was enacted to provide unemployment insurance protection to some four million additional Americans. Stabilization of living costs and the halting of inflation protected the value of pensions and savings. A broad program now helps to bring good homes within the reach of the great majority of our people. With the States
column4: we are providing rehabilitation facilities and more clinics
column5: hospitals
column6: and nursing homes for patients with chronic illnesses. Also with the States
column7: we have begun a great and fruitful expansion in the restoration of disabled persons to employment and useful lives. In the areas of Federal responsibility
column8: we have made historic progress in eliminating from among our people demeaning practices based on race or color. All of us may be proud of these achievements during the past two years. Yet essential Federal tasks remain to be done.

column1: As part of our efforts to provide decent
column2: safe and sanitary housing for low-income families
column3: we must carry forward the housing program authorized during the 83rd Congress. We must also authorize contracts for a firm program of 35
column4: 000 additional public housing units in each of the next two fiscal years. This program will meet the most pressing obligations of the Federal Government into the 1958 fiscal year for planning and building public housing. By that time the private building industry
column5: aided by the Housing Act of 1954
column6: will have had the opportunity to assume its full role in providing adequate housing for our low income families.

column1: The health of our people is one of our most precious assets. Preventable sickness should be prevented; knowledge available to combat disease and disability should be fully used. Otherwise
column2: we as a people are guilty not only of neglect of human suffering but also of wasting our national strength.

column1: Constant advances in medical care are not available to enough of our citizens. Clearly our nation must do more to reduce the impact of accident and disease. Two fundamental problems confront us: first
column2: high and ever-rising costs of health services; second
column3: serious gaps and shortages in these services.

column1: By special message on January 24
column2: I shall propose a coordinated program to strengthen and improve existing health services. This program will continue to reject socialized medicine. It will emphasize individual and local responsibility. Under it the Federal Government will neither dominate nor direct
column3: but serve as a helpful partner. Within this framework
column4: the program can be broad in scope.

column1: My recommendations will include a Federal health reinsurance service to encourage the development of more and better voluntary health insurance coverage by private organizations. I shall also recommend measures to improve the medical care of that group of our citizens who
column2: because of need
column3: receive Federal-State public assistance. These two proposals will help more of our people to meet the costs of health services.

column1: To reduce the gaps in these services
column2: I shall propose: New measures to facilitate construction of needed health facilities and help reduce shortages of trained health personnel; Vigorous steps to combat the misery and national loss involved in mental illness; Improved services for crippled children and for maternal and child health; Better consumer protection under our existing pure food and drug laws; and
column3: finally
column4: Strengthened programs to combat the increasingly serious pollution of our rivers and streams and the growing problem of air pollution. These measures together constitute a comprehensive program holding rich promise for better health for all of our people. Last year's expansion of social security coverage and our new program of improved medical care for public assistance recipients together suggest modification of the formula for Federal sharing in old age assistance payments. I recommend modification of the formula where such payments will
column5: in the future
column6: supplement benefits received under the old age and survivors insurance system.

column1: It is the inalienable right of every person
column2: from childhood on
column3: to have access to knowledge. In our form of society
column4: this right of the individual takes on a special meaning
column5: for the education of all our citizens is imperative to the maintenance and invigoration of America's free institutions. Today
column6: we face grave educational problems. Effective and up-to-date analyses of these problems and their solutions are being carried forward through the individual State conferences and the White House Conference to be completed this year.

column1: However
column2: such factors as population growth
column3: additional responsibilities of schools
column4: and increased and longer school attendance have produced an unprecedented classroom shortage. This shortage is of immediate concern to all of our people. Positive
column5: affirmative action must be taken now. Without impairing in any way the responsibilities of our States
column6: localities
column7: communities
column8: or families
column9: the Federal government can and should serve as an effective-catalyst in dealing with this problem. I shall forward a special message to the Congress on February 15
column10: presenting an affirmative program dealing with this shortage.

column1: To help the States do a better and more timely job
column2: we must strengthen their resources for preventing and dealing with juvenile delinquency. I shall propose Federal legislation to assist the States to promote concerted action in dealing with this nationwide problem. I shall carry forward the vigorous efforts of the Administration to improve the international control of the traffic in narcotics and
column3: in cooperation with State and local agencies
column4: to combat narcotic addiction in our country.

column1: I should like to speak now of additional matters of importance to all our people and especially to our wage earners. During the past year certain industrial changes and the readjustment of the economy to conditions of peace brought unemployment and other difficulties to various localities and industries. These problems are engaging our most earnest attention. But for the overwhelming majority of our working people
column2: the past year has meant good jobs. Moreover
column3: the earnings and savings of our wage earners are no longer depreciating in value. Because of cooperative relations between labor and management
column4: fewer working days were lost through strikes in 1954 than in any year in the past decade.

column1: The outlook for our wage earners can be made still more promising by several legislative actions. First
column2: in the past five years we have had economic growth which will support an increase in the Federal minimum wage. In the light of present economic conditions
column3: I recommend its increase to ninety cents an hour. I also recommend that many others
column4: at present excluded
column5: be given the protection of a minimum wage.

column1: Second
column2: I renew my recommendation of last year for amendment of the Labor Management Relations Act of 1947 to further the basic objectives of this statute.
