column7: the areas of agreement can be very wide indeed: a clear understanding about Berlin
column8: stability in Southeast Asia
column9: an end to nuclear testing
column10: new checks on surprise or accidental attack
column12: ultimately

column1: For we seek not the worldwide victory of one nation or system but a worldwide victory of man. The modern globe is too small
column2: its weapons are too destructive
column3: and its disorders are too contagious to permit any other kind of victory.

column1: To achieve this end
column2: the United States will continue to spend a greater portion of its national production than any other people in the free world. For 15 years no other free nation has demanded so much of itself. Through hot wars and cold
column3: through recession and prosperity
column4: through the ages of the atom and outer space
column5: the American people have never faltered and their faith has never flagged. If at times our actions seem to make life difficult for others
column6: it is only because history has made life difficult for us all.

column1: But difficult days need not be dark. I think these are proud and memorable days in the cause of peace and freedom. We are proud
column2: for example
column3: of Major Rudolf Anderson who gave his life over the island of Cuba. We salute Specialist James Allen Johnson who died on the border of South Korea. We pay honor to Sergeant Gerald Pendell who was killed in Viet Nam. They are among the many who in this century
column4: far from home
column5: have died for our country. Our task now
column6: and the task of all Americans is to live up to their commitment.

column1: My friends: I close on a note of hope. We are not lulled by the momentary calm of the sea or the somewhat clearer skies above. We know the turbulence that lies below
column2: and the storms that are beyond the horizon this year. But now the winds of change appear to be blowing more strongly than ever
column3: in the world of communism as well as our own. For 175 years we have sailed with those winds at our back
column4: and with the tides of human freedom in our favor. We steer our ship with hope
column5: as Thomas Jefferson said
column6: "leaving Fear astern."

column1: Today we still welcome those winds of change - and we have every reason to believe that our tide is running strong. With thanks to Almighty God for seeing us through a perilous passage
column2: we ask His help anew in guiding the "Good Ship Union."@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1963-11-27|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the House
column4: Members of the Senate
column5: my fellow Americans:

column1: All I have I would have given gladly not to be standing here today.

The greatest leader of our time has been struck down by the foulest deed of our time. Today John Fitzgerald Kennedy lives on in the immortal words and works that he left behind. He lives on in the mind and memories of mankind. He lives on in the hearts of his countrymen.
No words are sad enough to express our sense of loss. No words are strong enough to express our determination to continue the forward thrust of America that he began.

The dream of conquering the vastness of space--the dream of partnership across the Atlantic--and across the Pacific as well--the dream of a Peace Corps in less developed nations--the dream of education for all of our children--the dream of jobs for all who seek them and need them--the dream of care for our elderly--the dream of an all-out attack on mental illness--and above all
column2: the dream of equal rights for all Americans
column3: whatever their race or color--these and other American dreams have been vitalized by his drive and by his dedication.

column1: And now the ideas and the ideals which he so nobly represented must and will be translated into effective action.
Under John Kennedy's leadership
column2: this Nation has demonstrated that it has the courage to seek peace
column3: and it has the fortitude to risk war. We have proved that we are a good and reliable friend to those who seek peace and freedom. We have shown that we can also be a formidable foe to those who reject the path of peace and those who seek to impose upon us or our allies the yoke of tyranny.

column1: This Nation will keep its commitments from South Viet-Nam to West Berlin. We will be unceasing in the search for peace; resourceful in our pursuit of areas of agreement even with those with whom we differ; and generous and loyal to those who join with us in common cause.
In this age when there can be no losers in peace and no victors in war
column2: we must recognize the obligation to match national strength with national restraint. We must be prepared at one and the same time for both the confrontation of power and the limitation of power. We must be ready to defend the national interest and to negotiate the common interest. This is the path that we shall continue to pursue. Those who test our courage will find it strong
column3: and those who seek our friendship will find it honorable. We will demonstrate anew that the strong can be just in the use of strength; and the just can be strong in the defense of justice.

column1: And let all know we will extend no special privilege and impose no persecution. We will carry on the fight against poverty and misery
column2: and disease and ignorance
column3: in other lands and in our own.

column1: We will serve all the Nation
column2: not one section or one sector
column3: or one group
column4: but all Americans. These are the United States--a united people with a united purpose.

column1: Our American unity does not depend upon unanimity. We have differences; but now
column2: as in the past
column3: we can derive from those differences strength
column4: not weakness
column5: wisdom
column6: not despair. Both as a people and a government
column7: we can unite upon a program
column8: a program which is wise and just
column9: enlightened and constructive.

column1: For 32 years Capitol Hill has been my home. I have shared many moments of pride with you
column2: pride in the ability of the Congress of the United States to act
column3: to meet any crisis
column4: to distill from our differences strong programs of national action.

column1: An assassin's bullet has thrust upon me the awesome burden of the Presidency. I am here today to say I need your help; I cannot bear this burden alone. I need the help of all Americans
column2: and all America. This Nation has experienced a profound shock
column3: and in this critical moment
column4: it is our duty
column5: yours and mine
column6: as the Government of the United States
column7: to do away with uncertainty and doubt and delay
column8: and to show that we are capable of decisive action; that from the brutal loss of our leader we will derive not weakness
column9: but strength; that we can and will act and act now.

column1: From this chamber of representative government
column2: let all the world know and none misunderstand that I rededicate this Government to the unswerving support of the United Nations
column3: to the honorable and determined execution of our commitments to our allies
column4: to the maintenance of military strength second to none
column5: to the defense of the strength and the stability of the dollar
column6: to the expansion of our foreign trade
column7: to the reinforcement of our programs of mutual assistance and cooperation in Asia and Africa
column8: and to our Alliance for Progress in this hemisphere.

column1: On the 20th day of January
column3: John F. Kennedy told his countrymen that our national work would not be finished "in the first thousand days
column4: nor in the life of this administration
column5: nor even perhaps in our lifetime on this planet. But
column6: he said, let us begin."

column1: Today
column2: in this moment of new resolve
column3: I would say to all my fellow Americans
column4: let us continue.

column1: This is our challenge--not to hesitate
column2: not to pause
column3: not to turn about and linger over this evil moment
column4: but to continue on our course so that we may fulfill the destiny that history has set for us. Our most immediate tasks are here on this Hill.

column1: First
column2: no memorial oration or eulogy could more eloquently honor President Kennedy's memory than the earliest possible passage of the civil rights bill for which he fought so long. We have talked long enough in this country about equal rights. We have talked for one hundred years or more. It is time now to write the next chapter
column3: and to write it in the books of law.

column1: I urge you again
column2: as I did in 1957 and again in 1960
column3: to enact a civil rights law so that we can move forward to eliminate from this Nation every trace of discrimination and oppression that is based upon race or color. There could be no greater source of strength to this Nation both at home and abroad.

column1: And second
column2: no act of ours could more fittingly continue the work of President Kennedy than the early passage of the tax bill for which he fought all this long year. This is a bill designed to increase our national income and Federal revenues
column3: and to provide insurance against recession. That bill
column4: if passed without delay
column5: means more security for those now working
column6: more jobs for those now without them
column7: and more incentive for our economy.

column1: In short
column2: this is no time for delay. It is a time for action--strong
column3: forward-looking action on the pending education bills to help bring the light of learning to every home and hamlet in America--strong
column4: forward-looking action on youth employment opportunities; strong
column5: forward-looking action on the pending foreign aid bill
column6: making clear that we are not forfeiting our responsibilities to this hemisphere or to the world
column7: nor erasing Executive flexibility in the conduct of our foreign affairs--and strong
column8: prompt
column9: and forward-looking action on the remaining appropriation bills.

column1: In this new spirit of action
column2: the Congress can expect the full cooperation and support of the executive branch. And in particular
column3: I pledge that the expenditures of your Government will be administered with the utmost thrift and frugality. I will insist that the Government get a dollar's value for a dollar spent. The Government will set an example of prudence and economy. This does not mean that we will not meet our unfilled needs or that we will not honor our commitments. We will do both.

column1: As one who has long served in both Houses of the Congress
column2: I firmly believe in the independence and the integrity of the legislative branch. And I promise you that I shall always respect this. It is deep in the marrow of my bones. With equal firmness
column3: I believe in the capacity and I believe in the ability of the Congress
column4: despite the divisions of opinions which characterize our Nation
column5: to act--to act wisely
column6: to act vigorously
column7: to act speedily when the need arises.

column1: The need is here. The need is now. I ask your help.
We meet in grief
column2: but let us also meet in renewed dedication and renewed vigor. Let us meet in action
column3: in tolerance
column4: and in mutual understanding. John Kennedy's death commands what his life conveyed--that America must move forward. The time has come for Americans of all races and creeds and political beliefs to understand and to respect one another. So let us put an end to the teaching and the preaching of hate and evil and violence. Let us turn away from the fanatics of the far left and the far right
column5: from the apostles of bitterness and bigotry
column6: from those defiant of law
column7: and those who pour venom into our Nation's bloodstream.

column1: I profoundly hope that the tragedy and the torment of these terrible days will bind us together in new fellowship
column2: making us one people in our hour of sorrow. So let us here highly resolve that John Fitzgerald Kennedy did not live--or die--in vain. And on this Thanksgiving eve
column3: as we gather together to ask the Lord's blessing
column4: and give Him our thanks
column5: let us unite in those familiar and cherished words:

column1: America
column2: America

column1: God shed His grace on thee
And crown thy good With brotherhood
From sea to shining sea.@
Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1964-01-08|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the House and Senate
column4: my fellow Americans:

column1: I will be brief
column2: for our time is necessarily short and our agenda is already long.

column1: Last year's congressional session was the longest in peacetime history. With that foundation
column2: let us work together to make this year's session the best in the Nation's history.

column1: Let this session of Congress be known as the session which did more for civil rights than the last hundred sessions combined; as the session which enacted the most far-reaching tax cut of our time; as the session which declared all-out war on human poverty and unemployment in these United States; as the session which finally recognized the health needs of all our older citizens; as the session which reformed our tangled transportation and transit policies; as the session which achieved the most effective
column2: efficient foreign aid program ever; and as the session which helped to build more homes
column3: more schools
column4: more libraries
column5: and more hospitals than any single session of Congress in the history of our Republic.

column1: All this and more can and must be done. It can be done by this summer
column2: and it can be done without any increase in spending. In fact
column3: under the budget that I shall shortly submit
column4: it can be done with an actual reduction in Federal expenditures and Federal employment.

column1: We have in 1964 a unique opportunity and obligation--to prove the success of our system; to disprove those cynics and critics at home and abroad who question our purpose and our competence.
If we fail
column2: if we fritter and fumble away our opportunity in needless
column3: senseless quarrels between Democrats and Republicans
column4: or between the House and the Senate
column5: or between the South and North
column6: or between the Congress and the administration
column7: then history will rightfully judge us harshly. But if we succeed
column8: if we can achieve these goals by forging in this country a greater sense of union
column9: then
column10: and only then
column11: can we take full satisfaction in the State of the Union.

column1: II.
Here in the Congress you can demonstrate effective legislative leadership by discharging the public business with clarity and dispatch
column2: voting each important proposal up
column3: or voting it down
column4: but at least bringing it to a fair and a final vote.

column1: Let us carry forward the plans and programs of John Fitzgerald Kennedy--not because of our sorrow or sympathy
column2: but because they are right.

column1: In his memory today
column2: I especially ask all members of my own political faith
column3: in this election year
column4: to put your country ahead of your party
column5: and to always debate principles; never debate personalities.

column1: For my part
column2: I pledge a progressive administration which is efficient
column3: and honest and frugal. The budget to be submitted to the Congress shortly is in full accord with this pledge.

column1: It will cut our deficit in half--from $10 billion to $4
column2: 900 million. It will be
column3: in proportion to our national output
column4: the smallest budget since 1951.

column1: It will call for a substantial reduction in Federal employment
column2: a feat accomplished only once before in the last 10 years. While maintaining the full strength of our combat defenses
column3: it will call for the lowest number of civilian personnel in the Department of Defense since 1950.

column1: It will call for total expenditures of $97
column2: 900 million--compared to $98
column3: 400 million for the current year
column4: a reduction of more than $500 million. It will call for new obligational authority of $103
column5: 800 million--a reduction of more than $4 billion below last year's request of $107
column6: 900 million.

column1: But it is not a standstill budget
column2: for America cannot afford to stand still. Our population is growing. Our economy is more complex. Our people's needs are expanding.

column1: But by closing down obsolete installations
column2: by curtailing less urgent programs
column3: by cutting back where cutting back seems to be wise
column4: by insisting on a dollar's worth for a dollar spent
column5: I am able to recommend in this reduced budget the most Federal support in history for education
column6: for health
column7: for retraining the unemployed
column8: and for helping the economically and the physically handicapped.

column1: This budget
column2: and this year's legislative program
column3: are designed to help each and every American citizen fulfill his basic hopes--his hopes for a fair chance to make good; his hopes for fair play from the law; his hopes for a full-time job on full-time pay; his hopes for a decent home for his family in a decent community; his hopes for a good school for his children with good teachers; and his hopes for security when faced with sickness or unemployment or old age.

column1: III.
Unfortunately
column2: many Americans live on the outskirts of hope--some because of their poverty
column3: and some because of their color
column4: and all too many because of both. Our task is to help replace their despair with opportunity.

column1: This administration today
column2: here and now
column3: declares unconditional war on poverty in America. I urge this Congress and all Americans to join with me in that effort.

column1: It will not be a short or easy struggle
column2: no single weapon or strategy will suffice
column3: but we shall not rest until that war is won. The richest Nation on earth can afford to win it. We cannot afford to lose it. One thousand dollars invested in salvaging an unemployable youth today can return $40
column4: 000 or more in his lifetime.

column1: Poverty is a national problem
column2: requiring improved national organization and support. But this attack
column3: to be effective
column4: must also be organized at the State and the local level and must be supported and directed by State and local efforts.

column1: For the war against poverty will not be won here in Washington. It must be won in the field
column2: in every private home
column3: in every public office
column4: from the courthouse to the White House.

column1: The program I shall propose will emphasize this cooperative approach to help that one-fifth of all American families with incomes too small to even meet their basic needs.
Our chief weapons in a more pinpointed attack will be better schools
column2: and better health
column3: and better homes
column4: and better training
column5: and better job opportunities to help more Americans
column6: especially young Americans
column7: escape from squalor and misery and unemployment rolls where other citizens help to carry them.

column1: Very often a lack of jobs and money is not the cause of poverty
column2: but the symptom. The cause may lie deeper in our failure to give our fellow citizens a fair chance to develop their own capacities
column3: in a lack of education and training
column4: in a lack of medical care and housing
column5: in a lack of decent communities in which to live and bring up their children.

column1: But whatever the cause
column2: our joint Federal-local effort must pursue poverty
column3: pursue it wherever it exists--in city slums and small towns
column4: in sharecropper shacks or in migrant worker camps
column5: on Indian Reservations
column6: among whites as well as Negroes
column7: among the young as well as the aged
column8: in the boom towns and in the depressed areas.

column1: Our aim is not only to relieve the symptom of poverty
column2: but to cure it and
column3: above all
column4: to prevent it. No single piece of legislation
column5: however
column6: is going to suffice.

column1: We will launch a special effort in the chronically distressed areas of Appalachia.
We must expand our small but our successful area redevelopment program.
We must enact youth employment legislation to put jobless
column2: aimless
column3: hopeless youngsters to work on useful projects.

column1: We must distribute more food to the needy through a broader food stamp program.
We must create a National Service Corps to help the economically handicapped of our own country as the Peace Corps now helps those abroad.
We must modernize our unemployment insurance and establish a high-level commission on automation. If we have the brain power to invent these machines
column2: we have the brain power to make certain that they are a boon and not a bane to humanity.

column1: We must extend the coverage of our minimum wage laws to more than 2 million workers now lacking this basic protection of purchasing power.
We must
column2: by including special school aid funds as part of our education program
column3: improve the quality of teaching
column4: training
column5: and counseling in our hardest hit areas.

column1: We must build more libraries in every area and more hospitals and nursing homes under the Hill-Burton Act
column2: and train more nurses to staff them.

column1: We must provide hospital insurance for our older citizens financed by every worker and his employer under Social Security
column2: contributing no more than $1 a month during the employee's working career to protect him in his old age in a dignified manner without cost to the Treasury
column3: against the devastating hardship of prolonged or repeated illness.

column1: We must
column2: as a part of a revised housing and urban renewal program
column3: give more help to those displaced by slum clearance
column4: provide more housing for our poor and our elderly
column5: and seek as our ultimate goal in our free enterprise system a decent home for every American family.

column1: We must help obtain more modern mass transit within our communities as well as low-cost transportation between them.
Above all
column2: we must release $11 billion of tax reduction into the private spending stream to create new jobs and new markets in every area of this land.

column1: IV.

These programs are obviously not for the poor or the underprivileged alone. Every American will benefit by the extension of social security to cover the hospital costs of their aged parents. Every American community will benefit from the construction or modernization of schools
column2: libraries
column3: hospitals
column4: and nursing homes
column5: from the training of more nurses and from the improvement of urban renewal in public transit. And every individual American taxpayer and every corporate taxpayer will benefit from the earliest possible passage of the pending tax bill from both the new investment it will bring and the new jobs that it will create.

column1: That tax bill has been thoroughly discussed for a year. Now we need action. The new budget clearly allows it. Our taxpayers surely deserve it. Our economy strongly demands it. And every month of delay dilutes its benefits in 1964 for consumption
column2: for investment
column3: and for employment.

column1: For until the bill is signed
column2: its investment incentives cannot be deemed certain
column3: and the withholding rate cannot be reduced--and the most damaging and devastating thing you can do to any businessman in America is to keep him in doubt and to keep him guessing on what our tax policy is. And I say that we should now reduce to 14 percent instead of 15 percent our withholding rate.

column1: I therefore urge the Congress to take final action on this bill by the first of February
column2: if at all possible. For however proud we may be of the unprecedented progress of our free enterprise economy over the last 3 years
column3: we should not and we cannot permit it to pause.

column2: for the first time in history
column3: we crossed the 70 million job mark
column4: but we will soon need more than 75 million jobs. In 1963 our gross national product reached the $600 billion level--$100 billion higher than when we took office. But it easily could and it should be still $30 billion higher today than it is.

column1: Wages and profits and family income are also at their highest levels in history--but I would remind you that 4 million workers and 13 percent of our industrial capacity are still idle today.
We need a tax cut now to keep this country moving.
V.
For our goal is not merely to spread the work. Our goal is to create more jobs. I believe the enactment of a 35-hour week would sharply increase costs
column2: would invite inflation
column3: would impair our ability to compete
column4: and merely share instead of creating employment. But I am equally opposed to the 45- or 50-hour week in those industries where consistently excessive use of overtime causes increased unemployment.

column1: So
column2: therefore
column3: I recommend legislation authorizing the creation of a tripartite industry committee to determine on an industry-by-industry basis as to where a higher penalty rate for overtime would increase job openings without unduly increasing costs
column4: and authorizing the establishment of such higher rates.

column1: VI.
Let me make one principle of this administration abundantly clear: All of these increased opportunities--in employment
column2: in education
column3: in housing
column4: and in every field--must be open to Americans of every color. As far as the writ of Federal law will run
column5: we must abolish not some
column6: but all racial discrimination. For this is not merely an economic issue
column7: or a social
column8: political
column9: or international issue. It is a moral issue
column10: and it must be met by the passage this session of the bill now pending in the House.

column1: All members of the public should have equal access to facilities open to the public. All members of the public should be equally eligible for Federal benefits that are financed by the public. All members of the public should have an equal chance to vote for public officials and to send their children to good public schools and to contribute their talents to the public good.
Today
column2: Americans of all races stand side by side in Berlin and in Viet Nam. They died side by side in Korea. Surely they can work and eat and travel side by side in their own country.

column1: VII.
We must also lift by legislation the bars of discrimination against those who seek entry into our country
column2: particularly those who have much needed skills and those joining their families.

column1: In establishing preferences
column2: a nation that was built by the immigrants of all lands can ask those who now seek admission: "What can you do for our country?" But we should not be asking: "In what country were you born?"

column1: VIII.
For our ultimate goal is a world without war
column2: a world made safe for diversity
column3: in which all men
column4: goods
column5: and ideas can freely move across every border and every boundary.

column1: We must advance toward this goal in 1964 in at least 10 different ways
column2: not as partisans
column3: but as patriots.

column1: First
column2: wc must maintain--and our reduced defense budget will maintain--that margin of military safety and superiority obtained through 3 years of steadily increasing both the quality and the quantity of our strategic
column3: our conventional
column4: and our antiguerilla forces. In 1964 we will be better prepared than ever before to defend the cause of freedom
column5: whether it is threatened by outright aggression or by the infiltration practiced by those in Hanoi and Havana
column6: who ship arms and men across international borders to foment insurrection. And we must continue to use that strength as John Kennedy used it in the Cuban crisis and for the test ban treaty--to demonstrate both the futility of nuclear war and the possibilities of lasting peace.

column1: Second
column2: we must take new steps--and we shall make new proposals at Geneva--toward the control and the eventual abolition of arms. Even in the absence of agreement
column3: we must not stockpile arms beyond our needs or seek an excess of military power that could be provocative as well as wasteful.

column1: It is in this spirit that in this fiscal year we are cutting back our production of enriched uranium by 25 percent. We are shutting down four plutonium piles. We are closing many nonessential military installations. And it is in this spirit that we today call on our adversaries to do the same.
Third
column2: we must make increased use of our food as an instrument of peace--making it available by sale or trade or loan or donation-to hungry people in all nations which tell us of their needs and accept proper conditions of distribution.

column1: Fourth
column2: we must assure our pre-eminence in the peaceful exploration of outer space
column3: focusing on an expedition to the moon in this decade--in cooperation with other powers if possible
column4: alone if necessary.

column1: Fifth
column2: we must expand world trade. Having recognized in the Act of 1962 that we must buy as well as sell
column3: we now expect our trading partners to recognize that we must sell as well as buy. We are willing to give them competitive access to our market
column4: asking only that they do the same for us.

column1: Sixth
column2: we must continue
column3: through such measures as the interest equalization tax
column4: as well as the cooperation of other nations
column5: our recent progress toward balancing our international accounts.

column1: This administration must and will preserve the present gold value of the dollar.
Seventh
column2: we must become better neighbors with the free states of the Americas
column3: working with the councils of the OAS
column4: with a stronger Alliance for Progress
column5: and with all the men and women of this hemisphere who really believe in liberty and justice for all.

column1: Eighth
column2: we must strengthen the ability of free nations everywhere to develop their independence and raise their standard of living
column3: and thereby frustrate those who prey on poverty and chaos. To do this
column4: the rich must help the poor--and we must do our part. We must achieve a more rigorous administration of our development assistance
column5: with larger roles for private investors
column6: for other industrialized nations
column7: and for international agencies and for the recipient nations themselves.

column1: Ninth
column2: we must strengthen our Atlantic and Pacific partnerships
column3: maintain our alliances and make the United Nations a more effective instrument for national independence and international order.

column1: Tenth
column2: and finally
column3: we must develop with our allies new means of bridging the gap between the East and the West
column4: facing danger boldly wherever danger exists
column5: but being equally bold in our search for new agreements which can enlarge the hopes of all
column6: while violating the interests of none.

column1: In short
column2: I would say to the Congress that we must be constantly prepared for the worst
column3: and constantly acting for the best. We must be strong enough to win any war
column4: and we must be wise enough to prevent one.

column1: We shall neither act as aggressors nor tolerate acts of aggression. We intend to bury no one
column2: and we do not intend to be buried.

column1: We can fight
column2: if we must
column3: as we have fought before
column4: but we pray that we will never have to fight again.

column1: IX.
My good friends and my fellow Americans: In these last 7 sorrowful weeks
column2: we have learned anew that nothing is so enduring as faith
column3: and nothing is so degrading as hate.

column1: John Kennedy was a victim of hate
column2: but he was also a great builder of faith--faith in our fellow Americans
column3: whatever their creed or their color or their station in life; faith in the future of man
column4: whatever his divisions and differences.

column1: This faith was echoed in all parts of the world. On every continent and in every land to which Mrs. Johnson and I traveled
column2: we found faith and hope and love toward this land of America and toward our people.

column1: So I ask you now in the Congress and in the country to join with me in expressing and fulfilling that faith in working for a nation
column2: a nation that is free from want and a world that is free from hate--a world of peace and justice
column3: and freedom and abundance
column4: for our time and for all time to come.@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1965-01-04|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the Congress
column4: my fellow Americans:

column1: On this Hill which was my home
column2: I am stirred by old friendships.

column1: Though total agreement between the Executive and the Congress is impossible
column2: total respect is important.

column1: I am proud to be among my colleagues of the Congress whose legacy to their trust is their loyalty to their Nation.
I am not unaware of the inner emotions of the new Members of this body tonight.
Twenty-eight years ago
column2: I felt as you do now. You will soon learn that you are among men whose first love is their country
column3: men who try each day to do as best they can what they believe is right.

column1: We are entering the third century of the pursuit of American union.
Two hundred years ago
column3: nine assembled colonies first joined together to demand freedom from arbitrary power.

column1: For the first century we struggled to hold together the first continental union of democracy in the history of man. One hundred years ago
column3: following a terrible test of blood and fire
column4: the compact of union was finally sealed.

column1: For a second century we labored to establish a unity of purpose and interest among the many groups which make up the American community.
That struggle has often brought pain and violence. It is not yet over. But we have achieved a unity of interest among our people that is unmatched in the history of freedom.
And so tonight
column2: now
column4: we begin a new quest for union. We seek the unity of man with the world that he has built--with the knowledge that can save or destroy him--with the cities which can stimulate or stifle him--with the wealth and the machines which can enrich or menace his spirit.

column1: We seek to establish a harmony between man and society which will allow each of us to enlarge the meaning of his life and all of us to elevate the quality of our civilization.
This is the search that we begin tonight.
STATE OF THE WORLD
But the unity we seek cannot realize its full promise in isolation. For today the state of the Union depends
column2: in large measure
column3: upon the state of the world.

column1: Our concern and interest
column2: compassion and vigilance
column3: extend to every corner of a dwindling planet.

column1: Yet
column2: it is not merely our concern but the concern of all free men. We will not
column3: and we should not
column4: assume that it is the task of Americans alone to settle all the conflicts of a torn and troubled world.

column1: Let the foes of freedom take no comfort from this. For in concert with other nations
column2: we shall help men defend their freedom.

column1: Our first aim remains the safety and the well-being of our own country.
We are prepared to live as good neighbors with all
column2: but we cannot be indifferent to acts designed to injure our interests
column3: or our citizens
column4: or our establishments abroad. The community of nations requires mutual respect. We shall extend it--and we shall expect it.

column1: In our relations with the world we shall follow the example of Andrew Jackson who said: "I intend to ask for nothing that is not clearly right and to submit to nothing that is wrong." And he promised
column2: that "the honor of my country shall never be stained by an apology from me for the statement of truth or for the performance of duty." That was this Nation's policy in the 1830's and that is this Nation's policy in the 1960's.

column1: Our own freedom and growth have never been the final goal of the American dream.

We were never meant to be an oasis of liberty and abundance in a worldwide desert of disappointed dreams. Our Nation was created to help strike away the chains of ignorance and misery and tyranny wherever they keep man less than God means him to be.
We are moving toward that destiny
column2: never more rapidly than we have moved in the last 4 years.

column1: In this period we have built a military power strong enough to meet any threat and destroy any adversary. And that superiority will continue to grow so long as this office is mine--and you sit on Capitol Hill.
In this period no new nation has become Communist
column2: and the unity of the Communist empire has begun to crumble.

column1: In this period we have resolved in friendship our disputes with our neighbors of the hemisphere
column2: and joined in an Alliance for Progress toward economic growth and political democracy.

column1: In this period we have taken more steps toward peace--including the test ban treaty--than at any time since the cold war began.
In this period we have relentlessly pursued our advances toward the conquest of space.
Most important of all
column2: in this period
column3: the United States has reemerged into the fullness of its self-confidence and purpose. No longer are we called upon to get America moving. We are moving. No longer do we doubt our strength or resolution. We are strong and we have proven our resolve.

column1: No longer can anyone wonder whether we are in the grip of historical decay. We know that history is ours to make. And if there is great danger
column2: there is now also the excitement of great expectations.

column1: AMERICA AND THE COMMUNIST NATIONS
Yet we still live in a troubled and perilous world. There is no longer a single threat. There are many. They differ in intensity and in danger. They require different attitudes and different answers.
With the Soviet Union we seek peaceful understandings that can lessen the danger to freedom.
Last fall I asked the American people to choose that course.
I will carry forward their command.
If we are to live together in peace
column2: we must come to know each other better.

column1: I am sure that the American people would welcome a chance to listen to the Soviet leaders on our television--as I would like the Soviet people to hear our leaders on theirs.
I hope the new Soviet leaders can visit America so they can learn about our country at firsthand.
In Eastern Europe restless nations are slowly beginning to assert their identity. Your Government
column2: assisted by the leaders in American labor and business
column3: is now exploring ways to increase peaceful trade with these countries and with the Soviet Union. I will report our conclusions to the Congress.

column1: In Asia
column2: communism wears a more aggressive face.

column1: We see that in Viet-Nam.
Why are we there?
We are there
column2: first
column3: because a friendly nation has asked us for help against the Communist aggression. Ten years ago our President pledged our help. Three Presidents have supported that pledge. We will not break it now.

column1: Second
column2: our own security is tied to the peace of Asia. Twice in one generation we have had to fight against aggression in the Far East. To ignore aggression now would only increase the danger of a much larger war.

column1: Our goal is peace in southeast Asia. That will come only when aggressors leave their neighbors in peace.
What is at stake is the cause of freedom and in that cause America will never be found wanting.
THE NON-COMMUNIST WORLD
But communism is not the only source of trouble and unrest. There are older and deeper sources--in the misery of nations and in man's irrepressible ambition for liberty and a better life.

With the free Republics of Latin America I have always felt--and my country has always felt--very special ties of interest and affection. It will be the purpose of my administration to strengthen these ties. Together we share and shape the destiny of the new world. In the coming year I hope to pay a visit to Latin America. And I will steadily enlarge our commitment to the Alliance for Progress as the instrument of our war against poverty and injustice in this hemisphere.
In the Atlantic community we continue to pursue our goal of 20 years--a Europe that is growing in strength
column2: unity
column3: and cooperation with America. A great unfinished task is the reunification of Germany through self-determination.

column1: This European policy is not based on any abstract design. It is based on the realities of common interests and common values
column2: common dangers and common expectations. These realities will continue to have their way--especially
column3: I think
column4: in our expanding trade and especially in our common defense.

column1: Free Americans have shaped the policies of the United States. And because we know these realities
column2: those policies have been
column3: and will be
column4: in the interest of Europe.

column1: Free Europeans must shape the course of Europe. And
column2: for the same reasons
column3: that course has been
column4: and will be
column5: in our interest and in the interest of freedom.

column1: I found this truth confirmed in my talks with European leaders in the last year. I hope to repay these visits to some of our friends in Europe this year.
In Africa and Asia we are witnessing the turbulent unfolding of new nations and continents.
We welcome them to the society of nations.
We are committed to help those seeking to strengthen their own independence
column2: and to work most closely with those governments dedicated to the welfare of all of their people.

column1: We seek not fidelity to an iron faith
column2: but a diversity of belief as varied as man himself. We seek not to extend the power of America but the progress of humanity. We seek not to dominate others but to strengthen the freedom of all people.

column1: I will seek new ways to use our knowledge to help deal with the explosion in world population and the growing scarcity in world resources.
Finally
column2: we renew our commitment to the continued growth and the effectiveness of the United Nations. The frustrations of the United Nations are a product of the world that we live in
column3: and not of the institution which gives them voice. It is far better to throw these differences open to the assembly of nations than to permit them to fester in silent danger.

column1: These are some of the goals of the American Nation in the world in which we live.
For ourselves we seek neither praise nor blame
column2: neither gratitude nor obedience.

column1: We seek peace.
We seek freedom.
We seek to enrich the life of man.
For that is the world in which we will flourish and that is the world that we mean for all men to ultimately have.
TOWARD THE GREAT SOCIETY
World affairs will continue to call upon our energy and our courage.
But today we can turn increased attention to the character of American life.
We are in the midst of the greatest upward surge of economic well-being in the history of any nation.

Our flourishing progress has been marked by price stability that is unequalled in the world. Our balance of payments deficit has declined and the soundness of our dollar is unquestioned. I pledge to keep it that way and I urge business and labor to cooperate to that end.

We worked for two centuries to climb this peak of prosperity. But we are only at the beginning of the road to the Great Society. Ahead now is a summit where freedom from the wants of the body can help fulfill the needs of the spirit.
We built this Nation to serve its people.
We want to grow and build and create
column2: but we want progress to be the servant and not the master of man.

column1: We do not intend to live in the midst of abundance
column2: isolated from neighbors and nature
column3: confined by blighted cities and bleak suburbs
column4: stunted by a poverty of learning and an emptiness of leisure.

column1: The Great Society asks not how much
column2: but how good; not only how to create wealth but how to use it; not only how fast we are going
column3: but where we are headed.

column1: It proposes as the first test for a nation: the quality of its people.
This kind of society will not flower spontaneously from swelling riches and surging power.
It will not be the gift of government or the creation of presidents. It will require of every American
column2: for many generations
column3: both faith in the destination and the fortitude to make the journey.

column1: And like freedom itself
column2: it will always be challenge and not fulfillment.

column1: And tonight we accept that challenge.
A NATIONAL AGENDA
I propose that we begin a program in education to ensure every American child the fullest development of his mind and skills.
I propose that we begin a massive attack on crippling and killing diseases.
I propose that we launch a national effort to make the American city a better and a more stimulating place to live.
I propose that we increase the beauty of America and end the poisoning of our rivers and the air that we breathe.
I propose that we carry out a new program to develop regions of our country that are now suffering from distress and depression.
I propose that we make new efforts to control and prevent crime and delinquency.
I propose that we eliminate every remaining obstacle to the right and the opportunity to vote.
I propose that we honor and support the achievements of thought and the creations of art.
I propose that we make an all-out campaign against waste and inefficiency.
THE TASK
Our basic task is threefold:
First
column2: to keep our economy growing;

column1: --to open for all Americans the opportunity that is now enjoyed by most Americans;
--and to improve the quality of life for all.
In the next 6 weeks I will submit special messages with detailed proposals for national action in each of these areas.
Tonight I would like just briefly to explain some of my major recommendations in the three main areas of national need.
IV. A GROWING ECONOMY
BASIC POLICIES
First
column2: we must keep our Nation prosperous. We seek full employment opportunity for every American citizen. I will present a budget designed to move the economy forward. More money will be left in the hands of the consumer by a substantial cut in excise taxes. We will continue along the path toward a balanced budget in a balanced economy.

column1: I confidently predict--what every economic sign tells us tonight--the continued flourishing of the American economy.
But we must remember that fear of a recession can contribute to the fact of a recession. The knowledge that our Government will
column2: and can
column3: move swiftly will strengthen the confidence of investors and business.

column1: Congress can reinforce this confidence by insuring that its procedures permit rapid action on temporary income tax cuts. And special funds for job-creating public programs should be made available for immediate use if recession threatens.
Our continued prosperity demands continued price stability. Business
column2: labor
column3: and the consumer all have a high stake in keeping wages and prices within the framework of the guideposts that have already served the Nation so well.

column1: Finding new markets abroad for our goods depends on the initiative of American business. But we stand ready--with credit and other help--to assist the flow of trade which will benefit the entire Nation.
ON THE FARMS

Our economy owes much to the efficiency of our farmers. We must continue to assure them the opportunity to earn a fair reward. I have instructed the Secretary of Agriculture to lead a major effort to find new approaches to reduce the heavy cost of our farm programs and to direct more of our effort to the small farmer who needs the help the most.
INCREASED PROSPERITY
We can help insure continued prosperity through:
--a regional recovery program to assist the development of stricken areas left behind by our national progress;
--further efforts to provide our workers with the skills demanded by modern technology
column2: for the laboring-man is an indispensable force in the American system;

column1: --the extension of the minimum wage to more than 2 million unprotected workers;
--the improvement and the modernization of the unemployment compensation system.
And as pledged in our 1960 and 1964 Democratic platforms
column2: I will propose to Congress changes in the Taft-Hartley Act including section 14(b). I will do so hoping to reduce the conflicts that for several years have divided Americans in various States of our Union.

column1: In a country that spans a continent modern transportation is vital to continued growth.
TRANSPORTATION FOR GROWTH
I will recommend heavier reliance on competition in transportation and a new policy for our merchant marine.
I will ask for funds to study high-speed rail transportation between urban centers. We will begin with test projects between Washington and Boston. On high-speed trains
column2: passengers could travel this distance in less than 4 hours.

column1: II. OPPORTUNITY FOR ALL
Second
column2: we must open opportunity to all our people.

column1: Most Americans enjoy a good life. But far too many are still trapped in poverty and idleness and fear.
Let a just nation throw open to them the city of promise:
--to the elderly
column2: by providing hospital care under social security and by raising benefit payments to those struggling to maintain the dignity of their later years;

column1: --to the poor and the unfortunate
column2: through doubling the war against poverty this year;

column1: --to Negro Americans
column2: through enforcement of the civil rights law and elimination of barriers to the right to vote;

column1: --to those in other lands that are seeking the promise of America
column2: through an immigration law based on the work a man can do and not where he was born or how he spells his name.

column1: III. TO ENRICH THE LIFE OF ALL
Our third goal is to improve the quality of American life.
THROUGH EDUCATION
We begin with learning.
Every child must have the best education that this Nation can provide.
Thomas Jefferson said that no nation can be both ignorant and free. Today no nation can be both ignorant and great.
In addition to our existing programs
column2: I will recommend a new program for schools and students with a first year authorization of $1
column3: 500 million.

column1: It will help at every stage along the road to learning.
For the preschool years we will help needy children become aware of the excitement of learning.
For the primary and secondary school years we will aid public schools serving low-income families and assist students in both public and private schools.

For the college years we will provide scholarships to high school students of the greatest promise and the greatest need and we will guarantee low-interest loans to students continuing their college studies.

New laboratories and centers will help our schools--help them lift their standards of excellence and explore new methods of teaching. These centers will provide special training for those who need and those who deserve special treatment.
THROUGH BETTER HEALTH
Greatness requires not only an educated people but a healthy people.
Our goal is to match the achievements of our medicine to the afflictions of our people.
We already carry on a large program in this country. for research and health.
In addition
column2: regional medical centers can provide the most advanced diagnosis and treatment for heart disease and cancer and stroke and other major diseases.

column1: New support for medical and dental education will provide the trained people to apply our knowledge.
Community centers can help the mentally ill and improve health care for school-age children from poor families
column2: including services for the mentally retarded.

column1: THROUGH IMPROVING THE WORLD WE LIVE IN
The City
An educated and healthy people require surroundings in harmony with their hopes.
In our urban areas the central problem today is to protect and restore man's satisfaction in belonging to a community where he can find security and significance.

The first step is to break old patterns--to begin to think and work and plan for the development of the entire metropolitan areas. We will take this step with new programs of help for the basic community facilities and for neighborhood centers of health and recreation.
New and existing programs will be open to those cities which work together to develop unified long-range policies for metropolitan areas.
We must also make some very important changes in our housing programs if we are to pursue these same basic goals.
So a Department of Housing and Urban Development will be needed to spearhead this effort in our cities.
Every citizen has the right to feel secure in his home and on the streets of his community.
To help control crime
column2: we will recommend programs:

column1: --to train local law enforcement officers;
--to put the best techniques of modern science at their disposal;
--to discover the causes of crime and better ways to prevent it.
I will soon assemble a panel of outstanding experts of this Nation to search out answers to the national problem of crime and delinquency
column2: and I welcome the recommendations and the constructive efforts of the Congress.

column1: The Beauty of America

For over three centuries the beauty of America has sustained our spirit and has enlarged our vision. We must act now to protect this heritage. In a fruitful new partnership with the States and the cities the next decade should be a conservation milestone. We must make a massive effort to save the countryside and to establish--as a green legacy for tomorrow--more large and small parks
column2: more seashores and open spaces than have been created during any other period in our national history.

column1: A new and substantial effort must be made to landscape highways to provide places of relaxation and recreation wherever our roads run
Within our cities imaginative programs are needed to landscape streets and to transform open areas into places of beauty and recreation.
We will seek legal power to prevent pollution of our air and water before it happens. We will step up our effort to control harmful wastes
column2: giving first priority to the cleanup of our most contaminated rivers. We will increase research to learn much more about the control of pollution.

column1: We hope to make the Potomac a model of beauty here in the Capital
column2: and preserve unspoiled stretches of some of our waterways with a Wild Rivers bill.

column1: More ideas for a beautiful America will emerge from a White House Conference on Natural Beauty which I will soon call.
Art and Science
We must also recognize and encourage those who can be pathfinders for the Nation's imagination and understanding.
To help promote and honor creative achievements
column2: I will propose a National Foundation on the Arts.

column1: To develop knowledge which will enrich our lives and ensure our progress
column2: I will recommend programs to encourage basic science
column3: particularly in the universities--and to bring closer the day when the oceans will supply our growing need for fresh water.

column1: IV. THE GOVERNMENT
For government to serve these goals it must be modern in structure
column2: efficient in action
column3: and ready for any emergency.

column1: I am busy
column2: currently
column3: reviewing the structure of the entire executive branch of this Government. I hope to reshape it and to reorganize it to meet more effectively the tasks of the 20th century.

column1: Wherever waste is found
column2: I will eliminate it.

column1: Last year we saved almost $3
column2: 500 million by eliminating waste in the National Government.

column1: And I intend to do better this year.
And very soon I will report to you on our progress and on new economies that your Government plans to make.
Even the best of government is subject to the worst of hazards.
I will propose laws to insure the necessary continuity of leadership should the President become disabled or die.
In addition
column2: I will propose reforms in the electoral college--leaving undisturbed the vote by States--but making sure that no elector can substitute his will for that of the people.

column1: Last year
column2: in a sad moment
column3: I came here and I spoke to you after 33 years of public service
column4: practically all of them here on this Hill.

column1: This year I speak after 1 year as President of the United States.
Many of you in this Chamber are among my oldest friends. We have shared many happy moments and many hours of work
column2: and we have watched many Presidents together. Yet
column3: only in the White House can you finally know the full weight of this Office.

column1: The greatest burden is not running the huge operations of government--or meeting daily troubles
column2: large and small--or even working with the Congress.

column1: A President's hardest task is not to do what is right
column2: but to know what is right.

column1: Yet the Presidency brings no special gift of prophecy or foresight. You take an oath
column2: you step into an office
column3: and you must then help guide a great democracy.

column1: The answer was waiting for me in the land where I was born.

It was once barren land. The angular hills were covered with scrub cedar and a few large live oaks. Little would grow in that harsh caliche soil of my country. And each spring the Pedernales River would flood our valley.
But men came and they worked and they endured and they built.
And tonight that country is abundant; abundant with fruit and cattle and goats and sheep
column2: and there are pleasant homes and lakes and the floods are gone.

column1: Why did men come to that once forbidding land?
Well
column2: they were restless
column3: of course
column4: and they had to be moving on. But there was more than that. There was a dream--a dream of a place where a free man could build for himself
column5: and raise his children to a better life--a dream of a continent to be conquered
column6: a world to be won
column7: a nation to be made.

column1: Remembering this
column2: I knew the answer.

column1: A President does not shape a new and personal vision of America.
He collects it from the scattered hopes of the American past.
It existed when the first settlers saw the coast of a new world
column2: and when the first pioneers moved westward.

column1: It has guided us every step of the way.
It sustains every President. But it is also your inheritance and it belongs equally to all the people that we all serve.
It must be interpreted anew by each generation for its own needs; as I have tried
column2: in part
column3: to do tonight.

column1: It shall lead us as we enter the third century of the search for "a more perfect union."
This
column2: then
column3: is the state of the Union: Free and restless
column4: growing and full of hope.

column1: So it was in the beginning.
So it shall always be
column2: while God is willing
column3: and we are strong enough to keep the faith.@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Special Message to the Congress: The American Promise|1965-03-15|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the Congress:

column1: I speak tonight for the dignity of man and the destiny of democracy.
I urge every member of both parties
column2: Americans of all religions and of all colors
column3: from every section of this country
column4: to join me in that cause.

column1: At times history and fate meet at a single time in a single place to shape a turning point in man's unending search for freedom. So it was at Lexington and Concord. So it was a century ago at Appomattox. So it was last week in Selma
column2: Alabama.

column1: There
column2: long-suffering men and women peacefully protested the denial of their rights as Americans. Many were brutally assaulted. One good man
column3: a man of God
column4: was killed.

column1: There is no cause for pride in what has happened in Selma. There is no cause for self-satisfaction in the long denial of equal rights of millions of Americans. But there is cause for hope and for faith in our democracy in what is happening here tonight.
For the cries of pain and the hymns and protests of oppressed people have summoned into convocation all the majesty of this great Government--the Government of the greatest Nation on earth.
Our mission is at once the oldest and the most basic of this country: to right wrong
column2: to do justice
column3: to serve man.

column1: In our time we have come to live with moments of great crisis. Our lives have been marked with debate about great issues; issues of war and peace
column2: issues of prosperity and depression. But rarely in any time does an issue lay bare the secret heart of America itself. Rarely are we met with a challenge
column3: not to our growth or abundance
column4: our welfare or our security
column5: but rather to the values and the purposes and the meaning of our beloved Nation.

column1: The issue of equal rights for American Negroes is such an issue. And should we defeat every enemy
column2: should we double our wealth and conquer the stars
column3: and still be unequal to this issue
column4: then we will have failed as a people and as a nation.

column1: For with a country as with a person
column2: "What is a man profited
column3: if he shall gain the whole world
column4: and lose his own soul ?"

column1: There is no Negro problem. There is no Southern problem. There is no Northern problem. There is only an American problem. And we are met here tonight as Americans--not as Democrats or Republicans-we are met here as Americans to solve that problem.
This was the first nation in the history of the world to be founded with a purpose. The great phrases of that purpose still sound in every American heart
column2: North and South: "All men are created equal"--"government by consent of the governed"--"give me liberty or give me death." Well
column3: those are not just clever words
column4: or those are not just empty theories. In their name Americans have fought and died for two centuries
column5: and tonight around the world they stand there as guardians of our liberty
column6: risking their lives.

column1: Those words are a promise to every citizen that he shall share in the dignity of man. This dignity cannot be found in a man's possessions; it cannot be found in his power
column2: or in his position. It really rests on his right to be treated as a man equal in opportunity to all others. It says that he shall share in freedom
column3: he shall choose his leaders
column4: educate his children
column5: and provide for his family according to his ability and his merits as a human being.

column1: To apply any other test--to deny a man his hopes because of his color or race
column2: his religion or the place of his birth--is not only to do injustice
column3: it is to deny America and to dishonor the dead who gave their lives for American freedom.

column1: THE RIGHT TO VOTE
Our fathers believed that if this noble view of the rights of man was to flourish
column2: it must be rooted in democracy. The most basic right of all was the right to choose your own leaders. The history of this country
column3: in large measure
column4: is the history of the expansion of that right to all of our people.

column1: Many of the issues of civil rights are very complex and most difficult. But about this there can and should be no argument. Every American citizen must have an equal right to vote. There is no reason which can excuse the denial of that right. There is no duty which weighs more heavily on us than the duty we have to ensure that right.
Yet the harsh fact is that in many places in this country men and women are kept from voting simply because they are Negroes.
Every device of which human ingenuity is capable has been used to deny this right. The Negro citizen may go to register only to be told that the day is wrong
column2: or the hour is late
column3: or the official in charge is absent. And if he persists
column4: and if he manages to present himself to the registrar
column5: he may be disqualified because he did not spell out his middle name or because he abbreviated a word on the application.

column1: And if he manages to fill out an application he is given a test. The registrar is the sole judge of whether he passes this test. He may be asked to recite the entire Constitution
column2: or explain the most complex provisions of State law. And even a college degree cannot be used to prove that he can read and write.

column1: For the fact is that the only way to pass these barriers is to show a white skin.

Experience has clearly shown that the existing process of law cannot overcome systematic and ingenious discrimination. No law that we now have on the books-and I have helped to put three of them there--can ensure the right to vote when local officials are determined to deny it.

In such a case our duty must be clear to all of us. The Constitution says that no person shall be kept from voting because of his race or his color. We have all sworn an oath before God to support and to defend that Constitution. We must now act in obedience to that oath.
GUARANTEEING THE RIGHT TO VOTE
Wednesday I will send to Congress a law designed to eliminate illegal barriers to the right to vote.
The broad principles of that bill will be in the hands of the Democratic and Republican leaders tomorrow. After they have reviewed it
column2: it will come here formally as a bill. I am grateful for this opportunity to come here tonight at the invitation of the leadership to reason with my friends
column3: to give them my views
column4: and to visit with my former colleagues.

column1: I have had prepared a more comprehensive analysis of the legislation which I had intended to transmit to the clerk tomorrow but which I will submit to the clerks tonight. But I want to really discuss with you now briefly the main proposals of this legislation
This bill will strike down restrictions to voting in all elections--Federal
column2: State
column3: and local--which have been used to deny Negroes the right to vote.

column1: This bill will establish a simple
column2: uniform standard which cannot be used
column3: however ingenious the effort
column4: to flout our Constitution.

column1: It will provide for citizens to be registered by officials of the United States Government if the State officials refuse to register them.
It will eliminate tedious
column2: unnecessary lawsuits which delay the right to vote.

column1: Finally
column2: this legislation will ensure that properly registered individuals are not prohibited from voting.

column1: I will welcome the suggestions from all of the Members of Congress--I have no doubt that I will get some--on ways and means to strengthen this law and to make it effective. But experience has plainly shown that this is the only path to carry out the command of the Constitution.
To those who seek to avoid action by their National Government in their own communities; who want to and who seek to maintain purely local control over elections
column2: the answer is simple:

column1: Open your polling places to all your people.
Allow men and women to register and vote whatever the color of their skin.
Extend the rights of citizenship to every citizen of this land.
THE NEED FOR ACTION
There is no constitutional issue here. The command of the Constitution is plain.
There is no moral issue. It is wrong--deadly wrong--to deny any of your fellow Americans the right to vote in this country.
There is no issue of States rights or national rights. There is only the struggle for human rights.
I have not the slightest doubt what will be your answer.

The last time a President sent a civil rights bill to the Congress it contained a provision to protect voting rights in Federal elections. That civil rights bill was passed after 8 long months of debate. And when that bill came to my desk from the Congress for my signature
column2: the heart of the voting provision had been eliminated.

column1: This time
column2: on this issue
column3: there must be no delay
column4: no hesitation and no compromise with our purpose.

column1: We cannot
column2: we must not
column3: refuse to protect the right of every American to vote in every election that he may desire to participate in. And we ought not and we cannot and we must not wait another 8 months before we get a bill. We have already waited a hundred years and more
column4: and the time for waiting is gone.

column1: So I ask you to join me in working long hours--nights and weekends
column2: if necessary--to pass this bill. And I don't make that request lightly. For from the window where I sit with the problems of our country I recognize that outside this chamber is the outraged conscience of a nation
column3: the grave concern of many nations
column4: and the harsh judgment of history on our acts.

column1: WE SHALL OVERCOME
But even if we pass this bill
column2: the battle will not be over. What happened in Selma is part of a far larger movement which reaches into every section and State of America. It is the effort of American Negroes to secure for themselves the full blessings of American life.

column1: Their cause must be our cause too. Because it is not just Negroes
column2: but really it is all of us
column3: who must overcome the crippling legacy of bigotry and injustice.

column1: And we shall overcome.
As a man whose roots go deeply into Southern soil I know how agonizing racial feelings are. I know how difficult it is to reshape the attitudes and the structure of our society.
But a century has passed
column2: more than a hundred years
column3: since the Negro was freed. And he is not fully free tonight.

column1: It was more than a hundred years ago that Abraham Lincoln
column2: a great President of another party
column3: signed the Emancipation Proclamation
column4: but emancipation is a proclamation and not a fact.

column1: A century has passed
column2: more than a hundred years
column3: since equality was promised. And yet the Negro is not equal.

column1: A century has passed since the day of promise. And the promise is unkept.
The time of justice has now come. I tell you that I believe sincerely that no force can hold it back. It is right in the eyes of man and God that it should come. And when it does
column2: I think that day will brighten the lives of every American.

column1: For Negroes are not the only victims. How many white children have gone uneducated
column2: how many white families have lived in stark poverty
column3: how many white lives have been scarred by fear
column4: because we have wasted our energy and our substance to maintain the barriers of hatred and terror?

column1: So I say to all of you here
column2: and to all in the Nation tonight
column3: that those who appeal to you to hold on to the past do so at the cost of denying you your future.

column1: This great
column2: rich
column3: restless country can offer opportunity and education and hope to all: black and white
column4: North and South
column5: sharecropper and city dweller. These are the enemies: poverty
column6: ignorance
column7: disease. They are the enemies and not our fellow man
column8: not our neighbor. And these enemies too
column9: poverty
column10: disease and ignorance

column1: AN AMERICAN PROBLEM
Now let none of us in any sections look with prideful righteousness on the troubles in another section
column2: or on the problems of our neighbors. There is really no part of America where the promise of equality has been fully kept. In Buffalo as well as in Birmingham
column3: in Philadelphia as well as in Selma
column4: Americans are struggling for the fruits of freedom.

column1: This is one Nation. What happens in Selma or in Cincinnati is a matter of legitimate concern to every American. But let each of us look within our own hearts and our own communities
column2: and let each of us put our shoulder to the wheel to root out injustice wherever it exists.

column1: As we meet here in this peaceful
column2: historic chamber tonight
column3: men from the South
column4: some of whom were at Iwo Jima
column5: men from the North who have carried Old Glory to far corners of the world and brought it back without a stain on it
column6: men from the East and from the West
column7: are all fighting together without regard to religion
column8: or color
column9: or region
column10: in Viet-Nam. Men from every region fought for us across the world 20 years ago.

column1: And in these common dangers and these common sacrifices the South made its contribution of honor and gallantry no less than any other region of the great Republic--and in some instances
column2: a great many of them
column3: more.

column1: And I have not the slightest doubt that good men from everywhere in this country
column2: from the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico
column3: from the Golden Gate to the harbors along the Atlantic
column4: will rally together now in this cause to vindicate the freedom of all Americans. For all of us owe this duty; and I believe that all of us will respond to it.

column1: Your President makes that request of every American.
PROGRESS THROUGH THE DEMOCRATIC PROCESS
The real hero of this struggle is the American Negro. His actions and protests
column2: his courage to risk safety and even to risk his life
column3: have awakened the conscience of this Nation. His demonstrations have been designed to call attention to injustice
column4: designed to provoke change
column5: designed to stir reform.

column1: He has called upon us to make good the promise of America. And who among us can say that we would have made the same progress were it not for his persistent bravery
column2: and his faith in American democracy.

column1: For at the real heart of battle for equality is a deep-seated belief in the democratic process. Equality depends not on the force of arms or tear gas but upon the force of moral right; not on recourse to violence but on respect for law and order.

There have been many pressures upon your President and there will be others as the days come and go. But I pledge you tonight that we intend to fight this battle where it should be fought: in the courts
column2: and in the Congress
column3: and in the hearts of men.

column1: We must preserve the right of free speech and the right of free assembly. But the right of free speech does not carry with it
column2: as has been said
column3: the right to holler fire in a crowded theater. We must preserve the right to free assembly
column4: but free assembly does not carry with it the right to block public thoroughfares to traffic.

column1: We do have a right to protest
column2: and a right to march under conditions that do not infringe the constitutional rights of our neighbors. And I intend to protect all those rights as long as I am permitted to serve in this office.

column1: We will guard against violence
column2: knowing it strikes from our hands the very weapons which we seek--progress
column3: obedience to law
column4: and belief in American values.

column1: In Selma as elsewhere we seek and pray for peace. We seek order. We seek unity. But we will not accept the peace of stifled rights
column2: or the order imposed by fear
column3: or the unity that stifles protest. For peace cannot be purchased at the cost of liberty.

column1: In Selma tonight
column2: as in every--and we had a good day there--as in every city
column3: we are working for just and peaceful settlement. We must all remember that after this speech I am making tonight
column4: after the police and the FBI and the Marshals have all gone
column5: and after you have promptly passed this bill
column6: the people of Selma and the other cities of the Nation must still live and work together. And when the attention of the Nation has gone elsewhere they must try to heal the wounds and to build a new community.

column1: This cannot be easily done on a battleground of violence
column2: as the history of the South itself shows. It is in recognition of this that men of both races have shown such an outstandingly impressive responsibility in recent days--last Tuesday
column3: again today

column1: RIGHTS MUST BE OPPORTUNITIES
The bill that I am presenting to you will be known as a civil rights bill. But
column2: in a larger sense
column3: most of the program I am recommending is a civil rights program. Its object is to open the city of hope to all people of all races.

column1: Because all Americans just must have the right to vote. And we are going to give them that right.
All Americans must have the privileges of citizenship regardless of race. And they are going to have those privileges of citizenship regardless of race.
But I would like to caution you and remind you that to exercise these privileges takes much more than just legal right. It requires a trained mind and a healthy body. It requires a decent home
column2: and the chance to find a job
column3: and the opportunity to escape from the clutches of poverty.

column1: Of course
column2: people cannot contribute to the Nation if they are never taught to read or write
column3: if their bodies are stunted from hunger
column4: if their sickness goes untended
column5: if their life is spent in hopeless poverty just drawing a welfare check.

column1: So we want to open the gates to opportunity. But we are also going to give all our people
column2: black and white
column3: the help that they need to walk through those gates.

column1: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GOVERNMENT
My first job after college was as a teacher in Cotulla
column2: Tex.
column3: in a small Mexican-American school. Few of them could speak English
column4: and I couldn't speak much Spanish. My students were poor and they often came to class without breakfast
column5: hungry. They knew even in their youth the pain of prejudice. They never seemed to know why people disliked them. But they knew it was so
column6: because I saw it in their eyes. I often walked home late in the afternoon
column7: after the classes were finished
column8: wishing there was more that I could do. But all I knew was to teach them the little that I knew
column9: hoping that it might help them against the hardships that lay ahead.

column1: Somehow you never forget what poverty and hatred can do when you see its scars on the hopeful face of a young child.
I never thought then
