column3: that I would be standing here in 1965. It never even occurred to me in my fondest dreams that I might have the chance to help the sons and daughters of those students and to help people like them all over this country.

column1: But now I do have that chance--and I'll let you in on a secret--I mean to use it. And I hope that you will use it with me.
This is the richest and most powerful country which ever occupied the globe. The might of past empires is little compared to ours. But I do not want to be the President who built empires
column2: or sought grandeur
column3: or extended dominion.

column1: I want to be the President who educated young children to the wonders of their world. I want to be the President who helped to feed the hungry and to prepare them to be taxpayers instead of taxeaters.
I want to be the President who helped the poor to find their own way and who protected the right of every citizen to vote in every election.
I want to be the President who helped to end hatred among his fellow men and who promoted love among the people of all races and all regions and all parties.
I want to be the President who helped to end war among the brothers of this earth.
And so at the request of your beloved Speaker and the Senator from Montana; the majority leader
column2: the Senator from Illinois; the minority leader
column3: Mr. McCulloch
column4: and other Members of both parties
column5: I came here tonight--not as President Roosevelt came down one time in person to veto a bonus bill
column6: not as President Truman came down one time to urge the passage of a railroad bill--but I came down here to ask you to share this task with me and to share it with the people that we both work for. I want this to be the Congress
column7: Republicans and Democrats alike
column8: which did all these things for all these people.

column1: Beyond this great chamber
column2: out yonder in 50 States
column3: are the people that we serve. Who can tell what deep and unspoken hopes are in their hearts tonight as they sit there and listen. We all can guess
column4: from our own lives
column5: how difficult they often find their own pursuit of happiness
column6: how many problems each little family has. They look most of all to themselves for their futures. But I think that they also look to each of us.

column1: Above the pyramid on the great seal of the United States it says--in Latin--"God has favored our undertaking."

God will not favor everything that we do. It is rather our duty to divine His will. But I cannot help believing that He truly understands and that He really favors the undertaking that we begin here tonight.@
Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1966-01-12|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the House and the Senate
column4: my fellow Americans:

column1: I come before you tonight to report on the State of the Union for the third time.
I come here to thank you and to add my tribute
column2: once more
column3: to the Nation's gratitude for this
column4: the 89th Congress. This Congress has already reserved for itself an honored chapter in the history of America.

column1: Our Nation tonight is engaged in a brutal and bitter conflict in Vietnam. Later on I want to discuss that struggle in some detail with you. It just must be the center of our concerns.
But we will not permit those who fire upon us in Vietnam to win a victory over the desires and the intentions of all the American people. This Nation is mighty enough
column2: its society is healthy enough
column3: its people are strong enough
column4: to pursue our goals in the rest of the world while still building a Great Society here at home.

column1: And that is what I have come here to ask of you tonight.
I recommend that you provide the resources to carry forward
column2: with full vigor
column3: the great health and education programs that you enacted into law last year.

column1: I recommend that we prosecute with vigor and determination our war on poverty.
I recommend that you give a new and daring direction to our foreign aid program
column2: designed to make a maximum attack on hunger and disease and ignorance in those countries that are determined to help themselves
column3: and to help those nations that are trying to control population growth.

column1: I recommend that you make it possible to expand trade between the United States and Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
I recommend to you a program to rebuild completely
column2: on a scale never before attempted
column3: entire central and slum areas of several of our cities in America.

column1: I recommend that you attack the wasteful and degrading poisoning of our rivers
column2: and
column3: as the cornerstone of this effort
column4: clean completely entire large river basins.

column1: I recommend that you meet the growing menace of crime in the streets by building up law enforcement and by revitalizing the entire Federal system from prevention to probation.
I recommend that you take additional steps to insure equal justice to all of our people by effectively enforcing nondiscrimination in Federal and State jury selection
column2: by making it a serious Federal crime to obstruct public and private efforts to secure civil rights
column3: and by outlawing discrimination in the sale and rental of housing.

column1: I recommend that you help me modernize and streamline the Federal Government by creating a new Cabinet level Department of Transportation and reorganizing several existing agencies. In turn
column2: I will restructure our civil service in the top grades so that men and women can easily be assigned to jobs where they are most needed
column3: and ability will be both required as well as rewarded.

column1: I will ask you to make it possible for Members of the House of Representatives to work more effectively in the service of the Nation through a constitutional amendment extending the term of a Congressman to 4 years
column2: concurrent with that of the President.

column1: II.
Because of Vietnam we cannot do all that we should
column2: or all that we would like to do. We will ruthlessly attack waste and inefficiency. We will make sure that every dollar is spent with the thrift and with the commonsense which recognizes how hard the taxpayer worked in order to earn it.

column1: We will continue to meet the needs of our people by continuing to develop the Great Society.
Last year alone the wealth that we produced increased $47 billion
column2: and it will soar again this year to a total over $720 billion.

column1: Because our economic policies have produced rising revenues
column2: if you approve every program that I recommend tonight
column3: our total budget deficit will be one of the lowest in many years. It will be only $1.8 billion next year. Total spending in the administrative budget will be $112.8 billion. Revenues next year will be $111 billion.

column1: On a cash basis--which is the way that you and I keep our family budget--the Federal budget next year will actually show a surplus. That is to say
column2: if we include all the money that your Government will take in and all the money that your Government will spend
column3: your Government next year will collect one-half billion dollars more than it will spend in the year 1967.

column1: I have not come here tonight to ask for pleasant luxuries or for idle pleasures. I have come here to recommend that you
column2: the representatives of the richest Nation on earth
column3: you
column4: the elected servants of a people who live in abundance unmatched on this globe
column5: you bring the most urgent decencies of life to all of your fellow Americans.

column1: There are men who cry out: We must sacrifice. Well
column2: let us rather ask them: Who will they sacrifice? Are they going to sacrifice the children who seek the learning
column3: or the sick who need medical care
column4: or the families who dwell in squalor now brightened by the hope of home? Will they sacrifice opportunity for the distressed
column5: the beauty of our land
column6: the hope of our poor?

column1: Time may require further sacrifices. And if it does
column2: then we will make them.

column1: But we will not heed those who wring it from the hopes of the unfortunate here in a land of plenty.
I believe that we can continue the Great Society while we fight in Vietnam. But if there are some who do not believe this
column2: then
column3: in the name of justice
column4: let them call for the contribution of those who live in the fullness of our blessing
column5: rather than try to strip it from the hands of those that are most in need.

column1: And let no one think that the unfortunate and the oppressed of this land sit stifled and alone in their hope tonight. Hundreds of their servants and their protectors sit before me tonight here in this great Chamber.
III.
The Great Society leads us along three roads--growth and justice and liberation.
[1.] First is growth--the national prosperity which supports the well-being of our people and which provides the tools of our progress.
I can report to you tonight what you have seen for yourselves already--in every city and countryside. This Nation is flourishing.
Workers are making more money than ever--with after-tax income in the past 5 years up 33 percent; in the last year alone
column2: up 8 percent.

column1: More people are working than ever before in our history--an increase last year of 2 1/2 million jobs.
Corporations have greater after-tax earnings than ever in history. For the past 5 years those earnings have been up over 65 percent
column2: and last year alone they had a rise of 20 percent.

column1: Average farm income is higher than ever. Over the past 5 years it is up 40 percent
column2: and over the past year it is up 22 percent alone.

column1: I was informed this afternoon by the distinguished Secretary of the Treasury that his preliminary estimates indicate that our balance of payments deficit has been reduced from $2.8 billion in 1964 to $1.3 billion
column2: or less
column3: in 1965. This achievement has been made possible by the patriotic voluntary cooperation of businessmen and bankers working with your Government.

column1: We must now work together with increased urgency to wipe out this balance of payments deficit altogether in the next year.

And as our economy surges toward new heights we must increase our vigilance against the inflation which raises the cost of living and which lowers the savings of every family in this land. It is essential
column2: to prevent inflation
column3: that we ask both labor and business to exercise price and wage restraint
column4: and I do so again tonight.

column1: I believe it desirable
column2: because of increased military expenditures
column3: that you temporarily restore the automobile and certain telephone excise tax reductions made effective only 12 days ago. Without raising taxes--or even increasing the total tax bill paid--we should move to improve our withholding system so that Americans can more realistically pay as they go
column4: speed up the collection of corporate taxes
column5: and make other necessary simplifications of the tax structure at an early date.

column1: I hope these measures will be adequate. But if the necessities of Vietnam require it
column2: I will not hesitate to return to the Congress for additional appropriations
column3: or additional revenues if they are needed.

column1: [2.] The second road is justice. Justice means a man's hope should not be limited by the color of his skin.

I propose legislation to establish unavoidable requirements for nondiscriminatory jury selection in Federal and State courts--and to give the Attorney General the power necessary to enforce those requirements.
I propose legislation to strengthen authority of Federal courts to try those who murder
column2: attack
column3: or intimidate either civil rights workers or others exercising their constitutional rights--and to increase penalties to a level equal to the nature of the crime.

column1: Legislation
column2: resting on the fullest constitutional authority of the Federal Government
column3: to prohibit racial discrimination in the sale or rental of housing.

column1: For that other nation within a Nation--the poor--whose distress has now captured the conscience of America
column2: I will ask the Congress not only to continue
column3: but to speed up the war on poverty. And in so doing
column4: we will provide the added energy of achievement with the increased efficiency of experience.

column1: To improve the life of our rural Americans and our farm population
column2: we will plan for the future through the establishment of several new Community Development Districts
column3: improved education through the use of Teacher Corps teams
column4: better health measures
column5: physical examinations
column6: and adequate and available medical resources.

column1: For those who labor
column2: I propose to improve unemployment insurance
column3: to expand minimum wage benefits
column4: and by the repeal of section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Act to make the labor laws in all our States equal to the laws of the 31 States which do not have tonight right-to-work measures.

column1: And I also intend to ask the Congress to consider measures which
column2: without improperly invading State and local authority
column3: will enable us effectively to deal with strikes which threaten irreparable damage to the national interest.

column1: [3.] The third path is the path of liberation. It is to use our success for the fulfillment of our lives. A great nation is one which breeds a great people. A great people flower not from wealth and power
column2: but from a society which spurs them to the fullness of their genius. That alone is a Great Society.

column1: Yet
column2: slowly
column3: painfully
column4: on the edge of victory
column5: has come the knowledge that shared prosperity is not enough. In the midst of abundance modern man walks oppressed by forces which menace and confine the quality of his life
column6: and which individual abundance alone will not overcome.

column1: We can subdue and we can master these forces--bring increased meaning to our lives--if all of us
column2: Government and citizens
column3: are bold enough to change old ways
column4: daring enough to assault new dangers
column5: and if the dream is dear enough to call forth the limitless capacities of this great people.

column1: This year we must continue to improve the quality of American life.
Let us fulfill and improve the great health and education programs of last year
column2: extending special opportunities to those who risk their lives in our Armed Forces.

column1: I urge the House of Representatives to complete action on three programs already passed by the Senate--the Teacher Corps
column2: rent assistance
column3: and home rule for the District of Columbia.

column1: In some of our urban areas we must help rebuild entire sections and neighborhoods containing
column2: in some cases
column3: as many as 100
column4: 000 people. Working together
column5: private enterprise and government must press forward with the task of providing homes and shops
column6: parks and hospitals
column7: and all the other necessary parts of a flourishing community where our people can come to live the good life.

column1: I will offer other proposals to stimulate and to reward planning for the growth of entire metropolitan areas.
Of all the reckless devastations of our national heritage
column2: none is really more shameful than the continued poisoning of our rivers and our air.

column1: We must undertake a cooperative effort to end pollution in several river basins
column2: making additional funds available to help draw the plans and construct the plants that are necessary to make the waters of our entire river systems clean
column3: and make them a source of pleasure and beauty for all of our people.

column1: To attack and to overcome growing crime and lawlessness
column2: I think we must have a stepped-up program to help modernize and strengthen our local police forces.

column1: Our people have a right to feel secure in their homes and on their streets--and that right just must be secured.
Nor can we fail to arrest the destruction of life and property on our highways.
I will propose a Highway Safety Act of 1966 to seek an end to this mounting tragedy.

We must also act to prevent the deception of the American consumer--requiring all packages to state clearly and truthfully their contents--all interest and credit charges to be fully revealed--and keeping harmful drugs and cosmetics away from our stores.
It is the genius of our Constitution that under its shelter of enduring institutions and rooted principles there is ample room for the rich fertility of American political invention.
We must change to master change.
I propose to take steps to modernize and streamline the executive branch
column2: to modernize the relations between city and State and Nation.

column1: A new Department of Transportation is needed to bring together our transportation activities. The present structure--35 Government agencies
column2: spending $5 billion yearly--makes it almost impossible to serve either the growing demands of this great Nation or the needs of the industry
column3: or the right of the taxpayer to full efficiency and real frugality.

column1: I will propose in addition a program to construct and to flight-test a new supersonic transport airplane that will fly three times the speed of sound--in excess of 2
column2: 000 miles per hour.

column1: I propose to examine our Federal system--the relation between city
column2: State
column3: Nation
column4: and the citizens themselves. We need a commission of the most distinguished scholars and men of public affairs to do this job. I will ask them to move on to develop a creative federalism to best use the wonderful diversity of our institutions and our people to solve the problems and to fulfill the dreams of the American people.

column1: As the process of election becomes more complex and more costly
column2: we must make it possible for those without personal wealth to enter public life without being obligated to a few large contributors.

column1: Therefore
column2: I will submit legislation to revise the present unrealistic restriction on contributions--to prohibit the endless proliferation of committees
column3: bringing local and State committees under the act--to attach strong teeth and severe penalties to the requirement of full disclosure of contributions--and to broaden the participation of the people
column4: through added tax incentives
column5: to stimulate small contributions to the party and to the candidate of their choice.

column1: To strengthen the work of Congress I strongly urge an amendment to provide a 4-year term for Members of the House of Representatives--which should not begin before 1972.

The present 2-year term requires most Members of Congress to divert enormous energies to an almost constant process of campaigning--depriving this Nation of the fullest measure of both their skill and their wisdom. Today
column2: too
column3: the work of government is far more complex than in our early years
column4: requiring more time to learn and more time to master the technical tasks of legislating. And a longer term will serve to attract more men of the highest quality to political life. The Nation
column5: the principle of democracy
column6: and
column7: I think
column8: each congressional district
column9: will all be better served by a 4-year term for Members of the House. And I urge your swift action.

column1: IV.
Tonight the cup of peril is full in Vietnam.
That conflict is not an isolated episode
column2: but another great event in the policy that we have followed with strong consistency since World War II.

column1: The touchstone of that policy is the interest of the United States--the welfare and the freedom of the people of the United States. But nations sink when they see that interest only through a narrow glass.
In a world that has grown small and dangerous
column2: pursuit of narrow aims could bring decay and even disaster.

column1: An America that is mighty beyond description--yet living in a hostile or despairing--world would be neither safe nor free to build a civilization to liberate the spirit of man.
In this pursuit we helped rebuild Western Europe. We gave our aid to Greece and Turkey
column2: and we defended the freedom of Berlin.

column1: In this pursuit we have helped new nations toward independence. We have extended the helping hand of the Peace Corps and carried forward the largest program of economic assistance in the world.
And in this pursuit we work to build a hemisphere of democracy and of social justice.

In this pursuit we have defended against Communist aggression--in Korea under President Truman--in the Formosa Straits under President Eisenhower--in Cuba under President Kennedy--and again in Vietnam.
Tonight Vietnam must hold the center of our attention
column2: but across the world problems and opportunities crowd in on the American Nation. I will discuss them fully in the months to come
column3: and I will follow the five continuing lines of policy that America has followed under its last four Presidents.

column1: [1.] The first principle is strength.
Tonight I can tell you that we are strong enough to keep all of our commitments. We will need expenditures of $58.3 billion for the next fiscal year to maintain this necessary defense might.
While special Vietnam expenditures for the next fiscal year are estimated to increase by $5.8 billion
column2: I can tell you that all the other expenditures put together in the entire Federal budget will rise this coming year by only $.6 billion. This is true because of the stringent cost-conscious economy program inaugurated in the Defense Department
column3: and followed by the other departments of Government.

column1: [2.] A second principle of policy is the effort to control
column2: and to reduce
column3: and to ultimately eliminate the modern engines of destruction.

column1: We will vigorously pursue existing proposals--and seek new ones--to control arms and to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.
[3.] A third major principle of our foreign policy is to help build those associations of nations which reflect the opportunities and the necessities of the modern world.
By strengthening the common defense
column2: by stimulating world commerce
column3: by meeting new hopes
column4: these associations serve the cause of a flourishing world.

column1: We will take new steps this year to help strengthen the Alliance for Progress
column2: the unity of Europe
column3: the community of the Atlantic
column4: the regional organizations of developing continents
column5: and that supreme association--the United Nations.

column1: We will work to strengthen economic cooperation
column2: to reduce barriers to trade
column3: and to improve international finance.

column1: [4.] A fourth enduring strand of policy has been to help improve the life of man.
From the Marshall plan to this very moment tonight
column2: that policy has rested on the claims of compassion
column3: and the certain knowledge that only a people advancing in expectation will build secure and peaceful lands.

column1: This year I propose major new directions in our program of foreign assistance to help those countries who will help themselves.
We will conduct a worldwide attack on the problems of hunger and disease and ignorance.
We will place the matchless skill and the resources of our own great America
column2: in farming and in fertilizers
column3: at the service of those countries committed to develop a modern agriculture.

column1: We will aid those who educate the young in other lands
column2: and we will give children in other continents the same head start that we are trying to give our own children. To advance these ends I will propose the International Education Act of 1966.

column1: I will also propose the International Health Act of 1966 to strike at disease by a new effort to bring modern skills and knowledge to the uncared-for
column2: those suffering in the world
column3: and by trying to wipe out smallpox and malaria and control yellow fever over most of the world during this next decade; to help countries trying to control population growth
column4: by increasing our research--and we will earmark funds to help their efforts.

column1: In the next year
column2: from our foreign aid sources
column3: we propose to dedicate $1 billion to these efforts
column4: and we call on all who have the means to join us in this work in the world.

column1: [5.] The fifth and most important principle of our foreign policy is support of national independence--the right of each people to govern themselves--and to shape their own institutions.
For a peaceful world order will be possible only when each country walks the way that it has chosen to walk for itself.
We follow this principle by encouraging the end of colonial rule.
We follow this principle
column2: abroad as well as at home
column3: by continued hostility to the rule of the many by the few--or the oppression of one race by another.

column1: We follow this principle by building bridges to Eastern Europe. And I will ask the Congress for authority to remove the special tariff restrictions which are a barrier to increasing trade between the East and the West.
The insistent urge toward national independence is the strongest force of today's world in which we live.
In Africa and Asia and Latin America it is shattering the designs of those who would subdue others to their ideas or their will.
It is eroding the unity of what was once a Stalinist empire.
In recent months a number of nations have cast out those who would subject them to the ambitions of mainland China.
History is on the side of freedom and is on the side of societies shaped from the genius of each people. History does not favor a single system or belief--unless force is used to make it so.
That is why it has been necessary for us to defend this basic principle of our policy
column2: to defend it in Berlin
column3: in Korea
column4: in Cuba--and tonight in Vietnam.

column1: For tonight
column2: as so many nights before
column3: young Americans struggle and young Americans die in a distant land.

column1: Tonight
column2: as so many nights before
column3: the American Nation is asked to sacrifice the blood of its children and the fruits of its labor for the love of its freedom.

column1: How many times--in my lifetime and in yours--have the American people gathered
column2: as they do now
column3: to hear their President tell them of conflict and tell them of danger?

column1: Each time they have answered. They have answered with all the effort that the security and the freedom of this Nation required.
And they do again tonight in Vietnam.
Not too many years ago Vietnam was a peaceful
column2: if troubled
column3: land. In the North was an independent Communist government. In the South a people struggled to build a nation
column4: with the friendly help of the United States.

column1: There were some in South Vietnam who wished to force Communist rule on their own people. But their progress was slight. Their hope of success was dim. Then
column2: little more than 6 years ago
column3: North Vietnam decided on conquest. And from that day to this
column4: soldiers and supplies have moved from North to South in a swelling stream that is swallowing the remnants of revolution in aggression.

column1: As the assault mounted
column2: our choice gradually became clear. We could leave
column3: abandoning South Vietnam to its attackers and to certain conquest
column4: or we could stay and fight beside the people of South Vietnam.

column1: We stayed.
And we will stay until aggression has stopped.

We will stay because a just nation cannot leave to the cruelties of its enemies a people who have staked their lives and independence on America's solemn pledge--a pledge which has grown through the commitments of three American Presidents.
We will stay because in Asia and around the world are countries whose independence rests
column2: in large measure
column3: on confidence in America's word and in America's protection. To yield to force in Vietnam would weaken that confidence
column4: would undermine the independence of many lands
column5: and would whet the appetite of aggression. We would have to fight in one land
column6: and then we would have to fight in another--or abandon much of Asia to the domination of Communists.

column1: And we do not intend to abandon Asia to conquest.

Last year the nature of the war in Vietnam changed again. Swiftly increasing numbers of armed men from the North crossed the borders to join forces that were already in the South. Attack and terror increased
column2: spurred and encouraged by the belief that the United States lacked the will to continue and that their victory was near.

column1: Despite our desire to limit conflict
column2: it was necessary to act: to hold back the mounting aggression
column3: to give courage to the people of the South
column4: and to make our firmness clear to the North. Thus. we began limited air action against military targets in North Vietnam. We increased our fighting force to its present strength tonight of 190
column5: 000 men.

column1: These moves have not ended the aggression but they have prevented its success. The aims of the enemy have been put out of reach by the skill and the bravery of Americans and their allies--and by the enduring courage of the South Vietnamese who
column2: I can tell you
column3: have lost eight men last year for every one of ours.

column1: The enemy is no longer close to victory. Time is no longer on his side. There is no cause to doubt the American commitment.
Our decision to stand firm has been matched by our desire for peace.
In 1965 alone we had 300 private talks for peace in Vietnam
column2: with friends and adversaries throughout the world.

column1: Since Christmas your Government has labored again
column2: with imagination and endurance
column3: to remove any barrier to peaceful settlement. For 20 days now we and our Vietnamese allies have dropped no bombs in North Vietnam.

column1: Able and experienced spokesmen have visited
column2: in behalf of America
column3: more than 40 countries. We have talked to more than a hundred governments
column4: all 113 that we have relations with
column5: and some that we don't. We have talked to the United Nations and we have called upon all of its members to make any contribution that they can toward helping obtain peace.

column1: In public statements and in private communications
column2: to adversaries and to friends
column3: in Rome and Warsaw
column4: in Paris and Tokyo
column5: in Africa and throughout this hemisphere
column6: America has made her position abundantly clear.

column1: We seek neither territory nor bases
column2: economic domination or military alliance in Vietnam. We fight for the principle of self-determination--that the people of South Vietnam should be able to choose their own course
column3: choose it in free elections without violence
column4: without terror
column5: and without fear.

column1: The people of all Vietnam should make a free decision on the great question of reunification.
This is all we want for South Vietnam. It is all the people of South Vietnam want. And if there is a single nation on this earth that desires less than this for its own people
column2: then let its voice be heard.

column1: We have also made it clear--from Hanoi to New York--that there are no arbitrary limits to our search for peace. We stand by the Geneva Agreements of 1954 and 1962. We will meet at any conference table
column2: we will discuss any proposals--four points or fourteen or forty--and we will consider the views of any group. We will work for a cease-fire now or once discussions have begun. We will respond if others reduce their use of force
column3: and we will withdraw our soldiers once South Vietnam is securely guaranteed the right to shape its own future.

column1: We have said all this
column2: and we have asked--and hoped--and we have waited for a response.

column1: So far we have received no response to prove either success or failure.
We have carried our quest for peace to many nations and peoples because we share this planet with others whose future
column2: in large measure
column3: is tied to our own action
column4: and whose counsel is necessary to our own hopes.

column1: We have found understanding and support. And we know they wait with us tonight for some response that could lead to peace.
I wish tonight that I could give you a blueprint for the course of this conflict over the coming months
column2: but we just cannot know what the future may require. We may have to face long
column3: hard combat or a long
column4: hard conference
column5: or even both at once.

column1: Until peace comes
column2: or if it does not come
column3: our course is clear. We will act as we must to help protect the independence of the valiant people of South Vietnam. We will strive to limit the conflict
column4: for we wish neither increased destruction nor do we want to invite increased danger.

column1: But we will give our fighting men what they must have: every gun
column2: and every dollar
column3: and every decision--whatever the cost or whatever the challenge.

column1: And we will continue to help the people of South Vietnam care for those that are ravaged by battle
column2: create progress in the villages
column3: and carry forward the healing hopes of peace as best they can amidst the uncertain terrors of war.

column1: And let me be absolutely clear: The days may become months
column2: and the months may become years
column3: but we will stay as long as aggression commands us to battle.

column1: There may be some who do not want peace
column2: whose ambitions stretch so far that war in Vietnam is but a welcome and convenient episode in an immense design to subdue history to their will. But for others it must now be clear--the choice is not between peace and victory
column3: it lies between peace and the ravages of a conflict from which they can only lose.

column1: The people of Vietnam
column2: North and South
column3: seek the same things: the shared needs of man
column4: the needs for food and shelter and education--the chance to build and work and till the soil
column5: free from the arbitrary horrors of battle--the desire to walk in the dignity of those who master their own destiny. For many painful years
column6: in war and revolution and infrequent peace
column7: they have struggled to fulfill those needs.

column1: It is a crime against mankind that so much courage
column2: and so much will
column3: and so many dreams
column4: must be flung on the fires of war and death.

column1: To all of those caught up in this conflict we therefore say again tonight: Let us choose peace
column2: and with it the wondrous works of peace
column3: and beyond that
column4: the time when hope reaches toward consummation
column5: and life is the servant of life.

column1: In this work
column2: we plan to discharge our duty to the people whom we serve.

column1: V.
This is the State of the Union.
But over it all--wealth
column2: and promise
column3: and expectation--lies our troubling awareness of American men at war tonight.

column1: How many men who listen to me tonight have served their Nation in other wars? How very many are not here to listen?
The war in Vietnam is not like these other wars. Yet
column2: finally
column3: war is always the same. It is young men dying in the fullness of their promise. It is trying to kill a man that you do not even know well enough to hate.

column1: Therefore
column2: to know war is to know that there is still madness in this world.

column1: Many of you share the burden of this knowledge tonight with me. But there is a difference. For finally I must be the one to order our guns to fire
column2: against all the most inward pulls of my desire. For we have children to teach
column3: and we have sick to be cured
column4: and we have men to be freed. There are poor to be lifted up
column5: and there are cities to be built
column6: and there is a world to be helped.

column1: Yet we do what we must.
I am hopeful
column2: and I will try as best I can
column3: with everything I have got
column4: to end this battle and to return our sons to their desires.

column1: Yet as long as others will challenge America's security and test the clearness of our beliefs with fire and steel
column2: then we must stand or see the promise of two centuries tremble. I believe tonight that you do not want me to try that risk. And from that belief your President summons his strength for the trials that lie ahead in the days to come.

column1: The work must be our work now. Scarred by the weaknesses of man
column2: with whatever guidance God may offer us
column3: we must nevertheless and alone with our mortality
column4: strive to ennoble the life of man on earth.

column1: Thank you
column2: and goodnight.@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1967-01-10|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: distinguished Members of the Congress:

column1: I share with all of you the grief that you feel at the death today of one of the most beloved
column2: respected
column3: and effective Members of this body
column4: the distinguished Representative from Rhode Island
column5: Mr. Fogarty.

column1: I have come here tonight to report to you that this is a time of testing for our Nation.
At home
column2: the question is whether we will continue working for better opportunities for all Americans
column3: when most Americans are already living better than any people in history.

column1: Abroad
column2: the question is whether we have the staying power to fight a very costly war
column3: when the objective is limited and the danger to us is seemingly remote.

column1: So our test is not whether we shrink from our country's cause when the dangers to us are obvious and close at hand
column2: but
column3: rather
column4: whether we carry on when they seem obscure and distant--and some think that it is safe to lay down our burdens.

column1: I have come tonight to ask this Congress and this Nation to resolve that issue: to meet our commitments at home and abroad--to continue to build a better America--and to reaffirm this Nation's allegiance to freedom.
As President Abraham Lincoln said
column2: "We must ask where we are
column3: and whither we are tending."

column1: I.
The last 3 years bear witness to our determination to make this a better country.
We have struck down legal barriers to equality.
We have improved the education of 7 million deprived children and this year alone we have enabled almost 1 million students to go to college.
We have brought medical care to older people who were unable to afford it. Three and one-half million Americans have already received treatment under Medicare since July.
We have built a strong economy that has put almost 3 million more Americans on the payrolls in the last year alone.
We have included more than 9 million new workers under a higher minimum wage.
We have launched new training programs to provide job skills for almost 1 million Americans.
We have helped more than a thousand local communities to attack poverty in the neighborhoods of the poor.
We have set out to rebuild our cities on a scale that has never been attempted before.
We have begun to rescue our waters from the menace of pollution and to restore the beauty of our land and our countryside
column2: our cities and our towns.

column1: We have given 1 million young Americans a chance to earn through the Neighborhood Youth Corps--or through Head Start
column2: a chance to learn.

column1: So together we have tried to meet the needs of our people. And
column2: we have succeeded in creating a better life for the many as well as the few. Now we must answer whether our gains shall be the foundations of further progress
column3: or whether they shall be only monuments to what might have been--abandoned now by a people who lacked the will to see their great work through.

column1: I believe that our people do not want to quit--though the task is great
column2: the work hard
column3: often frustrating
column4: and success is a matter not of days or months
column5: but of years--and sometimes it may be even decades.

column1: II.
I have come here tonight to discuss with you five ways of carrying forward the progress of these last 3 years. These five ways concern programs
column2: partnerships
column3: priorities
column4: prosperity
column5: and peace.

column1: First
column2: programs. We must see to it
column3: I think
column4: that these new programs that we have passed work effectively and are administered in the best possible way.

column1: Three years ago we set out to create these new instruments of social progress. This required trial and error--and it has produced both. But as we learn
column2: through success and failure
column3: we are changing our strategy and we are trying to improve our tactics. In the long run
column4: these starts--some rewarding
column5: others inadequate and disappointing--are crucial to success.

column1: One example is the struggle to make life better for the less fortunate among us.
On a similar occasion
column2: at this rostrum in 1949
column3: I heard a great American President
column4: Harry S. Truman
column5: declare this: "The American people have decided that poverty is just as wasteful and just as unnecessary as preventable disease."

column1: Many listened to President Truman that day here in this Chamber
column2: but few understood what was required and did anything about it. The executive branch and the Congress waited 15 long years before ever taking any action on that challenge
column3: as it did on many other challenges that great President presented. And when
column4: 3 years ago
column5: you here in the Congress joined with me in a declaration of war on poverty
column6: then I warned
column7: "It will not be a short or easy struggle--no single weapon...will suffice--but we shall not rest until that war is won."

column1: And I have come here to renew that pledge tonight.
I recommend that we intensify our efforts to give the poor a chance to enjoy and to join in this Nation's progress.
I shall propose certain administrative changes suggested by the Congress--as well as some that we have learned from our own trial and error.
I shall urge special methods and special funds to reach the hundreds of thousands of Americans that are now trapped in the ghettos of our big cities and
column2: through Head Start
column3: to try to reach out to our very young
column4: little children. The chance to learn is their brightest hope and must command our full determination. For learning brings skills; and skills bring jobs; and jobs bring responsibility and dignity
column5: as well as taxes.

column1: This war--like the war in Vietnam--is not a simple one. There is no single battleline which you can plot each day on a chart. The enemy is not easy to perceive
column2: or to isolate
column3: or to destroy. There are mistakes and there are setbacks. But we are moving
column4: and our direction is forward.

column1: This is true with other programs that are making and breaking new ground. Some do not yet have the capacity to absorb well or wisely all the money that could be put into them. Administrative skills and trained manpower are just as vital to their success as dollars. And I believe those skills will come. But it will take time and patience and hard work. Success cannot be forced at a single stroke. So we must continue to strengthen the administration of every program if that success is to come--as we know it must.
We have done much in the space of 2 short years
column2: working together.

column1: I have recommended
column2: and you
column3: the Congress
column4: have approved
column5: 10 different reorganization plans
column6: combining and consolidating many bureaus of this Government
column7: and creating two entirely new Cabinet departments.

column1: I have come tonight to propose that we establish a new department--a Department of Business and Labor.
By combining the Department of Commerce with the Department of Labor and other related agencies
column2: I think we can create a more economical
column3: efficient
column4: and streamlined instrument that will better serve a growing nation.

column1: This is our goal throughout the entire Federal Government. Every program will be thoroughly evaluated Grant-in-aid programs will be improved and simplified as desired by many of our local administrators and our Governors.
Where there have been mistakes
column2: we will try very hard to correct them.

column1: Where there has been progress
column2: we will try to build upon it.

column1: Our second objective is partnership--to create an effective partnership at all levels of government. And I should treasure nothing more than to have that partnership begin between the executive and the Congress.

The 88th and the 89th Congresses passed more social and economic legislation than any two single Congresses in American history. Most of you who were Members of those Congresses voted to pass most of those measures. But your efforts will come to nothing unless it reaches the people.
Federal energy is essential. But it is not enough. Only a total working partnership among Federal
column2: State
column3: and local governments can succeed. The test of that partnership will be the concern of each public organization
column4: each private institution
column5: and each responsible citizen.

column1: Each State
column2: county
column3: and city needs to examine its capacity for government in today's world
column4: as we are examining ours in the executive department
column5: and as I see you are examining yours. Some will need to reorganize and reshape their methods of administration--as we are doing. Others will need to revise their constitutions and their laws to bring them up to date--as we are doing. Above all
column6: I think we must work together and find ways in which the multitudes of small jurisdictions can be brought together more efficiently.

column1: During the past 3 years we have returned to State and local governments about $40 billion in grants-in-aid. This year alone
column2: 70 percent of our Federal expenditures for domestic programs will be distributed through the State and local governments. With Federal assistance
column3: State and local governments by 1970 will be spending close to $110 billion annually. These enormous sums must be used wisely
column4: honestly
column5: and effectively.

column1: We intend to work closely with the States and the localities to do exactly that.
Our third objective is priorities
column2: to move ahead on the priorities that we have established within the resources that are available.

column1: I wish
column2: of course
column3: that we could do all that should be done--and that we could do it now. But the Nation has many commitments and responsibilities which make heavy demands upon our total resources. No administration would more eagerly utilize for these programs all the resources they require than the administration that started them.

column1: So let us resolve
column2: now
column3: to do all that we can
column4: with what we have--knowing that it is far
column5: far more than we have ever done before
column6: and far
column7: far less than our problems will ultimately require.

column1: Let us create new opportunities for our children and our young Americans who need special help.
We should strengthen the Head Start program
column2: begin it for children 3 years old
column3: and maintain its educational momentum by following through in the early years.

column1: We should try new methods of child development and care from the earliest years
column2: before it is too late to correct.

column1: And I will propose these measures to the 90th Congress.
Let us insure that older Americans
column2: and neglected Americans
column3: share in their Nation's progress.

column1: We should raise social security payments by an overall average of 20 percent. That will add $4 billion 100 million to social security payments in the first year. I will recommend that each of the 23 million Americans now receiving payments get an increase of at least 15 percent.
I will ask that you raise the minimum payments by 59 percent--from $44 to $70 a month
column2: and to guarantee a minimum benefit of $100 a month for those with a total of 25 years of coverage. We must raise the limits that retired workers can earn without losing social security income.

column1: We must eliminate by law unjust discrimination in employment because of age.

We should embark upon a major effort to provide self-help assistance to the forgotten in our midst--the American Indians and the migratory farm workers. And we should reach with the hand of understanding to help those who live in rural poverty.
And I will propose these measures to the 90th Congress.
So let us keep on improving the quality of life and enlarging the meaning of justice for all of our fellow Americans.
We should transform our decaying slums into places of decency through the landmark Model Cities program. I intend to seek for this effort
column2: this year
column3: the full amount that you in Congress authorized last year.

column1: We should call upon the genius of private industry and the most advanced technology to help rebuild our great cities.
We should vastly expand the fight for clean air with a total attack on pollution at its sources
column2: and--because air
column3: like water
column4: does not respect manmade boundaries--we should set up "regional airsheds" throughout this great land.

column1: We should continue to carry to every corner of the Nation our campaign for a beautiful America--to clean up our towns
column2: to make them more beautiful
column3: our cities
column4: our countryside
column5: by creating more parks
column6: and more seashores
column7: and more open spaces for our children to play in
column8: and for the generations that come after us to enjoy.

column1: We should continue to seek equality and justice for each citizen--before a jury
column2: in seeking a job
column3: in exercising his civil rights. We should find a solution to fair housing
column4: so that every American
column5: regardless of color
column6: has a decent home of his choice.

column1: We should modernize our Selective Service System. The National Commission on Selective Service will shortly submit its report. I will send you new recommendations to meet our military manpower needs. But let us resolve that this is to be the Congress that made our draft laws as fair and as effective as possible.
We should protect what Justice Brandeis called the "right most valued by civilized men"--the right to privacy. We should outlaw all wiretapping--public and private--wherever and whenever it occurs
column2: except when the security of this Nation itself is at stake--and only then with the strictest governmental safeguards. And we should exercise the full reach of our constitutional powers to outlaw electronic "bugging" and "snooping."

column1: I hope this Congress will try to help me do more for the consumer. We should demand that the cost of credit be clearly and honestly expressed where average citizens can understand it. We should immediately take steps to prevent massive power failures
column2: to safeguard the home against hazardous household products
column3: and to assure safety in the pipelines that carry natural gas across our Nation.

column1: We should extend Medicare benefits that are now denied to 1
column3: 000 permanently and totally disabled Americans under 65 years of age.

column1: We should improve the process of democracy by passing our election reform and financing proposals
column2: by tightening our laws regulating lobbying
column3: and by restoring a reasonable franchise to Americans who move their residences.

column1: We should develop educational television into a vital public resource to enrich our homes
column2: educate our families
column3: and to provide assistance in our classrooms. We should insist that the public interest be fully served through the public's airwaves.

column1: And I will propose these measures to the 90th Congress.
Now we come to a question that weighs very heavily on all our minds--on yours and mine. This Nation must make an all-out effort to combat crime.

The 89th Congress gave us a new start in the attack on crime by passing the Law Enforcement Assistance Act that I recommended. We appointed the National Crime Commission to study crime in America and to recommend the best ways to carry that attack forward.
And while we do not have all the answers
column2: on the basis of its preliminary recommendations we are ready to move.

column1: This is not a war that Washington alone can win. The idea of a national police force is repugnant to the American people. Crime must be rooted out in local communities by local authorities. Our policemen must be better trained
column2: must be better paid
column3: and must be better supported by the local citizens that they try to serve and to protect.

column1: The National Government can and expects to help.
And so I will recommend to the 90th Congress the Safe Streets and Crime Control Act of 1967. It will enable us to assist those States and cities that try to make their streets and homes safer
column2: their police forces better
column3: their corrections systems more effective
column4: and their courts more efficient.

column1: When the Congress approves
column2: the Federal Government will be able to provide a substantial percentage of the cost:

column1: --90 percent of the cost of developing the State and local plans
column2: master plans
column3: to combat crime in their area;

column1: --60 percent of the cost of training new tactical units
column2: developing instant communications and special alarm systems
column3: and introducing the latest equipment and techniques so that they can become weapons in the war on crime;

column1: --50 percent of the cost of building crime laboratories and police academy-type centers so that our citizens can be protected by the best trained and served by the best equipped police to be found anywhere.

We will also recommend new methods to prevent juvenile delinquents from becoming adult delinquents. We will seek new partnerships with States and cities in order to deal with this hideous narcotics problem. And we will recommend strict controls on the sale of firearms.
At the heart of this attack on crime must be the conviction that a free America--as Abraham Lincoln once said--must "let reverence for the laws . . . become the political religion of the Nation."

Our country's laws must be respected. Order must be maintained. And I will support--with all the constitutional powers the President possesses--our Nation's law enforcement officials in their attempt to control the crime and the violence that tear the fabric of our communities.
Many of these priority proposals will be built on foundations that have already been laid. Some will necessarily be small at first
column2: but "every beginning is a consequence." If we postpone this urgent work now
column3: it will simply have to be done later
column4: and later we will pay a much higher price.

column1: Our fourth objective is prosperity
column2: to keep our economy moving ahead
column3: moving ahead steadily and safely.

column1: We have now enjoyed 6 years of unprecedented and rewarding prosperity.
Last year
--Wages were the highest in history--and the unemployment rate
column2: announced yesterday
column3: reached the lowest point in 13 years;

column1: --Total after-tax income of American families rose nearly 5 percent;
--Corporate profits after taxes rose a little more than 5 percent;
--Our gross national product advanced 5.5 percent
column2: to about $740 billion;

column1: --Income per farm went up 6 percent.

Now we have been greatly concerned because consumer prices rose 4.5 percent over the 18 months since we decided to send troops to Vietnam. This was more than we had expected--and the Government tried to do everything that we knew how to do to hold it down. Yet we were not as successful as we wished to be. In the 18 months after we entered World War II
column2: prices rose not 4.5 percent
column3: but 13.5 percent. In the first 18 months after Korea
column4: after the conflict broke out there
column5: prices rose not 4.5 percent
column6: but 11 percent. During those two periods we had OPA price control that the Congress gave us and War Labor Board wage controls.

column1: Since Vietnam we have not asked for those controls and we have tried to avoid imposing them. We believe that we have done better
column2: but we make no pretense of having been successful or doing as well as we wished.

column1: Our greatest disappointment in the economy during 1966 was the excessive rise in interest rates and the tightening of credit. They imposed very severe and very unfair burdens on our home buyers and on our home builders
column2: and all those associated with the home industry.

column1: Last January
column2: and again last September
column3: I recommended fiscal and moderate tax measures to try to restrain the unbalanced pace of economic expansion. Legislatively and administratively we took several billions out of the economy. With these measures
column4: in both instances
column5: the Congress approved most of the recommendations rather promptly.

column1: As 1966 ended
column2: price stability was seemingly being restored. Wholesale prices are lower tonight than they were in August. So are retail food prices. Monetary conditions are also easing. Most interest rates have retreated from their earlier peaks. More money now seems to be available.

column1: Given the cooperation of the Federal Reserve System
column2: which I so earnestly seek
column3: I am confident that this movement can continue. I pledge the American people that I will do everything in a President's power to lower interest rates and to ease money in this country. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board tomorrow morning will announce that it will make immediately available to savings and loan associations an additional $1 billion
column4: and will lower from 6 percent to 5 3/4 percent the interest rate charged on those loans.

column1: We shall continue on a sensible course of fiscal and budgetary policy that we believe will keep our economy growing without new inflationary spirals; that will finance responsibly the needs of our men in Vietnam and the progress of our people at home; that will support a significant improvement in our export surplus
column2: and will press forward toward easier credit and toward lower interest rates.

column1: I recommend to the Congress a surcharge of 6 percent on both corporate and individual income taxes--to last for 2 years or for so long as the unusual expenditures associated with our efforts in Vietnam continue. I will promptly recommend an earlier termination date if a reduction in these expenditures permits it. This surcharge will raise revenues by some $4.5 billion in the first year. For example
column2: a person whose tax payment
column3: the tax he owes
column4: is $1
column6: will pay
column7: under this proposal
column8: an extra $60 over the 12-month period
column9: or $5 a month. The overwhelming majority of Americans who pay taxes today are below that figure and they will pay substantially less than $5 a month. Married couples with two children
column10: with incomes up to $5
column12: will be exempt from this tax--as will single people with an income of up to $1

column1: Now if Americans today still paid the income and excise tax rates in effect when I came into the Presidency
column2: in the year 1964
column3: their annual taxes would have been over $20 billion more than at present tax rates. So this proposal is that while we have this problem and this emergency in Vietnam
column4: while we are trying to meet the needs of our people at home
column5: your Government asks for slightly more than one-fourth of that tax cut each year in order to try to hold our budget deficit in fiscal 1968 within prudent limits and to give our country and to give our fighting men the help they need in this hour of trial.

column1: For fiscal 1967
column2: we estimate the budget expenditures to be $126.7 billion and revenues of $117 billion. That will leave us a deficit this year of $9.7 billion.

column1: For fiscal 1968
column2: we estimate budget expenditures of $135 billion. And with the tax measures recommended
column3: and a continuing strong economy
column4: we estimate revenues will be $126.9 billion. The deficit then will be $8.1 billion.

column1: I will very soon forward all of my recommendations to the Congress. Yours is the responsibility to discuss and to debate them--to approve or modify or reject them.
I welcome your views
column2: as I have welcomed working with you for 30 years as a colleague and as Vice President and President.

column1: I should like to say to the Members of the opposition--whose numbers
column2: if I am not mistaken
column3: seem to have increased somewhat--that the genius of the American political system has always been best expressed through creative debate that offers choices and reasonable alternatives. Throughout our history
column4: great Republicans and Democrats have seemed to understand this. So let there be light and reason in our relations. That is the way to a responsible session and a responsive government.

column1: Let us be remembered as a President and a Congress who tried to improve the quality of life for every American--not just the rich
column2: not just the poor
column3: but every man
column4: woman
column5: and child in this great Nation of ours.

column1: We all go to school--to good schools or bad schools. We all take air into our lungs--clean air or polluted air. We all drink water--pure water or polluted water. We all face sickness someday
column2: and some more often than we wish
column3: and old age as well. We all have a stake in this Great Society--in its economic growth
column4: in reduction of civil strife--a great stake in good government.

column1: We just must not arrest the pace of progress we have established in this country in these years. Our children's children will pay the price if we are not wise enough
column2: and courageous enough
column3: and determined enough to stand up and meet the Nation's needs as well as we can in the time allotted us.

column1: III.
Abroad
column2: as at home
column3: there is also risk in change. But abroad
column4: as at home
column5: there is a greater risk in standing still. No part of our foreign policy is so sacred that it ever remains beyond review. We shall be flexible where conditions in the world change--and where man's efforts can change them for the better.

column1: We are in the midst of a great transition--a transition from narrow nationalism to international partnership; from the harsh spirit of the cold war to the hopeful spirit of common humanity on a troubled and a threatened planet.
In Latin America
column2: the American chiefs of state will be meeting very shortly to give our hemispheric policies new direction.

column1: We have come a long way in this hemisphere since the inter-American effort in economic and social development was launched by the conference at Bogota in 1960 under the leadership of President Eisenhower. The Alliance for Progress moved dramatically forward under President Kennedy. There is new confidence that the voice of the people is being heard; that the dignity of the individual is stronger than ever in this hemisphere
column2: and we are facing up to and meeting many of the hemispheric problems together. In this hemisphere that reform under democracy can be made to happen--because it has happened. So together
column3: I think
column4: we must now move to strike down the barriers to full cooperation among the American nations
column5: and to free the energies and the resources of two great continents on behalf of all of our citizens.

column1: Africa stands at an earlier stage of development than Latin America. It has yet to develop the transportation
column2: communications
column3: agriculture
column4: and
column5: above all
column6: the trained men and women without which growth is impossible. There
column7: too
column8: the job will best be done if the nations and peoples of Africa cooperate on a regional basis. More and more our programs for Africa are going to be directed toward self-help.

column1: The future of Africa is shadowed by unsolved racial conflicts. Our policy will continue to reflect our basic commitments as a people to support those who are prepared to work towards cooperation and harmony between races
column2: and to help those who demand change but reject the fool's gold of violence.

column1: In the Middle East the spirit of good will toward all
column2: unfortunately
column3: has not yet taken hold. An already tortured peace seems to be constantly threatened. We shall try to use our influence to increase the possibilities of improved relations among the nations of that region. We are working hard at that task.

column1: In the great subcontinent of South Asia live more than a sixth of the earth's population. Over the years we--and others--have invested very heavily in capital and food for the economic development of India and Pakistan.
We are not prepared to see our assistance wasted
column2: however
column3: in conflict. It must strengthen their capacity to help themselves. It must help these two nations--both our friends--to overcome poverty
column4: to emerge as self-reliant leaders
column5: and find terms for reconciliation and cooperation.

column1: In Western Europe we shall maintain in NATO an integrated common defense. But we also look forward to the time when greater security can be achieved through measures of arms control and disarmament
column2: and through other forms of practical agreement.

column1: We are shaping a new future of enlarged partnership in nuclear affairs
column2: in economic and technical cooperation
column3: in trade negotiations
column4: in political consultation
column5: and in working together with the governments and peoples of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

column1: The emerging spirit of confidence is precisely what we hoped to achieve when we went to work a generation ago to put our shoulder to the wheel and try to help rebuild Europe. We faced new challenges and opportunities then and there--and we faced also some dangers. But I believe that the peoples on both sides of the Atlantic
column2: as well as both sides of this Chamber
column3: wanted to face them together.

column1: Our relations with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe are also in transition. We have avoided both the acts and the rhetoric of the cold war. When we have differed with the Soviet Union
column2: or other nations
column3: for that matter
column4: I have tried to differ quietly and with courtesy
column5: and without venom.

column1: Our objective is not to continue the cold war
column2: but to end it.

column1: We have reached an agreement at the United Nations on the peaceful uses of outer space.
We have agreed to open direct air flights with the Soviet Union.
We have removed more than 400 nonstrategic items from export control.
We are determined that the Export-Import Bank can allow commercial credits to Poland
column2: Hungary
column3: Bulgaria
column4: and Czechoslovakia
column5: as well as to Romania and Yugoslavia.

column1: We have entered into a cultural agreement with the Soviet Union for another 2 years.
We have agreed with Bulgaria and Hungary to upgrade our legations to embassies.
We have started discussions with international agencies on ways of increasing contacts with Eastern European countries.
This administration has taken these steps even as duty compelled us to fulfill and execute alliances and treaty obligations throughout the world that were entered into before I became President.
So tonight I now ask and urge this Congress to help our foreign and our commercial trade policies by passing an East-West trade bill and by approving our consular convention with the Soviet Union.

The Soviet Union has in the past year increased its long-range missile capabilities. It has begun to place near Moscow a limited antimissile defense. My first responsibility to our people is to assure that no nation can ever find it rational to launch a nuclear attack or to use its nuclear power as a credible threat against us or against our allies.
I would emphasize that that is why an important link between Russia and the United States is in our common interest
column2: in arms control and in disarmament. We have the solemn duty to slow down the arms race between us
column3: if that is at all possible
column4: in both conventional and nuclear weapons and defenses. I thought we were making some progress in that direction the first few months I was in office. I realize that any additional race would impose on our peoples
column5: and on all mankind
column6: for that matter
column7: an additional waste of resources with no gain in security to either side.

column1: I expect in the days ahead to closely consult and seek the advice of the Congress about the possibilities of international agreements bearing directly upon this problem.
Next to the pursuit of peace
column2: the really greatest challenge to the human family is the race between food supply and population increase. That race tonight is being lost.

column1: The time for rhetoric has clearly passed. The time for concerted action is here and we must get on with the job.
We believe that three principles must prevail if our policy is to succeed:
First
column2: the developing nations must give highest priority to food production
column3: including the use of technology and the capital of private enterprise.

column1: Second
column2: nations with food deficits must put more of their resources into voluntary family planning programs.

column1: And third
column2: the developed nations must all assist other nations to avoid starvation in the short run and to move rapidly towards the ability to feed themselves.

column1: Every member of the world community now bears a direct responsibility to help bring our most basic human account into balance.
IV.

I come now finally to Southeast Asia--and to Vietnam in particular. Soon I will submit to the Congress a detailed report on that situation. Tonight I want to just review the essential points as briefly as I can.
We are in Vietnam because the United States of America and our allies are committed by the SEATO Treaty to "act to meet the common danger" of aggression in Southeast Asia.
We are in Vietnam because an international agreement signed by the United States
column2: North Vietnam
column3: and others in 1962 is being systematically violated by the Communists. That violation threatens the independence of all the small nations in Southeast Asia
column4: and threatens the peace of the entire region and perhaps the world.

column1: We are there because the people of South Vietnam have as much right to remain non-Communist--if that is what they choose--as North Vietnam has to remain Communist.
We are there because the Congress has pledged by solemn vote to take all necessary measures to prevent further aggression.
No better words could describe our present course than those once spoken by the great Thomas Jefferson:
It is the melancholy law of human societies to be compelled sometimes to choose a great evil in order to ward off a greater.
We have chosen to fight a limited war in Vietnam in an attempt to prevent a larger war--a war almost certain to follow
column2: I believe
column3: if the Communists succeed in overrunning and taking over South Vietnam by aggression and by force. I believe
column4: and I am supported by some authority
column5: that if they are not checked now the world can expect to pay a greater price to check them later.

column1: That is what our statesmen said when they debated this treaty
column2: and that is why it was ratified 82 to 1 by the Senate many years ago.

column1: You will remember that we stood in Western Europe 20 years ago. Is there anyone in this Chamber tonight who doubts that the course of freedom was not changed for the better because of the courage of that stand?

Sixteen years ago we and others stopped another kind of aggression--this time it was in Korea. Imagine how different Asia might be today if we had failed to act when the Communist army of North Korea marched south. The Asia of tomorrow will be far different because we have said in Vietnam
column2: as we said 16 years ago in Korea: "This far and no further."

column1: I think I reveal no secret when I tell you that we are dealing with a stubborn adversary who is committed to the use of force and terror to settle political questions.
I wish I could report to you that the conflict is almost over. This I cannot do. We face more cost
column2: more loss
column3: and more agony. For the end is not yet. I cannot promise you that it will come this year--or come next year. Our adversary still believes
column4: I think
column5: tonight
column6: that he can go on fighting longer than we can
column7: and longer than we and our allies will be prepared to stand up and resist.

column1: Our men in that area--there are nearly 500
column2: 000 now--have borne well "the burden and the heat of the day." Their efforts have deprived the Communist enemy of the victory that he sought and that he expected a year ago. We have steadily frustrated his main forces. General Westmoreland reports that the enemy can no longer succeed on the battlefield.

column1: So I must say to you that our pressure must be sustained--and will be sustained--until he realizes that the war he started is costing him more than he can ever gain.
I know of no strategy more likely to attain that end than the strategy of "accumulating slowly
column2: but inexorably
column3: every kind of material resource"--of "laboriously teaching troops the very elements of their trade." That
column4: and patience--and I mean a great deal of patience.

column1: Our South Vietnamese allies are also being tested tonight. Because they must provide real security to the people living in the countryside. And this means reducing the terrorism and the armed attacks which kidnaped and killed 26
column2: 900 civilians in the last 32 months
column3: to levels where they can be successfully controlled by the regular South Vietnamese security forces. It means bringing to the villagers an effective civilian government that they can respect
column4: and that they can rely upon and that they can participate in
column5: and that they can have a personal stake in. We hope that government is now beginning to emerge.

column1: While I cannot report the desired progress in the pacification effort
column2: the very distinguished and able Ambassador
column3: Henry Cabot Lodge
column4: reports that South Vietnam is turning to this task with a new sense of urgency. We can help
column5: but only they can win this part of the war. Their task is to build and protect a new life in each rural province.

column1: One result of our stand in Vietnam is already clear.

It is this: The peoples of Asia now know that the door to independence is not going to be slammed shut. They know that it is possible for them to choose their own national destinies--without coercion.

The performance of our men in Vietnam--backed by the American people--has created a feeling of confidence and unity among the independent nations of Asia and the Pacific. I saw it in their faces in the 19 days that I spent in their homes and in their countries. Fear of external Communist conquest in many Asian nations is already subsiding--and with this
column2: the spirit of hope is rising. For the first time in history
column3: a common outlook and common institutions are already emerging.

column1: This forward movement is rooted in the ambitions and the interests of Asian nations themselves. It was precisely this movement that we hoped to accelerate when I spoke at Johns Hopkins in Baltimore in April 1965
column2: and I pledged "a much more massive effort to improve the life of man" in that part of the world
column3: in the hope that we could take some of the funds that we were spending on bullets and bombs and spend it on schools and production.

column1: Twenty months later our efforts have produced a new reality: The doors of the billion dollar Asian Development Bank that I recommended to the Congress
column2: and you endorsed almost unanimously
column3: I am proud to tell you are already open. Asians are engaged tonight in regional efforts in a dozen new directions. Their hopes are high. Their faith is strong. Their confidence is deep.

column1: And even as the war continues
column2: we shall play our part in carrying forward this constructive historic development. As recommended by the Eugene Black mission
column3: and if other nations will join us
column4: I will seek a special authorization from the Congress of $200 million for East Asian regional programs.

column1: We are eager to turn our resources to peace. Our efforts in behalf of humanity I think need not be restricted by any parallel or by any boundary line. The moment that peace comes
column2: as I pledged in Baltimore
column3: I will ask the Congress for funds to join in an international program of reconstruction and development for all the people of Vietnam--and their deserving neighbors who wish our help.

column1: We shall continue to hope for a reconciliation between the people of Mainland China and the world community--including working together in all the tasks of arms control
column2: security
column3: and progress on which the fate of the Chinese people
column4: like their fellow men elsewhere
column5: depends.

column1: We would be the first to welcome a China which decided to respect her neighbors' rights. We would be the first to applaud her were she to apply her great energies and intelligence to improving the welfare of her people. And we have no intention of trying to deny her legitimate needs for security and friendly relations with her neighboring countries.
Our hope that all of this will someday happen rests on the conviction that we
column2: the American people and our allies
column3: will and are going to see Vietnam through to an honorable peace.

column1: We will support all appropriate initiatives by the United Nations
column2: and others
column3: which can bring the several parties together for unconditional discussions of peace--anywhere
column4: any time. And we will continue to take every possible initiative ourselves to constantly probe for peace.

column1: Until such efforts succeed
column2: or until the infiltration ceases
column3: or until the conflict subsides
column4: I think the course of wisdom for this country is that we just must firmly pursue our present course. We will stand firm in Vietnam.
