column1: I think you know that our fighting men there tonight bear the heaviest burden of all. With their lives they serve their Nation. We must give them nothing less than our full support--and we have given them that--nothing less than the determination that Americans have always given their fighting men. Whatever our sacrifice here
column2: even if it is more than $5 a month
column3: it is small compared to their own.

column1: How long it will take I cannot prophesy. I only know that the will of the American people
column2: I think
column3: is tonight being tested.

column1: Whether we can fight a war of limited objectives over a period of time
column2: and keep alive the hope of independence and stability for people other than ourselves; whether we can continue to act with restraint when the temptation to "get it over with" is inviting but dangerous; whether we can accept the necessity of choosing "a great evil in order to ward off a greater"; whether we can do these without arousing the hatreds and the passions that are ordinarily loosed in time of war--on all these questions so much turns.

column1: The answers will determine not only where we are
column2: but "whither we are tending."

column1: A time of testing--yes. And a time of transition. The transition is sometimes slow; sometimes unpopular; almost always very painful; and often quite dangerous.
But we have lived with danger for a long time before
column2: and we shall live with it for a long time yet to come. We know that "man is born unto trouble." We also know that this Nation was not forged and did not survive and grow and prosper without a great deal of sacrifice from a great many men.

column1: For all the disorders that we must deal with
column2: and all the frustrations that concern us
column3: and all the anxieties that we are called upon to resolve
column4: for all the issues we must face with the agony that attends them
column5: let us remember that "those who expect to reap the blessings of freedom must
column6: like men
column7: undergo the fatigues of supporting it."

column1: But let us also count not only our burdens but our blessings--for they are many.
And let us give thanks to the One who governs us all.
Let us draw encouragement from the signs of hope--for they
column2: too
column3: are many.

column1: Let us remember that we have been tested before and America has never been found wanting.
So with your understanding
column2: I would hope your confidence
column3: and your support
column4: we are going to persist--and we are going to succeed.@

column1: Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1968-01-17|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the Congress
column4: and my fellow Americans:

column1: I was thinking as I was walking down the aisle tonight of what Sam Rayburn told me many years ago: The Congress always extends a very warm welcome to the President--as he comes in.
Thank all of you very
column2: very much.

column1: I have come once again to this Chamber--the home of our democracy--to give you
column2: as the Constitution requires
column3: "Information of the State of the Union."

column1: I report to you that our country is challenged
column2: at home and abroad:

column1: --that it is our will that is being tried
column2: not our strength; our sense of purpose
column3: not our ability to achieve a better America;

column1: --that we have the strength to meet our every challenge; the physical strength to hold the course of decency and compassion at home; and the moral strength to support the cause of peace in the world.
And I report to you that I believe
column2: with abiding conviction
column3: that this people--nurtured by their deep faith
column4: tutored by their hard lessons
column5: moved by their high aspirations--have the will to meet the trials that these times impose.

column1: Since I reported to you last January:
--Three elections have been held in Vietnam--in the midst of war and under the constant threat of violence.
--A President
column2: a Vice President
column3: a House and Senate
column4: and village officials have been chosen by popular
column5: contested ballot.

column1: --The enemy has been defeated in battle after battle.
--The number of South Vietnamese living in areas under Government protection tonight has grown by more than a million since January of last year.
These are all marks of progress. Yet:
--The enemy continues to pour men and material across frontiers and into battle
column2: despite his continuous heavy losses.

column1: --He continues to hope that America's will to persevere can be broken. Well--he is wrong. America will persevere. Our patience and our perseverance will match our power. Aggression will never prevail.
But our goal is peace--and peace at the earliest possible moment.
Right now we are exploring the meaning of Hanoi's recent statement. There is no mystery about the questions which must be answered before the bombing is stopped.
We believe that any talks should follow the San Antonio formula that I stated last September
column2: which said:

column1: --The bombing would stop immediately if talks would take place promptly and with reasonable hopes that they would be productive.
--And the other side must not take advantage of our restraint as they have in the past. This Nation simply cannot accept anything less without jeopardizing the lives of our men and of our allies.

If a basis for peace talks can be established on the San Antonio foundations--and it is my hope and my prayer that they can--we would consult with our allies and with the other side to see if a complete cessation of hostilities--a really true cease-fire--could be made the first order of business. I will report at the earliest possible moment the results of these explorations to the American people.

I have just recently returned from a very fruitful visit and talks with His Holiness the Pope and I share his hope--as he expressed it earlier today--that both sides will extend themselves in an effort to bring an end to the war in Vietnam. I have today assured him that we and our allies will do our full part to bring this about.
Since I spoke to you last January
column2: other events have occurred that have major consequences for world peace.

column1: --The Kennedy Round achieved the greatest reduction in tariff barriers in all the history of trade negotiations.
--The nations of Latin America at Punta del Este resolved to move toward economic integration.
--In Asia
column2: the nations from Korea and Japan to Indonesia and Singapore worked behind America's shield to strengthen their economies and to broaden their political cooperation.

column1: --In Africa
column2: from which the distinguished Vice President has just returned
column3: he reports to me that there is a spirit of regional cooperation that is beginning to take hold in very practical ways.

column1: These events we all welcomed. Yet since I last reported to you
column2: we and the world have been confronted by a number of crises:

column1: --During the Arab-Israeli war last June
column2: the hot line between Washington and Moscow was used for the first time in our history. A cease-fire was achieved without a major power confrontation.

column1: Now the nations of the Middle East have the opportunity to cooperate with Ambassador Jarring's U.N. mission and they have the responsibility to find the terms of living together in stable peace and dignity
column2: and we shall do all in our power to help them achieve that result.

column1: --Not far from this scene of conflict
column2: a crisis flared on Cyprus involving two peoples who are America's friends: Greece and Turkey. Our very able representative
column3: Mr. Cyrus Vance
column4: and others helped to ease this tension.

column1: --Turmoil continues on the mainland of China after a year of violent disruption. The radical extremism of their Government has isolated the Chinese people behind their own borders. The United States
column2: however
column3: remains willing to permit the travel of journalists to both our countries; to undertake cultural and educational exchanges; and to talk about the exchange of basic food crop materials.

column1: Since I spoke to you last
column2: the United States and the Soviet Union have taken several important steps toward the goal of international cooperation.

column1: As you will remember
column2: I met with Chairman Kosygin at Glassboro and we achieved if not accord
column3: at least a clearer understanding of our respective positions after 2 days of meeting.

column1: Because we believe the nuclear danger must be narrowed
column2: we have worked with the Soviet Union and with other nations to reach an agreement that will halt the spread of nuclear weapons. On the basis of communications from Ambassador Fisher in Geneva this afternoon
column3: I am encouraged to believe that a draft treaty can be laid before the conference in Geneva in the very near future. I hope to be able to present that treaty to the Senate this year for the Senate's approval.

column1: We achieved
column3: a consular treaty with the Soviets
column4: the first commercial air agreement between the two countries
column5: and a treaty banning weapons in outer space. We shall sign
column6: and submit to the Senate shortly
column7: a new treaty with the Soviets and with others for the protection of astronauts.

column1: Serious differences still remain between us
column2: yet in these relations
column3: we have made some progress since Vienna
column4: the Berlin Wall
column5: and the Cuban missile crisis.

column1: But despite this progress
column2: we must maintain a military force that is capable of deterring any threat to this Nation's security
column3: whatever the mode of aggression. Our choices must not be confined to total war--or to total acquiescence.

column1: We have such a military force today. We shall maintain it.
I wish--with all of my heart--that the expenditures that are necessary to build and to protect our power could all be devoted to the programs of peace. But until world conditions permit
column2: and until peace is assured
column3: America's might--and America's bravest sons who wear our Nation's uniform--must continue to stand guard for all of us--as they gallantly do tonight in Vietnam and other places in the world.

column1: Yet neither great weapons nor individual courage can provide the conditions of peace.
For two decades America has committed itself against the tyranny of want and ignorance in the world that threatens the peace. We shall sustain that commitment.
This year I shall propose:
--That we launch
column2: with other nations
column3: an exploration of the ocean depths to tap its wealth
column4: and its energy
column5: and its abundance.

column1: --That we contribute our fair share to a major expansion of the International Development Association
column2: and to increase the resources of the Asian Development Bank.

column1: --That we adopt a prudent aid program
column2: rooted in the principle of self-help.

column1: --That we renew and extend the food for freedom program.
Our food programs have already helped millions avoid the horrors of famine.
But unless the rapid growth of population in developing countries is slowed
column2: the gap between rich and poor will widen steadily.

column1: Governments in the developing countries must take such facts into consideration. We in the United States are prepared to help assist them in those efforts.

But we must also improve the lives of children already born in the villages and towns and cities on this earth. They can be taught by great teachers through space communications and the miracle of satellite television--and we are going to bring to bear every resource of mind and technology to help make this dream come true.
Let me speak now about some matters here at home.

Tonight our Nation is accomplishing more for its people than has ever been accomplished before. Americans are prosperous as men have never been in recorded history. Yet there is in the land a certain restlessness--a questioning.
The total of our Nation's annual production is now above $800 billion. For 83 months this Nation has been on a steady upward trend of growth.
All about them
column2: most American families can see the evidence of growing abundance: higher paychecks
column3: humming factories
column4: new cars moving down new highways. More and more families own their own homes
column5: equipped with more than 70 million television sets.

column1: A new college is founded every week. Today more than half of the high school graduates go on to college.
There are hundreds of thousands of fathers and mothers who never completed grammar school--who will see their children graduate from college.
Why
column2: then
column3: this restlessness?

column1: Because when a great ship cuts through the sea
column2: the waters are always stirred and troubled.

column1: And our ship is moving. It is moving through troubled and new waters; it is moving toward new and better shores.
We ask now
column2: not how can we achieve abundance?--but how shall we use our abundance? Not
column3: is there abundance enough for all?--but
column4: how can all share in our abundance?

column1: While we have accomplished much
column2: much remains for us to meet and much remains for us to master.

column1: --In some areas
column2: the jobless rate is still three or four times the national average.

column1: --Violence has shown its face in some of our cities.
--Crime increases on our streets.
--Income for farm workers remains far behind that for urban workers; and parity for our farmers who produce our food is still just a hope--not an achievement.
--New housing construction is far less than we need--to assure decent shelter for every family.
--Hospital and medical costs are high
column2: and they are rising.

column1: --Many rivers--and the air in many cities--remain badly polluted. And our citizens suffer from breathing that air.
We have lived with conditions like these for many
column2: many years. But much that we once accepted as inevitable
column3: we now find absolutely intolerable.

column1: In our cities last summer
column2: we saw how wide is the gulf for some Americans between the promise and the reality of our society.

column1: We know that we cannot change all of this in a day. It represents the bitter consequences of more than three centuries.
But the issue is not whether we can change this; the issue is whether we will change this.
Well
column2: I know we can. And I believe we will.

column1: This then is the work we should do in the months that are ahead of us in this Congress.
The first essential is more jobs
column2: useful jobs for tens of thousands who can become productive and can pay their own way.

column1: Our economy has created 7 1/2 million new jobs in the past 4 years. It is adding more than a million and a half new jobs this year.
Through programs passed by the Congress
column2: job training is being given tonight to more than a million Americans in this country.

column1: This year
column2: the time has come when we must get to those who are last in line--the hard-core unemployed--the hardest to reach.

column1: Employment officials estimate that 500
column2: 000 of these persons are now unemployed in the major cities of America. Our objective is to place these 500
column3: 000 in private industry jobs within the next 3 years.

column1: To do this
column2: I propose a $2.1 billion manpower program in the coming fiscal year--a 25 percent increase over the current year. Most of this increase will be used to start a new partnership between government and private industry to train and to hire the hard-core unemployed persons. I know of no task before us of more importance to us
column3: to the country
column4: or to our future.

column1: Another essential is to rebuild our cities.

Last year the Congress authorized $662 million for the Model Cities program. I requested the full amount of that authorization to help meet the crisis in the cities of America. But the Congress appropriated only $312 million--less than half.
This year I urge the Congress to honor my request for model cities funds to rebuild the centers of American cities by granting us the full amount that you in the Congress authorized--$1 billion.
The next essential is more housing--and more housing now.
Surely a nation that can go to the moon can place a decent home within the reach of its families.
Therefore we must call together the resources of industry and labor
column2: to start building 300
column3: 000 housing units for low- and middle-income families next year--that is three times more than this year. We must make it possible for thousands of families to become homeowners
column4: not rent-payers.

column1: I propose
column2: for the consideration of this Congress
column3: a 10-year campaign to build 6 million new housing units for low- and middle-income families. Six million units in the next 10 years. We have built 530
column4: 000 the last 10 years.

column1: Better health for our children--all of our children--is essential if we are to have a better America.
Last year
column2: Medicare
column3: Medicaid
column4: and other new programs that you passed in the Congress brought better health to more than 25 million Americans.

column1: American medicine--with the very strong support and cooperation of public resources-has produced a phenomenal decline in the death rate from many of the dread diseases.
But it is a shocking fact that
column2: in saving the lives of babies
column3: America ranks 15th among the nations of the world. And among children
column4: crippling defects are often discovered too late for any corrective action. This is a tragedy that Americans can
column5: and Americans should
column6: prevent.

column1: I shall
column2: therefore
column3: propose to the Congress a child health program to provide
column4: over the next 5 years
column5: for families unable to afford it--access to health services from prenatal care of the mother through the child's first year.

column1: When we do that you will find it is the best investment we ever made because we will get these diseases in their infancy and we will find a cure in a great many instances that we can never find by overcrowding our hospitals when they are grown.
Now when we act to advance the consumer's cause I think we help every American.
Last year
column2: with very little fanfare the Congress and the executive branch moved in that field.

column1: We enacted the Wholesome Meat Act
column2: the Flammable Fabrics Act
column3: the Product Safety Commission
column4: and a law to improve clinical laboratories.

column1: And now
column2: I think
column3: the time has come to complete our unfinished work. The Senate has already passed the truth-in-lending bill
column4: the fire safety bill
column5: and the pipeline safety laws.

column1: Tonight I plead with the House to immediately act upon these measures and I hope take favorable action upon all of them. I call upon the Congress to enact
column2: without delay
column3: the remainder of the 12 vital consumer protection laws that I submitted to the Congress last year.

column1: I also urge final action on a measure that is already passed by the House to guard against fraud and manipulation in the Nation's commodity exchange market.
These measures are a pledge to our people--to keep them safe in their homes and at work
column2: and to give them a fair deal in the marketplace.

column1: And I think we must do more. I propose:
--New powers for the Federal Trade Commission to stop those who defraud and who swindle our public.
--New safeguards to insure the quality of fish and poultry
column2: and the safety of our community water supplies.

column1: --A major study of automobile insurance.
--Protection against hazardous radiation from television sets and other electronic equipment.
And to give the consumer a stronger voice
column2: I plan to appoint a consumer counsel in the Justice Department--a lawyer for the American consumer--to work directly under the Attorney General
column3: to serve the President's Special Assistant for Consumer Affairs
column4: and to serve the consumers of this land.

column1: This Congress--Democrats and Republicans--can earn the thanks of history. We can make this truly a new day for the American consumer
column2: and by giving him this protection we can live in history as the consumer-conscious Congress.

column1: So let us get on with the work. Let us act soon.
We
column2: at every level of the government
column3: State
column4: local
column5: Federal
column6: know that the American people have had enough of rising crime and lawlessness in this country.

column1: They recognize that law enforcement is first the duty of local police and local government.
They recognize that the frontline headquarters against crime is in the home
column2: the church
column3: the city hall and the county courthouse and the statehouse--not in the far-removed National Capital of Washington.

column1: But the people also recognize that the National Government can and the National Government should help the cities and the States in their war on crime to the full extent of its resources and its constitutional authority. And this we shall do.
This does not mean a national police force. It does mean help and financial support:
--to develop State and local master plans to combat crime
--to provide better training and better pay for police
column2: and

column1: --to bring the most advanced technology to the war on crime in every city and every county in America.

There is no more urgent business before this Congress than to pass the Safe Streets Act this year that I proposed last year. That law will provide these required funds. They are so critically needed that I have doubled my request under this act to $100 million in fiscal 1969.
And I urge the Congress to stop the trade in mail-order murder
column2: to stop it this year by adopting a proper gun control law.

column1: This year
column2: I will propose a Drug Control Act to provide stricter penalties for those who traffic in LSD and other dangerous drugs with our people.

column1: I will ask for more vigorous enforcement of all of our drug laws by increasing the number of Federal drug and narcotics control officials by more than 30 percent. The time has come to stop the sale of slavery to the young. I also request you to give us funds to add immediately 100 assistant United States attorneys throughout the land to help prosecute our criminal laws. We have increased our judiciary by 40 percent and we have increased our prosecutors by 16 percent. The dockets are full of cases because we don't have assistant district attorneys to go before the Federal judge and handle them. We start these young lawyers at $8
column2: 200 a year. And the docket is clogged because we don't have authority to hire more of them.

column1: I ask the Congress for authority to hire 100 more. These young men will give special attention to this drug abuse
column2: too.

column1: Finally
column2: I ask you to add 100 FBI agents to strengthen law enforcement in the Nation and to protect the individual rights of every citizen.

column1: A moment ago I spoke of despair and frustrated hopes in the cities where the fires of disorder burned last summer. We can--and in time we will--change that despair into confidence
column2: and change those frustrations into achievements. But violence will never bring progress.

column1: We can make progress only by attacking the causes of violence and only where there is civil order founded on justice.
Today we are helping local officials improve their capacity to deal promptly with disorders.
Those who preach disorder and those who preach violence must know that local authorities are able to resist them swiftly
column2: to resist them sternly
column3: and to resist them decisively.

column1: I shall recommend other actions:
--To raise the farmers' income by establishing a security commodity reserve that will protect the market from price-depressing stocks and protect the consumer from food scarcity.
--I shall recommend programs to help farmers bargain more effectively for fair prices.
--I shall recommend programs for new air safety measures.
--Measures to stem the rising costs of medical care.
--Legislation to encourage our returning veterans to devote themselves to careers in community service such as teaching
column2: and being firemen
column3: and joining our police force
column4: and our law enforcement officials.

column1: --I shall recommend programs to strengthen and finance our anti-pollution efforts.
--Fully funding all of the $2.18 billion poverty program that you in the Congress had just authorized in order to bring opportunity to those who have been left far behind.
--I shall recommend an Educational Opportunity Act to speed up our drive to break down the financial barriers that are separating our young people from college.
I shall also urge the Congress to act on several other vital pending bills--especially the civil rights measures--fair jury trials
column2: protection of Federal rights
column3: enforcement of equal employment opportunity
column4: and fair housing.

column1: The unfinished work of the first session must be completed--the Higher Education Act
column2: the Juvenile Delinquency Act
column3: conservation measures to save the redwoods of California
column4: and to preserve the wonders of our scenic rivers
column5: the Highway Beautification Act--and all the other measures for a cleaner
column6: and for a better
column7: and for a more beautiful America.

column1: Next month we'll begin our 8th year of uninterrupted prosperity. The economic outlook for this year is one of steady growth--if we are vigilant.
True
column2: there are some clouds on the horizon. Prices are rising. Interest rates have passed the peak of 1966; and if there is continued inaction on the tax bill
column3: they will climb even higher.

column1: I warn the Congress and the Nation tonight that this failure to act on the tax bill will sweep us into an accelerating spiral of price increases
column2: a slump in homebuilding
column3: and a continuing erosion of the American dollar.

column1: This would be a tragedy for every American family. And I predict that if this happens
column2: they will all let us know about it.

column1: We--those of us in the executive branch
column2: in the Congress
column3: and the leaders of labor and business--must do everything we can to prevent that kind of misfortune.

column1: Under the new budget
column2: the expenditures for 1969 will increase by $10.4 billion. Receipts will increase by $22.3 billion including the added tax revenues. Virtually all of this expenditure increase represents the mandatory cost of our defense efforts
column3: $3 billion; increased interest
column4: almost $1 billion; or mandatory payments under laws passed by Congress--such as those provided in the Social Security Act that you passed in 1967
column5: and to Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries
column6: veterans
column7: and farmers
column8: of about $4 1/2 billion; and the additional $1 billion 600 million next year for the pay increases that you passed in military and civilian pay. That makes up the $10 billion that is added to the budget. With few exceptions
column9: very few
column10: we are holding the fiscal 1969 budget to last year's level
column11: outside of those mandatory and required increases.

column1: A Presidential commission composed of distinguished congressional fiscal leaders and other prominent Americans recommended this year that we adopt a new budget approach. I am carrying out their recommendations in this year's budget. This budget
column2: therefore
column3: for the first time accurately covers all Federal expenditures and all Federal receipts
column4: including for the first time in one budget $47 billion from the social security
column5: Medicare
column6: highway
column7: and other trust funds.

column1: The fiscal 1969 budget has expenditures of approximately $186 billion
column2: with total estimated revenues
column3: including the tax bill
column4: of about $178 billion.

column1: If the Congress enacts the tax increase
column2: we will reduce the budget deficit by some $12 billion. The war in Vietnam is costing us about $25 billion and we are asking for about $12 billion in taxes--and if we get that $12 billion tax bill we will reduce the deficit from about $20 billion in 1968 to about $8 billion in 1969.

column1: Now
column2: this is a tight budget. It follows the reduction that I made in cooperation with the Congress--a reduction made after you had reviewed every appropriations bill and reduced the appropriations by some $5 or $6 billion and expenditures by $1.5 billion. We conferred together and I recommended to the Congress and you subsequently approved taking 2 percent from payrolls and 10 percent from controllable expenditures. We therefore reduced appropriations almost $10 billion last session and expenditures over $4 billion. Now
column3: that was in the budget last year.

column1: I ask the Congress to recognize that there are certain selected programs that meet the Nation's most urgent needs and they have increased. We have insisted that decreases in very desirable but less urgent programs be made before we would approve any increases.
So I ask the Congress tonight:
--to hold its appropriations to the budget requests
column2: and

column1: --to act responsibly early this year by enacting the tax surcharge which for the average American individual amounts to about a penny out of each dollar's income.
This tax increase would yield about half of the $23 billion per year that we returned to the people in the tax reduction bills of 1964 and 1965.
This must be a temporary measure
column2: which expires in less than 2 years. Congress can repeal it sooner if the need has passed. But Congress can never repeal inflation.

column1: The leaders of American business and the leaders of American labor--those who really have power over wages and prices--must act responsibly
column2: and in their Nation's interest by keeping increases in line with productivity. If our recognized leaders do not do this
column3: they and those for whom they speak and all of us are going to suffer very serious consequences.

column1: On January 1st
column2: I outlined a program to reduce our balance of payments deficit sharply this year. We will ask the Congress to help carry out those parts of the program which require legislation. We must restore equilibrium to our balance of payments.

column1: We must also strengthen the international monetary system. We have assured the world that America's full gold stock stands behind our commitment to maintain the price of gold at $35 an ounce. We must back this commitment by legislating now to free our gold reserves.
Americans
column2: traveling more than any other people in history
column3: took $4 billion out of their country last year in travel costs. We must try to reduce the travel deficit that we have of more than $2 billion. We are hoping that we can reduce it by $500 million--without unduly penalizing the travel of teachers
column4: students
column5: business people who have essential and necessary travel
column6: or people who have relatives abroad whom they want to see. Even with this reduction of $500 million
column7: the American people will still be traveling more overseas than they did in 1967
column9: or 1965 or any other year in their history.

column1: If we act together as I hope we can
column2: I believe we can continue our economic expansion which has already broken all past records. And I hope that we can continue that expansion in the days ahead.

column1: Each of these questions I have discussed with you tonight is a question of policy for our people. Therefore
column2: each of them should be--and doubtless will be--debated by candidates for public office this year.

column1: I hope those debates will be marked by new proposals and by a seriousness that matches the gravity of the questions themselves.
These are not appropriate subjects for narrow partisan oratory. They go to the heart of what we Americans are all about--all of us
column2: Democrats and Republicans.

column1: Tonight I have spoken of some of the goals I should like to see America reach. Many of them can be achieved this year--others by the time we celebrate our Nation's 200th birthday--the bicentennial of our independence.

Several of these goals are going to be very hard to reach. But the State of our Union will be much stronger 8 years from now on our 200th birthday if we resolve to reach these goals now. They are more important--much more important--than the identity of the party or the President who will then be in office.
These goals are what the fighting and our alliances are really meant to protect.
Can we achieve these goals?
Of course we can--if we will.
If ever there was a people who sought more than mere abundance
column2: it is our people.

column1: If ever there was a nation that was capable of solving its problems
column2: it is this Nation.

column1: If ever there were a time to know the pride and the excitement and the hope of being an American--it is this time.
So this
column2: my friends
column3: is the State of our Union: seeking
column4: building
column5: tested many times in this past year--and always equal to the test.

column1: Thank you and good night.@
Lyndon B. Johnson|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1969-01-14|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: Members of the Congress and my fellow
column4: Americans:

column1: For the sixth and the last time
column2: I present to the Congress my assessment of the State of the Union.

column1: I shall speak to you tonight about challenge and opportunity--and about the commitments that all of us have made together that will
column2: if we carry them out
column3: give America our best chance to achieve the kind of great society that we all want.

column1: Every President lives
column2: not only with what is
column3: but with what has been and what could be.

column1: Most of the great events in his Presidency are part of a larger sequence extending back through several years and extending back through several other administrations.
Urban unrest
column2: poverty
column3: pressures on welfare
column4: education of our people
column5: law enforcement and law and order
column6: the continuing crisis in the Middle East
column7: the conflict in Vietnam
column8: the dangers of nuclear war
column9: the great difficulties of dealing with the Communist powers
column10: all have this much in common: They and their causes--the causes that gave rise to them--all of these have existed with us for many years. Several Presidents have already sought to try to deal with them. One or more Presidents will try to resolve them or try to contain them in the years that are ahead of us.

column1: But if the Nation's problems are continuing
column2: so are this great Nation's assets:

column1: --our economy
--the democratic system
--our sense of exploration
column2: symbolized most recently by the wonderful flight of the Apollo 8
column3: in which all Americans took great pride

column1: --the good commonsense and sound judgment of the American people
column2: and

column1: --their essential love of justice.

We must not ignore our problems. But neither should we ignore our strengths. Those strengths are available to sustain a President of either party--to support his progressive efforts both at home and overseas.
Unfortunately
column2: the departure of an administration does not mean the end of the problems that this administration has faced. The effort to meet the problems must go on
column3: year after year
column4: if the momentum that we have all mounted together in these past years is not to be lost.

column1: Although the struggle for progressive change is continuous
column2: there are times when a watershed is reached--when there is--if not really a break with the past--at least the fulfillment of many of its oldest hopes
column3: and a stepping forth into a new environment
column4: to seek new goals.

column1: I think the past 5 years have been such a time.
We have finished a major part of the old agenda.
Some of the laws that we wrote have already
column2: in front of our eyes
column3: taken on the flesh of achievement.

column1: Medicare that we were unable to pass for so many years is now a part of American life.
Voting rights and the voting booth that we debated so long back in the fifties
column2: and the doors to public service
column3: are open at last to all Americans regardless of their color.

column1: Schools and school children all over America tonight are receiving Federal assistance to go to good schools.
Preschool education--Head Start--is already here to stay and
column2: I think
column3: so are the Federal programs that tonight are keeping more than a million and a half of the cream of our young people in the colleges and the universities of this country.

column1: Part of the American earth--not only in description on a map
column2: but in the reality of our shores
column3: our hills
column4: our parks
column5: our forests
column6: and our mountains--has been permanently set aside for the American public and for their benefit. And there is more that will be set aside before this administration ends.

column1: Five million Americans have been trained for jobs in new Federal programs.

I think it is most important that we all realize tonight that this Nation is close to full employment--with less unemployment than we have had at any time in almost 20 years. That is not in theory; that is in fact. Tonight
column2: the unemployment rate is down to 3.3 percent. The number of jobs has grown more than 8 1/2 million in the last 5 years. That is more than in all the preceding 12 years.

column1: These achievements completed the full cycle
column2: from idea to enactment and
column3: finally
column4: to a place in the lives of citizens all across this country.

column1: I wish it were possible to say that everything that this Congress and the administration achieved during this period had already completed that cycle. But a great deal of what we have committed needs additional funding to become a tangible realization.
Yet the very existence of these commitments--these promises to the American people
column2: made by this Congress and by the executive branch of the Government--are achievements in themselves
column3: and failure to carry through on our commitments would be a tragedy for this Nation.

column1: This much is certain: No one man or group of men made these commitments alone. Congress and the executive branch
column2: with their checks and balances
column3: reasoned together and finally wrote them into the law of the land. They now have all the moral force that the American political system can summon when it acts as one.

column1: They express America's common determination to achieve goals. They imply action.
In most cases
column2: you have already begun that action--but it is not fully completed
column3: of course.

column1: Let me speak for a moment about these commitments. I am going to speak in the language which the Congress itself spoke when it passed these measures.
I am going to quote from your words.

column2: Congress declared that "improving the quality of urban life is the most critical domestic problem facing the United States." Two years later it affirmed the historic goal of "a decent home . . . for every American family." That is your language.

column1: Now to meet these commitments
column2: we must increase our support for the model cities program
column3: where blueprints of change are already being prepared in more than 150 American cities

column1: To achieve the goals of the Housing Act of 1968 that you have already passed
column2: we should begin this year more than 500
column3: 000 homes for needy families in the coming fiscal year. Funds are provided in the new budget to do just this. This is almost 10 times--10 times--the average rate of the past 10 years.

column1: Our cities and our towns are being pressed for funds to meet the needs of their growing populations. So I believe an urban development bank should be created by the Congress. This bank could obtain resources through the issuance of taxable bonds and it could then lend these resources at reduced rates to the communities throughout the land for schools
column2: hospitals
column3: parks
column4: and other public facilities.

column1: Since we enacted the Social Security Act back in 1935
column2: Congress has recognized the necessity to "make more adequate provision for aged persons . . . through maternal and child welfare . . . and public health." Those are the words of the Congress--"more adequate."

column1: The time has come
column2: I think
column3: to make it more adequate. I believe we should increase social security benefits
column4: and I am so recommending tonight.

column1: I am suggesting that there should be an overall increase in benefits of at least 13 percent. Those who receive only the minimum of $55 should get $80 a month.
Our Nation
column2: too
column3: is rightfully proud of our medical advances. But we should remember that our country ranks 15th among the nations of the world in its infant mortality rate.

column1: I think we should assure decent medical care for every expectant mother and for their children during the first year of their life in the United States of America.
I think we should protect our children and their families from the costs of catastrophic illness.
As we pass on from medicine
column2: I think nothing is clearer to the Congress than the commitment that the Congress made to end poverty. Congress expressed it well
column3: I think
column5: when they said: "It is the policy of the United States to eliminate the paradox of poverty in the midst of plenty in this nation."

column1: This is the richest nation in the world. The antipoverty program has had many achievements. It also has some failures. But we must not cripple it after only 3 years of trying to solve the human problems that have been with us and have been building up among us for generations.
I believe the Congress this year will want to improve the administration of the poverty program by reorganizing portions of it and transferring them to other agencies. I believe
column2: though
column3: it will want to continue
column4: until we have broken the back of poverty
column5: the efforts we are now making throughout this land.

column1: I believe
column2: and I hope the next administration--I believe they believe--that the key to success in this effort is jobs. It is work for people who want to work.

column1: In the budget for fiscal 1970
column2: I shall recommend a total of $3.5 billion for our job training program
column3: and that is five times as much as we spent in 1964 trying to prepare Americans where they can work to earn their own living.

column1: The Nation's commitment in the field of civil rights began with the Declaration of Independence. They were extended by the 13th
column2: 14th
column3: and 15th amendments. They have been powerfully strengthened by the enactment of three far-reaching civil rights laws within the past 5 years
column4: that this Congress
column5: in its wisdom
column6: passed.

column1: On January 1 of this year
column2: the Fair Housing Act of 1968 covered over 20 million American homes and apartments. The prohibition against racial discrimination in that act should be remembered and it should be vigorously enforced throughout this land.

column1: I believe we should also extend the vital provisions of the Voting Rights Act for another 5 years.
In the Safe Streets Act of 1968
column2: Congress determined "To assist state and local governments in reducing the incidence of crime."

column1: This year I am proposing that the Congress provide the full $300 million that the Congress last year authorized to do just that.
I hope the Congress will put the money where the authorization is.

I believe this is an essential contribution to justice and to public order in the United States. I hope these grants can be made to the States and they can be used effectively to reduce the crime rate in this country.

But all of this is only a small part of the total effort that must be made--I think chiefly by the local governments throughout the Nation--if we expect to reduce the toll of crime that we all detest.
Frankly
column2: as I leave the Office of the Presidency
column3: one of my greatest disappointments is our failure to secure passage of a licensing and registration act for firearms. I think if we had passed that act
column4: it would have reduced the incidence of crime. I believe that the Congress should adopt such a law
column5: and I hope that it will at a not too distant date.

column1: In order to meet our long-standing commitment to make government as efficient as possible
column2: I believe that we should reorganize our postal system along the lines of the Kappel1 report.

column1: I hope we can all agree that public service should never impose an unreasonable financial sacrifice on able men and women who want to serve their country.
I believe that the recommendations of the Commission on Executive
column2: Legislative and Judicial Salaries are generally sound. Later this week
column3: I shall submit a special message which I reviewed with the leadership this evening containing a proposal that has been reduced and has modified the Commission's recommendation to some extent on the congressional salaries.

column1: For Members of Congress
column2: I will recommend the basic compensation not of the $50
column3: 000 unanimously recommended by the Kappel Commission and the other distinguished Members
column4: but I shall reduce that $50
column6: 500. I will suggest that Congress appropriate a very small additional allowance for official expenses
column7: so that Members will not be required to use their salary increase for essential official business.

column1: I would have submitted the Commission's recommendations
column2: except the advice that I received from the leadership--and you usually are consulted about matters that affect the Congress--was that the Congress would not accept the $50
column3: 000 recommendation
column4: and if I expected my recommendation to be seriously considered
column5: I should make substantial reductions. That is the only reason I didn't go along with the Kappel report.

column1: In 1967 I recommended to the Congress a fair and impartial random selection system for the draft. I submit it again tonight for your most respectful consideration.

I know that all of us recognize that most of the things we do to meet all of these commitments I talk about will cost money. If we maintain the strong rate of growth that we have had in this country for the past 8 years
column2: I think we shall generate the resources that we need to meet these commitments.

column1: We have already been able to increase our support for major social programs--although we have heard a lot about not being able to do anything on the home front because of Vietnam; but we have been able in the last 5 years to increase our commitments for such things as health and education from $30 billion in 1964 to $68 billion in the coming fiscal year. That is more than double. That is more than it has ever been increased in the 188 years of this Republic
column2: notwithstanding Vietnam.

column1: We must continue to budget our resources and budget them responsibly in a way that will preserve our prosperity and will strengthen our dollar.
Greater revenues and the reduced Federal spending required by Congress last year have changed the budgetary picture dramatically since last January when we made our estimates. At that time
column2: you will remember that we estimated we would have a deficit of $8 billion. Well
column3: I am glad to report to you tonight that the fiscal year ending June 30
column5: this June
column6: we are going to have not a deficit
column7: but we are going to have a $2.4 billion surplus.

column1: You will receive the budget tomorrow. The budget for the next fiscal year
column2: that begins July 1--which you will want to examine very carefully in the days ahead--will provide a $3.4 billion surplus.

column1: This budget anticipates the extension of the surtax that Congress enacted last year. I have communicated with the President-elect
column2: Mr. Nixon
column3: in connection with this policy of continuing the surtax for the time being.

column1: I want to tell you that both of us want to see it removed just as soon as circumstances will permit
column2: but the President-elect has told me that he has concluded that until his administration
column3: and this Congress
column4: can examine the appropriation bills
column5: and each item in the budget
column6: and can ascertain that the facts justify permitting the surtax to expire or to be reduced
column7: he
column8: Mr. Nixon
column9: will support my recommendation that the surtax be continued.

column1: Americans
column2: I believe
column3: are united in the hope that the Paris talks will bring an early peace to Vietnam. And if our hopes for an early settlement of the war are realized
column4: then our military expenditures can be reduced and very substantial savings can be made to be used for other desirable purposes
column5: as the Congress may determine.

column1: In any event
column2: I think it is imperative that we do all that we responsibly can to resist inflation while maintaining our prosperity. I think all Americans know that our prosperity is broad and it is deep
column3: and it has brought record profits
column4: the highest in our history
column5: and record wages.

column1: Our gross national product has grown more in the last 5 years than any other period in our Nation's history. Our wages have been the highest. Our profits have been the best. This prosperity has enabled millions to escape the poverty that they would have otherwise had the last few years.
I think also you will be very glad to hear that the Secretary of the Treasury informs me tonight that in 1968 in our balance of payments we have achieved a surplus. It appears that we have
column2: in fact
column3: done better this year than we have done in any year in this regard since the year 1957.

column1: The quest for a durable peace
column2: I think
column3: has absorbed every administration since the end of World War II. It has required us to seek a limitation of arms races not only among the superpowers
column4: but among the smaller nations as well. We have joined in the test ban treaty of 1963
column5: the outer space treaty of 1967
column6: and the treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons in 1968.

column1: This latter agreement--the nonproliferation treaty--is now pending in the Senate and it has been pending there since last July. In my opinion
column2: delay in ratifying it is not going to be helpful to the cause of peace. America took the lead in negotiating this treaty and America should now take steps to have it approved at the earliest possible date.

column1: Until a way can be found to scale down the level of arms among the superpowers
column2: mankind cannot view the future without fear and great apprehension. So
column3: I believe that we should resume the talks with the Soviet Union about limiting offensive and defensive missile systems. I think they would already have been resumed except for Czechoslovakia and our election this year.

column1: It was more than 20 years ago that we embarked on a program of trying to aid the developing nations. We knew then that we could not live in good conscience as a rich enclave on an earth that was seething in misery.
During these years there have been great advances made under our program
column2: particularly against want and hunger
column3: although we are disappointed at the appropriations last year. We thought they were woefully inadequate. This year I am asking for adequate funds for economic assistance in the hope that we can further peace throughout the world.

column1: I think we must continue to support efforts in regional cooperation. Among those efforts
column2: that of Western Europe has a very special place in America's concern.

column1: The only course that is going to permit Europe to play the great world role that its resources permit is to go forward to unity. I think America remains ready to work with a united Europe
column2: to work as a partner on the basis of equality.

column1: For the future
column2: the quest for peace
column3: I believe
column4: requires:

column1: --that we maintain the liberal trade policies that have helped us become the leading nation in world trade
--that we strengthen the international monetary system as an instrument of world prosperity
column2: and

column1: --that we seek areas of agreement with the Soviet Union where the interests of both nations and the interests of world peace are properly served.

The strained relationship between us and the world's leading Communist power has not ended--especially in the light of the brutal invasion of Czechoslovakia. But totalitarianism is no less odious to us because we are able to reach some accommodation that reduces the danger of world catastrophe.
What we do
column2: we do in the interest of peace in the world. We earnestly hope that time will bring a Russia that is less afraid of diversity and individual freedom.

column1: The quest for peace tonight continues in Vietnam
column2: and in the Paris talks.

column1: I regret more than any of you know that it has not been possible to restore peace to South Vietnam.
The prospects
column2: I think
column3: for peace are better today than at any time since North Vietnam began its invasion with its regular forces more than 4 years ago.

column1: The free nations of Asia know what they were not sure of at that time: that America cares about their freedom
column2: and it also cares about America's own vital interests in Asia and throughout the Pacific.

column1: The North Vietnamese know that they cannot achieve their aggressive purposes by force. There may be hard fighting before a settlement is reached; but
column2: I can assure you
column3: it will yield no victory to the Communist cause.

column1: I cannot speak to you tonight about Vietnam without paying a very personal tribute to the men who have carried the battle out there for all of us. I have been honored to be their Commander in Chief. The Nation owes them its unstinting support while the battle continues--and its enduring gratitude when their service is done.
Finally
column2: the quest for stable peace in the Middle East goes on in many capitals tonight. America fully supports the unanimous resolution of the U.N. Security Council which points the way.

column1: There must be a settlement of the armed hostility that exists in that region of the world today. It is a threat not only to Israel and to all the Arab States
column2: but it is a threat to every one of us and to the entire world as well.

column1: Now
column2: my friends in Congress
column3: I want to conclude with a few very personal words to you.

column1: I rejected and rejected and then finally accepted the congressional leadership's invitation to come here to speak this farewell to you in person tonight.
I did that for two reasons. One was philosophical. I wanted to give you my judgment
column2: as I saw it
column3: on some of the issues before our Nation
column4: as I view them
column5: before I leave.

column1: The other was just pure sentimental. Most all of my life as a public official has been spent here in this building. For 38 years--since I worked on that gallery as a doorkeeper in the House of Representatives--I have known these halls
column2: and I have known most of the men pretty well who walked them.

column1: I know the questions that you face. I know the conflicts that you endure. I know the ideals that you seek to serve.
I left here first to become Vice President
column2: and then to become
column3: in a moment of tragedy
column4: the President of the United States.

column1: My term of office has been marked by a series of challenges
column2: both at home and throughout the world.

column1: In meeting some of these challenges
column2: the Nation has found a new confidence. In meeting others
column3: it knew turbulence and doubt
column4: and fear and hate.

column1: Throughout this time
column2: I have been sustained by my faith in representative democracy--a faith that I had learned here in this Capitol Building as an employee and as a Congressman and as a Senator.

column1: I believe deeply in the ultimate purposes of this Nation--described by the Constitution
column2: tempered by history
column3: embodied in progressive laws
column4: and given life by men and women that have been elected to serve their fellow citizens.

column1: Now for 5 most demanding years in the White House
column2: I have been strengthened by the counsel and the cooperation of two great former Presidents
column3: Harry S. Truman and Dwight David Eisenhower. I have been guided by the memory of my pleasant and close association with the beloved John F. Kennedy
column4: and with our greatest modern legislator
column5: Speaker Sam Rayburn.

column1: I have been assisted by my friend every step of the way
column2: Vice President Hubert Humphrey. I am so grateful that I have been supported daily by the loyalty of Speaker McCormack and Majority Leader Albert.

column1: I have benefited from the wisdom of Senator Mike Mansfield
column2: and I am sure that I have avoided many dangerous pitfalls by the good commonsense counsel of the President Pro Tem of the Senate
column3: Senator Richard Brevard Russell.

column1: I have received the most generous cooperation from the leaders of the Republican Party in the Congress of the United States
column2: Senator Dirksen and Congressman Gerald Ford
column3: the Minority Leader.

column1: No President should ask for more
column2: although I did upon occasions. But few Presidents have ever been blessed with so much.

column1: President-elect Nixon
column2: in the days ahead
column3: is going to need your understanding
column4: just as I did. And he is entitled to have it. I hope every Member will remember that the burdens he will bear as our President
column5: will be borne for all of us. Each of us should try not to increase these burdens for the sake of narrow personal or partisan advantage.

column1: Now
column2: it is time to leave. I hope it may be said
column3: a hundred years from now
column4: that by working together we helped to make our country more just
column5: more just for all of its people
column6: as well as to insure and guarantee the blessings of liberty for all of our posterity.

column1: That is what I hope. But I believe that at least it will be said that we tried.@
Richard M. Nixon|Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union|1970-01-22|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. President
column3: my colleagues in the Congress
column4: our distinguished guests and my fellow Americans:

column1: To address a joint session of the Congress in this great Chamber in which I was once privileged to serve is an honor for which I am deeply grateful.
The State of the Union Address is traditionally an occasion for a lengthy and detailed account by the President of what he has accomplished in the past
column2: what he wants the Congress to do in the future
column3: and
column4: in an election year
column5: to lay the basis for the political issues which might be decisive in the fall.

column1: Occasionally there comes a time when profound and far-reaching events command a break with tradition.
This is such a time.

I say this not only because 1970 marks the beginning of a new decade in which America will celebrate its 200th birthday. I say it because new knowledge and hard experience argue persuasively that both our programs and our institutions in America need to be reformed.
The moment has arrived to harness the vast energies and abundance of this land to the creation of a new American experience
column2: an experience richer and deeper and more truly a reflection of the goodness and grace of the human spirit.

column1: The seventies will be a time of new beginnings
column2: a time of exploring both on the earth and in the heavens
column3: a time of discovery. But the time has also come for emphasis on developing better ways of managing what we have and of completing what man's genius has begun but left unfinished.

column1: Our land
column2: this land that is ours together
column3: is a great and a good land. It is also an unfinished land
column4: and the challenge of perfecting it is the summons of the seventies.

column1: It is in that spirit that I address myself to those great issues facing our Nation which are above partisanship.
When we speak of America's priorities the first priority must always be peace for America and the world.
The major immediate goal of our foreign policy is to bring an end to the war in Vietnam in a way that our generation will be remembered not so much as the generation that suffered in war
column2: but more for the fact that we had the courage and character to win the kind of a just peace that the next generation was able to keep.

column1: We are making progress toward that goal.
The prospects for peace are far greater today than they were a year ago.
A major part of the credit for this development goes to the Members of this Congress who
column2: despite their differences on the conduct of the war
column3: have overwhelmingly indicated their support of a just peace. By this action
column4: you have completely demolished the enemy's hopes that they can gain in Washington the victory our fighting men have denied them in Vietnam.

column1: No goal could be greater than to make the next generation the first in this century in which America was at peace with every nation in the world.
I shall discuss in detail the new concepts and programs designed to achieve this goal in a separate report on foreign policy
column2: which I shall submit to the Congress at a later date.

column1: Today
column2: let me describe the directions of our new policies.

column1: We have based our policies on an evaluation of the world as it is
column2: not as it was 25 years ago at the conclusion of World War II. Many of the policies which were necessary and right then are obsolete today.

column1: Then
column2: because of America's overwhelming military and economic strength
column3: because of the weakness of other major free world powers and the inability of scores of newly independent nations to defend
column4: or even govern
column5: themselves
column6: America had to assume the major burden for the defense of freedom in the world.

column1: In two wars
column2: first in Korea and now in Vietnam
column3: we furnished most of the money
column4: most of the arms
column5: most of the men to help other nations defend their freedom.

column1: Today the treat industrial nations of Europe
column2: as well as Japan
column3: have regained their economic strength; and the nations of Latin America and many of the nations who acquired their freedom from colonialism after World War II in Asia and Africa have a new sense of pride and dignity and a determination to assume the responsibility for their own defense.

column1: That is the basis of the doctrine I announced at Guam. 1
Neither the defense nor the development of other nations can be exclusively or primarily an American undertaking.
The nations of each part of the world should assume the primary responsibility for their own well-being; and they themselves should determine the terms of that well-being.
We shall be faithful to our treaty commitments
column2: but we shall reduce our involvement and our presence in other nations' affairs.

column1: To insist that other nations play a role is not a retreat from responsibility; it is a sharing of responsibility.
The result of this new policy has been not to weaken our alliances
column2: but to give them new life
column3: new strength
column4: a new sense of common purpose.

column1: Relations with our European allies are once again strong and healthy
column2: based on mutual consultation and mutual responsibility.

column1: We have initiated a new approach to Latin America in which we deal with those nations as partners rather than patrons.
The new partnership concept has been welcomed in Asia. We have developed a historic new basis for Japanese-American friendship and cooperation
column2: which is the linchpin for peace in the Pacific.

column1: If we are to have peace in the last third of the century
column2: a major factor will be the development of a new relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union.

column1: I would not underestimate our differences
column2: but we are moving with precision and purpose from an era of confrontation to an era of negotiation.

column1: Our negotiations on strategic arms limitations and in other areas will have far greater chance for success if both sides enter them motivated by mutual self-interest rather than na?ve sentimentality.
It is with this same spirit that we have resumed discussions with Communist China in our talks at Warsaw.
Our concern in our relations with both these nations is to avoid a catastrophic collision and to build a solid basis for peaceful settlement of our differences.
I would be the last to suggest that the road to peace is not difficult and dangerous
column2: but I believe our new policies have contributed to the prospect that America may have the best chance since World War II to enjoy a generation of uninterrupted peace. And that chance will be enormously increased if we continue to have a relationship between Congress and the Executive in which
column3: despite differences in detail
column4: where the security of America and the peace of mankind are concerned
column5: we act not as Republicans
column6: not as Democrats
column7: but as Americans.

column1: As we move into the decade of the seventies
column2: we have the greatest opportunity for progress at home of any people in world history.

column1: Our gross national product will increase by $500 billion in the next 10 years. This increase alone is greater than the entire growth of the American economy from 1790 to 1950.
The critical question is not whether we will grow
column2: but how we will use that growth.

column1: The decade of the sixties was also a period of great growth economically. But in that same 10-year period we witnessed the greatest growth of crime
column2: the greatest increase in inflation
column3: the greatest social unrest in America in 100 years. Never has a nation seemed to have had more and enjoyed it less.

column1: At heart
column2: the issue is the effectiveness of government.

column1: Ours has become as it continues to be
column2: and should remain a society of large expectations. Government helped to generate these expectations. It undertook to meet them. Yet
column3: increasingly
column4: it proved unable to do so.

column1: As a people
column2: we had too many visions and too little vision.

column1: Now
column2: as we enter the seventies
column3: we should enter also a great age of reform of the institutions of American government.

column1: Our purpose in this period should not be simply better management of the programs of the past. The time has come for a new quest a quest not for a greater quantity of what we have
column2: but for a new quality of life in America.

column1: A major part of the substance for an unprecedented advance in this Nation's approach to its problems and opportunities is contained in more than two score legislative proposals which I sent to the Congress last year and which still await enactment.
I will offer at least a dozen more major programs in the course of this session.
At this point I do not intend to go through a detailed listing of what I have proposed or will propose
column2: but I would like to mention three areas in which urgent priorities demand that we move and move now:

column1: First
column2: we cannot delay longer in accomplishing a total reform of our welfare system. When a system penalizes work
column3: breaks up homes
column4: robs recipients of dignity
column5: there is no alternative to abolishing that system and adopting in its place the program of income support
column6: job training
column7: and work incentives which I recommended to the Congress last year.

column1: Second
column2: the time has come to assess and reform all of our institutions of government at the Federal
column3: State
column4: and local level. It is time for a New Federalism
column5: in which
column6: after 190 years of power flowing from the people and local and State governments to Washington
column7: D.C.
column8: it will begin to flow from Washington back to the States and to the people of the United States.

column1: Third
column2: we must adopt reforms which will expand the range of opportunities for all Americans. We can fulfill the American dream only when each person has a fair chance to fulfill his own dreams. This means equal voting rights
column3: equal employment opportunity
column4: and new opportunities for expanded ownership. Because in order to be secure in their human rights
column5: people need access to property rights.

column1: I could give similar examples of the need for reform in our programs for health
column2: education
column3: housing
column4: transportation
column5: as well as other critical areas which directly affect the well-being of millions of Americans.

column1: The people of the United States should wait no longer for these reforms that would so deeply enhance the quality of their life.
When I speak of actions which would be beneficial to the American people
column2: I can think of none more important than for the Congress to join this administration in the battle to stop the rise in the cost of living.

column1: Now
column2: I realize it is tempting to blame someone else for inflation.

column1: Some blame business for raising prices.
Some blame unions for asking for more wages.
But a review of the stark fiscal facts of the 1960's clearly demonstrates where the primary blame for rising prices must be placed.
In the decade of the sixties the Federal Government spent $57 billion more than it took in in taxes.
In the same decade the American people paid the bill for that deficit in price increases which raised the cost of living for the average family of four by $200 per month in America.

Now millions of Americans are forced to go into debt today because the Federal Government decided to go into debt yesterday. We must balance our Federal budget so that American families will have a better chance to balance their family budgets.
Only with the cooperation of the Congress can we meet this highest priority objective of responsible government.
We are on the right track.
We had a balanced budget in 1969.
This administration cut more than $7 billion out of spending plans in order to produce a surplus in 1970
column2: and in spite of the fact that Congress reduced revenues by $ 3 billion
column3: I shall recommend a balanced budget for 1971.

column1: But I can assure that not only to present
column2: but to stay within
column3: a balanced budget requires some very hard decisions. It means rejecting spending programs which would benefit some of the people when their net effect would result in price increases for all the people.

column1: It is time to quit putting good money into bad programs. Otherwise
column2: we will end up with bad money and bad programs.

column1: I recognize the political popularity of spending programs
column2: and particularly in an election year. But unless we stop the rise in prices
column3: the cost of living for millions of American families will become unbearable and government's ability to plan programs for progress for the future will become impossible.

column1: In referring to budget cuts
column2: there is one area where I have ordered an increase rather than a cut and that is the requests of those agencies with the responsibilities for law enforcement.

column1: We have heard a great deal of overblown rhetoric during the sixties in which the word war has perhaps too often been used the war on poverty
column2: the war on misery
column3: the war on disease
column4: the war on hunger. But if there is one area where the word war  is appropriate it is in the fight against crime. We must declare and win the war against the criminal elements which increasingly threaten our cities
column5: our homes
column6: and our lives.

column1: We have a tragic example of this problem in the Nation's Capital
column2: for whose safety the Congress and the Executive have the primary responsibility. I doubt if many Members of this Congress who live more than a few blocks from here would dare leave their cars in the Capitol garage and walk home alone tonight.

column1: Last year this administration sent to the Congress 13 separate pieces of legislation dealing with organized crime
column2: pornography
column3: street crime
column4: narcotics
column5: crime in the District of Columbia.

column1: None of these bills has reached my desk for signature.
I am confident that the Congress will act now to adopt the legislation I placed before you last year. We in the Executive have done everything we can under existing law
column2: but new and stronger weapons are needed in that fight.

column1: While it is true that State and local law enforcement agencies are the cutting edge in the effort to eliminate street crime
column2: burglaries
column3: murder
column4: my proposals to you have embodied my belief that the Federal Government should play a greater role in working in partnership with these agencies.

column1: That is why 1971 Federal spending for local law enforcement will double that budgeted for 1970.
The primary responsibility for crimes that affect individuals is with local and State rather than with Federal Government. But in the field of organized crime
column2: narcotics
column3: pornography
column4: the Federal Government has a special responsibility it should fulfill. And we should make Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: where we have the primary responsibility
column7: an example to the Nation and the world of respect for law rather than lawlessness.

column1: I now turn to a subject which
column2: next to our desire for peace
column3: may well become the major concern of the American people in the decade of the seventies.

column1: In the next 10 years we shall increase our wealth by 50 percent. The profound question is: Does this mean we will be 50 percent richer in a real sense
column2: 50 percent better off
column3: 50 percent happier?

column1: Or does it mean that in the year 1980 the President standing in this place will look back on a decade in which 70 percent of our people lived in metropolitan areas chocked by traffic
column2: suffocated by smog
column3: poisoned by water
column4: deafened by noise
column5: and terrorized by crime?

column1: These are not the great questions that concern world leaders at summit conferences. But people do not live at the summit. They live in the foothills of everyday experience
column2: and it is time for all of us to concern ourselves with the way real people live in real life.

column1: The great question of the seventies is
column2: shall we surrender to our surroundings
column3: or shall we make our peace with nature and begin to make reparations for the damage we have done to our air
column4: to our land
column5: and to our water?

column1: Restoring nature to its natural state is a cause beyond party and beyond factions. It has become a common cause of all the people of this country. It is a cause of particular concern to young Americans
column2: because they more than we will reap the grim consequences of our failure to act on programs which are needed now if we are to prevent disaster later.

column1: Clean air
column2: clean water
column3: open spaces these should once again be the birthright of every American. If we act now
column4: they can be.

column1: We still think of air as free. But clean air is not free
column2: and neither is clean water. The price tag on pollution control is high. Through our years of past carelessness we incurred a debt to nature
column3: and now that debt is being called.

column1: The program I shall propose to Congress will be the most comprehensive and costly program in this field in America's history.
It is not a program for just one year. A year's plan in this field is no plan at all. This is a time to look ahead not a year
column2: but 5 years or 10 years whatever time is required to do the job.

column1: I shall propose to this Congress a $10 billion nationwide clean waters program to put modern municipal waste treatment plants in every place in America where they are needed to make our waters clean again
column2: and do it now. We have the industrial capacity
column3: if we begin now
column4: to build them all within 5 years. This program will get them built within 5 years.

column1: As our cities and suburbs relentlessly expand
column2: those priceless open spaces needed for recreation areas accessible to their people are swallowed up often forever. Unless we preserve these spaces while they are still available
column3: we will have none to preserve. Therefore
column4: I shall propose new financing methods for purchasing open space and parklands now
column5: before they are lost to us.

column1: The automobile is our worst polluter of the air. Adequate control requires further advances in engine design and fuel composition. We shall intensify our research
column2: set increasingly strict standards
column3: and strengthen enforcement procedures and we shall do it now.

column1: We can no longer afford to consider air and water common property
column2: free to be abused by anyone without regard to the consequences. Instead
column3: we should begin now to treat them as scarce resources
column4: which we are no more free to contaminate than we are free to throw garbage into our neighbor's yard.

column1: This requires comprehensive new regulations. It also requires that
column2: to the extent possible
column3: the price of goods should be made to include the costs of producing and disposing of them without damage to the environment.

column1: Now
column2: I realize that the argument is often made that there is a fundamental contradiction between economic growth and the quality of life
column3: so that to have one we must forsake the other.

column1: The answer is not to abandon growth
column2: but to redirect it. For example
column3: we should turn toward ending congestion and eliminating smog the same reservoir of inventive genius that created them in the first place.

column1: Continued vigorous economic growth provides us with the means to enrich life itself and to enhance our planet as a place hospitable to man.
Each individual must enlist in this fight if it is to be won.
It has been said that no matter how many national parks and historical monuments we buy and develop
column2: the truly significant environment for each of us is that in which we spend 80 percent of our time in our homes
column3: in our places of work
