column4: and distinguished guests:

column1: As we begin our Bicentennial
column2: America is still one of the youngest nations in recorded history. Long before our forefathers came to these shores
column3: men and women had been struggling on this planet to forge a better life for themselves and their families.

column1: In man's long
column2: upward march from savagery and slavery--throughout the nearly 2
column3: 000 years of the Christian calendar
column4: the nearly 6
column5: 000 years of Jewish reckoning--there have been many deep
column6: terrifying valleys
column7: but also many bright and towering peaks.

column1: One peak stands highest in the ranges of human history. One example shines forth of a people uniting to produce abundance and to share the good life fairly and with freedom. One union holds out the promise of justice and opportunity for every citizen: That union is the United States of America.
We have not remade paradise on Earth. We know perfection will not be found here. But think for a minute how far we have come in 200 years.
We came from many roots
column2: and we have many branches. Yet all Americans across the eight generations that separate us from the stirring deeds of 1776
column3: those who know no other homeland and those who just found refuge among our shores
column4: say in unison:

column1: I am proud of America
column2: and I am proud to be an American. Life will be a little better here for my children than for me. I believe this not because I am told to believe it
column3: but because life has been better for me than it was for my father and my mother. I know it will be better for my children because my hands
column4: my brains
column5: my voice
column6: and my vote can help make it happen.

column1: It has happened here in America. It has happened to you and to me.
Government exists to create and preserve conditions in which people can translate their ideas into practical reality. In the best of times
column2: much is lost in translation. But we try. Sometimes we have tried and failed. Always we have had the best of intentions.

column1: But in the recent past
column2: we sometimes forgot the sound principles that guided us through most of our history. We wanted to accomplish great things and solve age-old problems. And we became overconfident of our abilities. We tried to be a policeman abroad and the indulgent parent here at home.

column1: We thought we could transform the country through massive national programs
column2: but often the programs did not work. Too often they only made things worse. In our rush to accomplish great deeds quickly
column3: we trampled on sound principles of restraint and endangered the rights of individuals. We unbalanced our economic system by the huge and unprecedented growth of Federal expenditures and borrowing. And we were not totally honest with ourselves about how much these programs would cost and how we would pay for them. Finally
column4: we shifted our emphasis from defense to domestic problems while our adversaries continued a massive buildup of arms.

column1: The time has now come for a fundamentally different approach--for a new realism that is true to the great principles upon which this Nation was founded.
We must introduce a new balance to our economy--a balance that favors not only sound
column2: active government but also a much more vigorous
column3: healthy economy that can create new jobs and hold down prices.

column1: We must introduce a new balance in the relationship between the individual and the government--a balance that favors greater individual freedom and self-reliance.
We must strike a new balance in our system of federalism--a balance that favors greater responsibility and freedom for the leaders of our State and local governments.

We must introduce a new balance between the spending on domestic programs and spending on defense--a balance that ensures we will fully meet our obligation to the needy while also protecting our security in a world that is still hostile to freedom.
And in all that we do
column2: we must be more honest with the American people
column3: promising them no more than we can deliver and delivering all that we promise.

column1: The genius of America has been its incredible ability to improve the lives of its citizens through a unique combination of governmental and free citizen activity.
History and experience tells us that moral progress cannot come in comfortable and in complacent times
column2: but out of trial and out of confusion. Tom Paine aroused the troubled Americans of 1776 to stand up to the times that try men's souls because the harder the conflict
column3: the more glorious the triumph.

column1: Just a year ago I reported that the state of the Union was not good. Tonight
column2: I report that the state of our Union is better--in many ways a lot better--but still not good enough.

column1: To paraphrase Tom Paine
column2: 1975 was not a year for summer soldiers and sunshine patriots. It was a year of fears and alarms and of dire forecasts-- most of which never happened and won't happen.

column1: As you recall
column2: the year 1975 opened with rancor and with bitterness. Political misdeeds of the past had neither been forgotten nor forgiven. The longest
column3: most divisive war in our history was winding toward an unhappy conclusion. Many feared that the end of that foreign war of men and machines meant the beginning of a domestic war of recrimination and reprisal. Friends and adversaries abroad were asking whether America had lost its nerve. Finally
column4: our economy was ravaged by inflation--inflation that was plunging us into the worse recession in four decades. At the same time
column5: Americans became increasingly alienated from big institutions. They were steadily losing confidence
column6: not just in big government but in big business
column7: big labor
column8: and big education
column9: among others. Ours was a troubled land.

column1: And so
column2: 1975 was a year of hard decisions
column3: difficult compromises
column4: and a new realism that taught us something important about America. It brought back a needed measure of common sense
column5: steadfastness
column6: and self-discipline.

column1: Americans did not panic or demand instant but useless cures. In all sectors
column2: people met their difficult problems with the restraint and with responsibility worthy of their great heritage.

column1: Add up the separate pieces of progress in 1975
column2: subtract the setbacks
column3: and the sum total shows that we are not only headed in a new direction
column4: a direction which I proposed 12 months ago
column5: but it turned out to be the right direction.

column1: It is the right direction because it follows the truly revolutionary American concept of 1776
column2: which holds that in a free society the making of public policy and successful problemsolving involves much more than government. It involves a full partnership among all branches and all levels of government
column3: private institutions
column4: and individual citizens.

column1: Common sense tells me to stick to that steady course.
Take the state of our economy. Last January
column2: most things were rapidly getting worse. This January
column3: most things are slowly but surely getting better.

column1: The worst recession since World War II turned around in April. The best cost-of-living news of the past year is that double-digit inflation of 12 percent or higher was cut almost in half. The worst--unemployment remains far too high.
Today
column2: nearly 1
column4: 000 more Americans are working than at the bottom of the recession. At year's end
column5: people were again being hired much faster than they were being laid off.

column1: Yet
column2: let's be honest. Many Americans have not yet felt these changes in their daily lives. They still see prices going up far too fast
column3: and they still know the fear of unemployment.

column1: We are also a growing nation. We need more and more jobs every year. Today's economy has produced over 85 million jobs for Americans
column2: but we need a lot more jobs
column3: especially for the young.

column1: My first objective is to have sound economic growth without inflation.
We all know from recent experience what runaway inflation does to ruin every other worthy purpose. We are slowing it. We must stop it cold.
For many Americans
column2: the way to a healthy
column3: noninflationary economy has become increasingly apparent. The Government must stop spending so much and stop borrowing so much of our money. More money must remain in private hands where it will do the most good. To hold down the cost of living
column4: we must hold down the cost of government.

column1: In the past decade
column2: the Federal budget has been growing at an average rate of over 10 percent a year. The budget I am submitting Wednesday cuts this rate of growth in half. I have kept my promise to submit a budget for the next fiscal year of $395 billion. In fact
column3: it is $394.2 billion.

column1: By holding down the growth of Federal spending
column2: we can afford additional tax cuts and return to the people who pay taxes more decisionmaking power over their own lives.

column1: Last month I signed legislation to extend the 1975 tax reductions for the first 6 months of this year. I now propose that effective July 1
column3: we give our taxpayers a tax cut of approximately $10 billion more than Congress agreed to in December.

column1: My broader tax reduction would mean that for a family of four making $15
column2: 000 a year
column3: there will be $227 more in take-home pay annually. Hardworking Americans caught in the middle can really use that kind of extra cash.

column1: My recommendations for a firm restraint on the growth of Federal spending and for greater tax reduction are simple and straightforward. For every dollar saved in cutting the growth in the Federal budget
column2: we can have an added dollar of Federal tax reduction.

column1: We can achieve a balanced budget by 1979 if we have the courage and the wisdom to continue to reduce the growth of Federal spending.

One test of a healthy economy is a job for every American who wants to work. Government--our kind of government--cannot create that many jobs. But the Federal Government can create conditions and incentives for private business and industry to make more and more jobs.
Five out of six jobs in this country are in private business and in industry. Common sense tells us this is the place to look for more jobs and to find them faster. I mean real
column2: rewarding
column3: permanent jobs.

column1: To achieve this we must offer the American people greater incentives to invest in the future. My tax proposals are a major step in that direction. To supplement these proposals
column2: I ask that Congress enact changes in Federal tax laws that will speed up plant expansion and the purchase of new equipment. My recommendations will concentrate this job-creation tax incentive in areas where the unemployment rate now runs over 7 percent. Legislation to get this started must be approved at the earliest possible date.

column1: Within the strict budget total that I will recommend for the coming year
column2: I will ask for additional housing assistance for 500
column3: 000 families. These programs will expand housing opportunities
column4: spur construction
column5: and help to house moderate- and low-income families.

column1: We had a disappointing year in the housing industry in 1975. But with lower interest rates and available mortgage money
column2: we can have a healthy recovery in 1976.

column1: A necessary condition of a healthy economy is freedom from the petty tyranny of massive government regulation. We are wasting literally millions of working hours costing billions of taxpayers' and consumers' dollars because of bureaucratic redtape. The American farmer
column2: who now feeds 215 million Americans
column3: but also millions worldwide
column4: has shown how much more he can produce without the shackles of government control.

column1: Now
column2: we badly need reforms in other key areas in our economy: the airlines
column3: trucking
column4: railroads
column5: and financial institutions. I have submitted concrete plans in each of these areas
column6: not to help this or that industry
column7: but to foster competition and to bring prices down for the consumer.

column1: This administration
column2: in addition
column3: will strictly enforce the Federal antitrust laws for the very same purposes.

column1: Taking a longer look ail and gas is still declining. Our dependence on foreign oil at high prices is still too great
column2: draining jobs and dollars away from our own economy at the rate of $125 per year for every American.

column1: Last month
column2: I signed a compromise national energy bill which enacts a part of my comprehensive energy independence program. This legislation was late
column3: not the complete answer to energy independence
column4: but still a start in the right direction.

column1: I again urge the Congress to move ahead immediately on the remainder of my energy proposals to make America invulnerable to the foreign oil cartel.
My proposals
column2: as all of you know
column3: would reduce domestic natural gas shortages; allow production from Federal petroleum reserves; stimulate effective conservation
column4: including revitalization of our railroads and the expansion of our urban transportation systems; develop more and cleaner energy from our vast coal resources; expedite clean and safe nuclear power production; create a new national energy independence authority to stimulate vital energy investment; and accelerate development of technology to capture energy from the Sun and the Earth for this and future generations.

column1: Also
column2: I ask
column3: for the sake of future generations
column4: that we preserve the family farm and family-owned small business. Both strengthen America and give stability to our economy. I will propose estate tax changes so that family businesses and family farms can be handed down from generation to generation without having to be sold to pay taxes.

column1: I propose tax changes to encourage people to invest in America's future
column2: and their own
column3: through a plan that gives moderate-income families income tax benefits if they make long-term investments in common stock in American companies.

column1: The Federal Government must and will respond to clear-cut national needs--for this and future generations.
Hospital and medical services in America are among the best in the world
column2: but the cost of a serious and extended illness can quickly wipe out a family's lifetime savings. Increasing health costs are of deep concern to all and a powerful force pushing up the cost of living. The burden of catastrophic illness can be borne by very few in our society. We must eliminate this fear from every family.

column1: I propose catastrophic health insurance for everybody covered by Medicare. To finance this added protection
column2: fees for short-term care will go up somewhat
column3: but nobody after reaching age 65 will have to pay more than $500 a year for covered hospital or nursing home care
column4: nor more than $250 for 1 year's doctor bills.

column1: We cannot realistically afford federally dictated national health insurance providing full coverage for all 215 million Americans. The experience of other countries raises questions about the quality as well as the cost of such plans. But I do envision the day when we may use the private health insurance system to offer more middle-income families high quality health services at prices they can afford and shield them also from their catastrophic illnesses.
Using resources now available
column2: I propose improving the Medicare and other Federal health programs to help those who really need protection-- older people and the poor. To help States and local governments give better health care to the poor
column3: I propose that we combine 16 existing Federal programs
column4: including Medicaid
column5: into a single $10 billion Federal grant.

column1: Funds would be divided among States under a new formula which provides a larger share of Federal money to those States that have a larger share of low-income families.
I will take further steps to improve the quality of medical and hospital care for those who have served in our Armed Forces.

Now let me speak about social security. Our Federal social security system for people who have worked and contributed to it for all their lives is a vital part of our economic system. Its value is no longer debatable. In my budget for fiscal year 1977
column2: I am recommending that the full cost-of-living increases in the social security benefits be paid during the coming year.

column1: But I am concerned about the integrity of our Social Security Trust Fund that enables people--those retired and those still working who will retire--to count on this source of retirement income. Younger workers watch their deductions rise and wonder if they will be adequately protected in the future. We must meet this challenge head on. Simple arithmetic warns all of us that the Social Security Trust Fund is headed for trouble. Unless we act soon to make sure the fund takes in as much as it pays out
column2: there will be no security for old or for young.

column1: I must
column2: therefore
column3: recommend a three-tenths of 1 percent increase in both employer and employee social security taxes effective January 1
column4: 1977. This will cost each covered employee less than 1 extra dollar a week and will ensure the integrity of the trust fund.

column1: As we rebuild our economy
column2: we have a continuing responsibility to provide a temporary cushion to the unemployed. At my request
column3: the Congress enacted two extensions and two expansions in unemployment insurance which helped those who were jobless during 1975. These programs will continue in 1976.

column1: In my fiscal year 1977 budget
column2: I am also requesting funds to continue proven job training and employment opportunity programs for millions of other Americans.

column1: Compassion and a sense of community--two of America's greatest strengths throughout our history--tell us we must take care of our neighbors who cannot take care of themselves. The host of Federal programs in this field reflect our generosity as a people.
But everyone realizes that when it comes to welfare
column2: government at all levels is not doing the job well. Too many of our welfare programs are inequitable and invite abuse. Too many of our welfare programs have problems from beginning to end. Worse
column3: we are wasting badly needed resources without reaching many of the truly needy.

column1: Complex welfare programs cannot be reformed overnight. Surely we cannot simply dump welfare into the laps of the 50 States
column2: their local taxpayers
column3: or their private charities
column4: and just walk away from it. Nor is it the right time for massive and sweeping changes while we are still recovering from the recession.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: there are still plenty of improvements that we can make. I will ask Congress for Presidential authority to tighten up the rules for eligibility and benefits.

column1: Last year I twice sought long overdue reform of the scandal-riddled food stamp program. This year I say again: Let's give food stamps to those most in need. Let's not give any to those who don't need them.
Protecting the life and property of the citizen at home is the responsibility of all public officials
column2: but is primarily the job of local and State law enforcement authorities.

column1: Americans have always found the very thought of a Federal police force repugnant
column2: and so do I. But there are proper ways in which we can help to insure domestic tranquility as the Constitution charges us.

column1: My recommendations on how to control violent crime were submitted to the Congress last June with strong emphasis on protecting the innocent victims of crime. To keep a convicted criminal from committing more crimes
column2: we must put him in prison so he cannot harm more law-abiding citizens. To be effective
column3: this punishment must be swift and it must be certain.

column1: Too often
column2: criminals are not sent to prison after conviction but are allowed to return to the streets. Some judges are reluctant to send convicted criminals to prison because of inadequate facilities. To alleviate this problem at the Federal level
column3: my new budget proposes the construction of four new Federal facilities.

column1: To speed Federal justice
column2: I propose an increase this year in the United States attorneys prosecuting Federal crimes and the reinforcement of the number of United States marshals. Additional Federal judges are needed
column3: as recommended by me and the Judicial Conference.

column1: Another major threat to every American's person and property is the criminal carrying a handgun. The way to cut down on the criminal use of guns is not to take guns away from the law-abiding citizen
column2: but to impose mandatory sentences for crimes in which a gun is used
column3: make it harder to obtain cheap guns for criminal purposes
column4: and concentrate gun control enforcement in high-crime areas.

column1: My budget recommends 500 additional Federal agents in the 11 largest metropolitan high-crime areas to help local authorities stop criminals from selling and using handguns.
The sale of hard drugs is tragically on the increase again. I have directed all agencies of the Federal Government to step up law enforcement efforts against those who deal in drugs. In 1975
column2: I am glad to report
column3: Federal agents seized substantially more heroin coming into our country than in 1974.

column1: As President
column2: I have talked personally with the leaders of Mexico
column3: Colombia
column4: and Turkey to urge greater efforts by their Governments to control effectively the production and shipment of hard drugs.

column1: I recommended months ago that the Congress enact mandatory fixed sentences for persons convicted of Federal crimes involving the sale of hard drugs. Hard drugs
column2: we all know
column3: degrade the spirit as they destroy the body of their users.

column1: It is unrealistic and misleading to hold out the hope that the Federal Government can move into every neighborhood and clean up crime. Under the Constitution
column2: the greatest responsibility for curbing crime lies with State and local authorities. They are the frontline fighters in the war against crime.

column1: There are definite ways in which the Federal Government can help them. I will propose in the new budget that Congress authorize almost $7 billion over the next 5 years to assist State and local governments to protect the safety and property of all their citizens.
As President
column2: I pledge the strict enforcement of Federal laws and--by example
column3: support
column4: and leadership--to help State and local authorities enforce their laws. Together
column5: we must protect the victims of crime and ensure domestic tranquility.

column1: Last year I strongly recommended a 5-year extension of the existing revenue sharing legislation
column2: which thus far has provided $23 1/2 billion to help State and local units of government solve problems at home. This program has been effective with decisionmaking transferred from the Federal Government to locally elected officials. Congress must act this year
column3: or State and local units of government will have to drop programs or raise local taxes.

column1: Including my health care program reforms
column2: I propose to consolidate some 59 separate Federal programs and provide flexible Federal dollar grants to help States
column3: cities
column4: and local agencies in such important areas as education
column5: child nutrition
column6: and social services. This flexible system will do the job better and do it closer to home.

column1: The protection of the lives and property of Americans from foreign enemies is one of my primary responsibilities as President.
In a world of instant communications and intercontinental ballistic missiles
column2: in a world economy that is global and interdependent
column3: our relations with other nations become more
column4: not less
column5: important to the lives of Americans.

column1: America has had a unique role in the world since the day of our independence 200 years ago. And ever since the end of World War II
column2: we have borne--successfully--a heavy responsibility for ensuring a stable world order and hope for human progress.

column1: Today
column2: the state of our foreign policy is sound and strong. We are at peace
column3: and I will do all in my power to keep it that way.

column1: Our military forces are capable and ready. Our military power is without equal
column2: and I intend to keep it that way.

column1: Our principal alliances with the industrial democracies of the Atlantic community and Japan have never been more solid.
A further agreement to limit the strategic arms race may be achieved.
We have an improving relationship with China
column2: the world's most populous nation.

column1: The key elements for peace among the nations of the Middle East now exist.
Our traditional friendships in Latin America
column2: Africa
column3: and Asia continue.

column1: We have taken the role of leadership in launching a serious and hopeful dialog between the industrial world and the developing world.
We have helped to achieve significant reform of the international monetary system.
We should be proud of what America
column2: what our country
column3: has accomplished in these areas
column4: and I believe the American people are.

column1: The American people have heard too much about how terrible our mistakes
column2: how evil our deeds
column3: and how misguided our purposes. The American people know better.

column1: The truth is we are the world's greatest democracy. We remain the symbol of man's aspiration for liberty and well-being. We are the embodiment of hope for progress.
I say it is time we quit downgrading ourselves as a nation. Of course
column2: it is our responsibility to learn the right lesson from past mistakes. It is our duty to see that they never happen again. But our greater duty is to look to the future. The world's troubles will not go away.

column1: The American people want strong and effective international and defense policies. In our constitutional system
column2: these policies should reflect consultation and accommodation between the President and the Congress. But in the final analysis
column3: as the framers of our Constitution knew from hard experience
column4: the foreign relations of the United States can be conducted effectively only if there is strong central direction that allows flexibility of action. That responsibility clearly rests with the President.

column1: I pledge to the American people policies which seek a secure
column2: just
column3: and peaceful world. I pledge to the Congress to work with you to that end.

column1: We must not face a future in which we can no longer help our friends
column2: such as Angola
column3: even in limited and carefully controlled ways. We must not lose all capacity to respond short of military intervention.

column1: Some hasty actions of the Congress during the past year--most recently in respect to Angola--were
column2: in my view
column3: very shortsighted. Unfortunately
column4: they are still very much on the minds of our allies and our adversaries.

column1: A strong defense posture gives weight to our values and our views in international negotiations. It assures the vigor of our alliances. And it sustains our efforts to promote settlements of international conflicts. Only from a position of strength can we negotiate a balanced agreement to limit the growth of nuclear arms. Only a balanced agreement will serve our interests and minimize the threat of nuclear confrontation.

The defense budget I will submit to the Congress for fiscal year 1977 will show an essential increase over the current year. It provides for real growth in purchasing power over this year's defense budget
column2: which includes the cost of the all-volunteer force.

column1: We are continuing to make economies to enhance the efficiency of our military forces. But the budget I will submit represents the necessity of American strength for the real world in which we live.
As conflict and rivalry persist in the world
column2: our United States intelligence capabilities must be the best in the world.

column1: The crippling of our foreign intelligence services increases the danger of American involvement in direct armed conflict. Our adversaries are encouraged to attempt new adventures while our own ability to monitor events and to influence events short of military action is undermined. Without effective intelligence capability
column2: the United States stands blindfolded and hobbled.

column1: In the near future
column2: I will take actions to reform and strengthen our intelligence community. I ask for your positive cooperation. It is time to go beyond sensationalism and ensure an effective
column3: responsible
column4: and responsive intelligence capability.

column1: Tonight I have spoken about our problems at home and abroad. I have recommended policies that will meet the challenge of our third century. I have no doubt that our Union will endure
column2: better
column3: stronger
column4: and with more individual freedom. We can see forward only dimly--1 year
column5: 5 years
column6: a generation perhaps. Like our forefathers
column7: we know that if we meet the challenges of our own time with a common sense of purpose and conviction
column8: if we remain true to our Constitution and to our ideals
column9: then we can know that the future will be better than the past.

column1: I see America today crossing a threshold
column2: not just because it is our Bicentennial but because we have been tested in adversity. We have taken a new look at what we want to be and what we want our Nation to become.

column1: I see America resurgent
column2: certain once again that life will be better for our children than it is for us
column3: seeking strength that cannot be counted in megatons and riches that cannot be eroded by inflation.

column1: I see these United States of America moving forward as before toward a more perfect Union where the government serves and the people rule.
We will not make this happen simply by making speeches
column2: good or bad
column3: yours or mine
column4: but by hard work and hard decisions made with courage and with common sense.

column1: I have heard many inspiring Presidential speeches
column2: but the words I remember best were spoken by Dwight D. Eisenhower. "America is not good because it is great
column3: the President said. America is great because it is good."

column1: President Eisenhower was raised in a poor but religious home in the heart of America. His simple words echoed President Lincoln's eloquent testament that "right makes might." And Lincoln in turn evoked the silent image of George Washington kneeling in prayer at Valley Forge.
So
column2: all these magic memories which link eight generations of Americans are summed up in the inscription just above me. How many times have we seen it? "In God We Trust."

column1: Let us engrave it now in each of our hearts as we begin our Bicentennial.@
Gerald R. Ford|Address Before a Joint Session of the Congress Reporting on the State of the Union|1977-01-12|@Mr. Speaker
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: Members of the 95th Congress
column4: and distinguished guests:

column1: In accordance with the Constitution
column2: I come before you once again to report on the state of the Union.

column1: This report will be my last--maybe--[laughter]--but for the Union it is only the first of such reports in our third century of independence
column2: the close of which none of us will ever see. We can be confident
column3: however
column4: that 100 years from now a freely elected President will come before a freely elected Congress chosen to renew our great Republic's pledge to the Government of the people
column5: by the people
column6: and for the people.

column1: For my part I pray the third century we are beginning will bring to all Americans
column2: our children and their children's children
column3: a greater measure of individual equality
column4: opportunity
column5: and justice
column6: a greater abundance of spiritual and material blessings
column7: and a higher quality of life
column8: liberty
column9: and the pursuit of happiness.

column1: The state of the Union is a measurement of the many elements of which it is composed--a political union of diverse States
column2: an economic union of varying interests
column3: an intellectual union of common convictions
column4: and a moral union of immutable ideals.

column1: Taken in sum
column2: I can report that the state of the Union is good. There is room for improvement
column3: as always
column4: but today we have a more perfect Union than when my stewardship began.

column1: As a people we discovered that our Bicentennial was much more than a celebration of the past; it became a joyous reaffirmation of all that it means to be Americans
column2: a confirmation before all the world of the vitality and durability of our free institutions. I am proud to have been privileged to preside over the affairs of our Federal Government during these eventful years when we proved
column3: as I said in my first words upon assuming office
column4: that "our Constitution works; our great Republic is a Government of laws and not of men. Here the people rule."

column1: The people have spoken; they have chosen a new President and a new Congress to work their will. I congratulate you--particularly the new Members--as sincerely as I did President-elect Carter. In a few days it will be his duty to outline for you his priorities and legislative recommendations. Tonight I will not infringe on that responsibility
column2: but rather wish him the very best in all that is good for our country.

column1: During the period of my own service in this Capitol and in the White House
column2: I can recall many orderly transitions of governmental responsibility--of problems as well as of position
column3: of burdens as well as of power. The genius of the American system is that we do this so naturally and so normally. There are no soldiers marching in the street except in the Inaugural Parade; no public demonstrations except for some of the dancers at the Inaugural Ball; the opposition party doesn't go underground
column4: but goes on functioning vigorously in the Congress and in the country; and our vigilant press goes right on probing and publishing our faults and our follies
column5: confirming the wisdom of the framers of the first amendment.

column1: Because of the transfer of authority in our form of government affects the state of the Union and of the world
column2: I am happy to report to you that the current transition is proceeding very well. I was determined that it should; I wanted the new President to get off on an easier start than I had.

column1: When I became President on August 9
column3: our Nation was deeply divided and tormented. In rapid succession the Vice President and the President had resigned in disgrace. We were still struggling with the after-effects of a long
column4: unpopular
column5: and bloody war in Southeast Asia. The economy was unstable and racing toward the worst recession in 40 years. People were losing jobs. The cost of living was soaring. The Congress and the Chief Executive were at loggerheads. The integrity of our constitutional process and other institutions was being questioned. For more than 15 years domestic spending had soared as Federal programs multiplied
column6: and the expense escalated annually. During the same period our national security needs were steadily shortchanged. In the grave situation which prevailed in August 1974
column7: our will to maintain our international leadership was in doubt.

column1: I asked for your prayers and went to work.

In January 1975 I reported to the Congress that the state of the Union was not good. I proposed urgent action to improve the economy and to achieve energy independence in 10 years. I reassured America's allies and sought to reduce the danger of confrontation with potential adversaries. I pledged a new direction for America. 1975 was a year of difficult decisions
column2: but Americans responded with realism
column3: common sense
column4: and self-discipline.

column1: By January 1976 we were headed in a new direction
column2: which I hold to be the right direction for a free society. It was guided by the belief that successful problemsolving requires more than Federal action alone
column3: that it involves a full partnership among all branches and all levels of government and public policies which nurture and promote the creative energies of private enterprises
column4: institutions
column5: and individual citizens.

column1: A year ago I reported that the state of the Union was better--in many ways a lot better--but still not good enough. Common sense told me to stick to the steady course we were on
column2: to continue to restrain the inflationary growth of government
column3: to reduce taxes as well as spending
column4: to return local decisions to local officials
column5: to provide for long-range sufficiency in energy and national security needs. I resisted the immense pressures of an election year to open the floodgates of Federal money and the temptation to promise more than I could deliver. I told it as it was to the American people and demonstrated to the world that in our spirited political competition
column6: as in this chamber
column7: Americans can disagree without being disagreeable.

column1: Now
column2: after 30 months as your President
column3: I can say that while we still have a way to go
column4: I am proud of the long way we have come together.

column1: I am proud of the part I have had in rebuilding confidence in the Presidency
column2: confidence in our free system
column3: and confidence in our future. Once again
column4: Americans believe in themselves
column5: in their leaders
column6: and in the promise that tomorrow holds for their children.

column1: I am proud that today America is at peace. None of our sons are fighting and dying in battle anywhere in the world. And the chance for peace among all nations is improved by our determination to honor our vital commitments in defense of peace and freedom.
I am proud that the United States has strong defenses
column2: strong alliances
column3: and a sound and courageous foreign policy.

column1: Our alliances with major partners
column2: the great industrial democracies of Western Europe
column3: Japan
column4: and Canada
column5: have never been more solid. Consultations on mutual security
column6: defense
column7: and East-West relations have grown closer. Collaboration has branched out into new fields such as energy
column8: economic policy
column9: and relations with the Third World. We have used many avenues for cooperation
column10: including summit meetings held among major allied countries. The friendship of the democracies is deeper
column12: and more effective than at any time in 30 years.

column1: We are maintaining stability in the strategic nuclear balance and pushing back the specter of nuclear war. A decisive step forward was taken in the Vladivostok Accord which I negotiated with General Secretary Brezhnev--joint recognition that an equal ceiling should be placed on the number of strategic weapons on each side. With resolve and wisdom on the part of both nations
column2: a good agreement is well within reach this year.

column1: The framework for peace in the Middle East has been built. Hopes for future progress in the Middle East were stirred by the historic agreements we reached and the trust and confidence that we formed. Thanks to American leadership
column2: the prospects for peace in the Middle East are brighter than they have been in three decades. The Arab states and Israel continue to look to us to lead them from confrontation and war to a new era of accommodation and peace. We have no alternative but to persevere
column3: and I am sure we will. The opportunities for a final settlement are great
column4: and the price of failure is a return to the bloodshed and hatred that for too long have brought tragedy to all of the peoples of this area and repeatedly edged the world to the brink of war.

column1: Our relationship with the People's Republic of China is proving its importance and its durability. We are finding more and more common ground between our two countries on basic questions of international affairs.
In my two trips to Asia as President
column2: we have reaffirmed America's continuing vital interest in the peace and security of Asia and the Pacific Basin
column3: established a new partnership with Japan
column4: confirmed our dedication to the security of Korea
column5: and reinforced our ties with the free nations of Southeast Asia.

column1: An historic dialog has begun between industrial nations and developing nations. Most proposals on the table are the initiatives of the United States
column2: including those on food
column3: energy
column4: technology
column5: trade
column6: investment
column7: and commodities. We are well launched on this process of shaping positive and reliable economic relations between rich nations and poor nations over the long term.

column1: We have made progress in trade negotiations and avoided protectionism during recession. We strengthened the international monetary system. During the past 2 years the free world's most important economic powers have already brought about important changes that serve both developed and developing economies. The momentum already achieved must be nurtured and strengthened
column2: for the prosperity of the rich and poor depends upon it.

column1: In Latin America
column2: our relations have taken on a new maturity and a sense of common enterprise.

column1: In Africa the quest for peace
column2: racial justice
column3: and economic progress is at a crucial point. The United States
column4: in close cooperation with the United Kingdom
column5: is actively engaged in this historic process. Will change come about by warfare and chaos and foreign intervention? Or will it come about by negotiated and fair solutions
column6: ensuring majority rule
column7: minority rights
column8: and economic advance? America is committed to the side of peace and justice and to the principle that Africa should shape its own future
column9: free of outside intervention.

column1: American leadership has helped to stimulate new international efforts to stem the proliferation of nuclear weapons and to shape a comprehensive treaty governing the use of oceans.

I am gratified by these accomplishments. They constitute a record of broad success for America and for the peace and prosperity of all mankind. This administration leaves to its successor a world in better condition than we found. We leave
column2: as well
column3: a solid foundation for progress on a range of issues that are vital to the well-being of America.

column1: What has been achieved in the field of foreign affairs and what can be accomplished by the new administration demonstrate the genius of Americans working together for the common good. It is this
column2: our remarkable ability to work together
column3: that has made us a unique nation. It is Congress
column4: the President
column5: and the people striving for a better world.

column1: I know all patriotic Americans want this Nation's foreign policy to succeed. I urge members of my party in this Congress to give the new President loyal support in this area. I express the hope that this new Congress will reexamine its constitutional role in international affairs.
The exclusive right to declare war
column2: the duty to advise and consent on the part of the Senate
column3: the power of the purse on the part of the House are ample authority for the legislative branch and should be jealously guarded. But because we may have been too careless of these powers in the past does not justify congressional intrusion into
column4: or obstruction of
column5: the proper exercise of Presidential responsibilities now or in the future. There can be only one Commander in Chief. In these times crises cannot be managed and wars cannot be waged by committee
column6: nor can peace be pursued solely by parliamentary debate. To the ears of the world
column7: the President speaks for the Nation. While he is
column8: of course
column9: ultimately accountable to the Congress
column10: the courts
column12: he and his emissaries must not be handicapped in advance in their relations with foreign governments as has sometimes happened in the past.

column1: At home I am encouraged by the Nation's recovery from the recession and our steady return to sound economic growth. It is now continuing after the recent period of uncertainty
column2: which is part of the price we pay for free elections.

column1: Our most pressing need today and the future is more jobs-- productive
column2: permanent jobs created by a thriving economy. We must revise our tax system both to ease the burden of heavy taxation and to encourage the investment necessary for the creation of productive jobs for all Americans who want to work.

column1: Earlier this month I proposed a permanent income tax reduction of $10 billion below current levels
column2: including raising the personal exemption from $750 to $1
column3: 000. I also recommended a series of measures to stimulate investment
column4: such as accelerated depreciation for new plants and equipment in areas of high unemployment
column5: a reduction in the corporate tax rate from 48 to 46 percent
column6: and eliminating the present double taxation of dividends. I strongly urge the Congress to pass these measures to help create the productive
column7: permanent jobs in the private economy that are so essential for our future.

column1: All the basic trends are good; we are not on the brink of another recession or economic disaster. If we follow prudent policies that encourage productive investment and discourage destructive inflation
column2: we will come out on top
column3: and I am sure we will.

column1: We have successfully cut inflation by more than half. When I took office
column2: the Consumer Price Index was rising at 12.2 percent a year. During 1976 the rate of inflation was 5 percent.

column1: We have created more jobs--over 4 million more jobs today than in the spring of 1975. Throughout this Nation today we have over 88 million people in useful
column2: productive jobs--more than at any other time in our Nation's history. But there are still too many Americans unemployed. This is the greatest regret that I have as I leave office.

column1: We brought about with the Congress
column2: after much delay
column3: the renewal of the general revenue sharing. We expanded community development and Federal manpower programs. We began a significant urban mass transit program. Federal programs today provide more funds for our States and local governments than ever before--$70 billion for the current fiscal year. Through these programs and others that provide aid directly to individuals
column4: we have kept faith with our tradition of compassionate help for those who need it. As we begin our third century we can be proud of the progress that we have made in meeting human needs for all of our citizens.

column1: We have cut the growth of crime by nearly 90 percent. Two years ago crime was increasing at the rate of 18 percent annually. In the first three quarters of 1976
column2: that growth rate had been cut to 2 percent. But crime
column3: and the fear of crime
column4: remains one of the most serious problems facing our citizens.

column1: We have had some successes
column2: and there have been some disappointments. Bluntly
column3: I must remind you that we have not made satisfactory progress toward achieving energy independence. Energy is absolutely vital to the defense of our country
column4: to the strength of our economy
column5: and to the quality of our lives.

column1: Two years ago I proposed to the Congress the first comprehensive national energy program--a specific and coordinated set of measures that would end our vulnerability to embargo
column2: blockade
column3: or arbitrary price increases and would mobilize U.S. technology and resources to supply a significant share of the free world's energy after 1985. Of the major energy proposals I submitted 2 years ago
column4: only half
column5: belatedly
column6: became law. In 1973 we were dependent upon foreign oil imports for 36 percent of our needs. Today
column7: we are 40-percent dependent
column8: and we'll pay out $34 billion for foreign oil this year. Such vulnerability at present or in the future is intolerable and must be ended.

column1: The answer to where we stand on our national energy effort today reminds me of the old argument about whether the tank is half full or half empty. The pessimist will say we have half failed to achieve our 10-year energy goals; the optimist will say that we have half succeeded. I am always an optimist
column2: but we must make up for lost time.

column1: We have laid a solid foundation for completing the enormous task which confronts us. I have signed into law five major energy bills which contain significant measures for conservation
column2: resource development
column3: stockpiling
column4: and standby authorities. We have moved forward to develop the naval petroleum reserves; to build a 500-million barrel strategic petroleum stockpile; to phase out unnecessary Government allocation and price controls; to develop a lasting relationship with other oil consuming nations; to improve the efficiency of energy use through conservation in automobiles
column5: buildings
column6: and industry; and to expand research on new technology and renewable resources such as wind power
column7: geothermal and solar energy. All these actions
column8: significant as they are for the long term
column9: are only the beginning.

column1: I recently submitted to the Congress my proposals to reorganize the Federal energy structure and the hard choices which remain if we are serious about reducing our dependence upon foreign energy. These include programs to reverse our declining production of natural gas and increase incentives for domestic crude oil production. I proposed to minimize environmental uncertainties affecting coal development
column2: expand nuclear power generation
column3: and create an energy independence authority to provide government financial assistance for vital energy programs where private capital is not available.

column1: We must explore every reasonable prospect for meeting our energy needs when our current domestic reserves of oil and natural gas begin to dwindle in the next decade. I urgently ask Congress and the new administration to move quickly on these issues. This Nation has the resources and the capability to achieve our energy goals if its Government has the will to proceed
column2: and I think we do.

column1: I have been disappointed by inability to complete many of the meaningful organizational reforms which I contemplated for the Federal Government
column2: although a start has been made. For example
column3: the Federal judicial system has long served as a model for other courts. But today it is threatened by a shortage of qualified Federal judges and an explosion of litigation claiming Federal jurisdiction. I commend to the new administration and the Congress the recent report and recommendations of the Department of Justice
column4: undertaken at my request
column5: on "the needs of the Federal Courts." I especially endorse its proposals for a new commission on the judicial appointment process.

column1: While the judicial branch of our Government may require reinforcement
column2: the budgets and payrolls of the other branches remain staggering. I cannot help but observe that while the White House staff and the Executive Office of the President have been reduced and the total number of civilians in the executive branch contained during the 1970's
column3: the legislative branch has increased substantially although the membership of the Congress remains at 535. Congress now costs the taxpayers more than a million dollars per Member; the whole legislative budget has passed the billion dollar mark.

column1: I set out to reduce the growth in the size and spending of the Federal Government
column2: but no President can accomplish this alone. The Congress sidetracked most of my requests for authority to consolidate overlapping programs and agencies
column3: to return more decisionmaking and responsibility to State and local governments through block grants instead of rigid categorical programs
column4: and to eliminate unnecessary redtape and outrageously complex regulations.

column1: We have made some progress in cutting back the expansion of government and its intrusion into individual lives
column2: but believe me
column3: there is much more to be done--and you and I know it. It can only be done by tough and temporarily painful surgery by a Congress as prepared as the President to face up to this very real political problem. Again
column4: I wish my successor
column5: working with a substantial majority of his own party
column6: the best of success in reforming the costly and cumbersome machinery of the Federal Government.

column1: The task of self-government is never finished. The problems are great; the opportunities are greater.
America's first goal is and always will be peace with honor. America must remain first in keeping peace in the world. We can remain first in peace only if we are never second in defense.
In presenting the state of the Union to the Congress and to the American people
column2: I have a special obligation as Commander in Chief to report on our national defense. Our survival as a free and independent people requires
column3: above all
column4: strong military forces that are well equipped and highly trained to perform their assigned mission.

column1: I am particularly gratified to report that over the past 2 1/2 years
column2: we have been able to reverse the dangerous decline of the previous decade in real resources this country was devoting to national defense. This was an immediate problem I faced in 1974. The evidence was unmistakable that the Soviet Union had been steadily increasing the resources it applied to building its military strength. During this same period the United States real defense spending declined. In my three budgets we not only arrested that dangerous decline
column3: but we have established the positive trend which is essential to our ability to contribute to peace and stability in the world.

column1: The Vietnam war
column2: both materially and psychologically
column3: affected our overall defense posture. The dangerous antimilitary sentiment discouraged defense spending and unfairly disparaged the men and women who serve in our Armed Forces.

column1: The challenge that now confronts this country is whether we have the national will and determination to continue this essential defense effort over the long term
column2: as it must be continued. We can no longer afford to oscillate from year to year in so vital a matter; indeed
column3: we have a duty to look beyond the immediate question of budgets and to examine the nature of the problem we will face over the next generation.

column1: I am the first recent President able to address long-term
column2: basic issues without the burden of Vietnam. The war in Indo-china consumed enormous resources at the very time that the overwhelming strategic superiority we once enjoyed was disappearing. In past years
column3: as a result of decisions by the United States
column4: our strategic forces leveled off
column5: yet the Soviet Union continued a steady
column6: constant buildup of its own forces
column7: committing a high percentage of its national economic effort to defense.

column1: The United States can never tolerate a shift in strategic balance against us or even a situation where the American people or our allies believe the balance is shifting against us. The United States would risk the most serious political consequences if the world came to believe that our adversaries have a decisive margin of superiority.

To maintain a strategic balance we must look ahead to the 1980's and beyond. The sophistication of modern weapons requires that we make decisions now if we are to ensure our security 10 years from now. Therefore
column2: I have consistently advocated and strongly urged that we pursue three critical strategic programs: the Trident missile launching submarine; the B-1 bomber
column3: with its superior capability to penetrate modern air defenses; and a more advanced intercontinental ballistic missile that will be better able to survive nuclear attack and deliver a devastating retaliatory strike.

column1: In an era where the strategic nuclear forces are in rough equilibrium
column2: the risks of conflict below the nuclear threshold may grow more perilous. A major
column3: long-term objective
column4: therefore
column5: is to maintain capabilities to deal with
column6: and thereby deter
column7: conventional challenges and crises
column8: particularly in Europe.

column1: We cannot rely solely on strategic forces to guarantee our security or to deter all types of aggression. We must have superior naval and marine forces to maintain freedom of the seas
column2: strong multipurpose tactical air forces
column3: and mobile
column4: modern ground forces. Accordingly
column5: I have directed a long-term effort to improve our worldwide capabilities to deal with regional crises.

column1: I have submitted a 5-year naval building program indispensable to the Nation's maritime strategy. Because the security of Europe and the integrity of NATO remain the cornerstone of American defense policy
column2: I have initiated a special
column3: long-term program to ensure the capacity of the Alliance to deter or defeat aggression in Europe.

column1: As I leave office I can report that our national defense is effectively deterring conflict today. Our Armed Forces are capable of carrying out the variety of missions assigned to them. Programs are underway which will assure we can deter war in the years ahead. But I also must warn that it will require a sustained effort over a period of years to maintain these capabilities. We must have the wisdom
column2: the stamina
column3: and the courage to prepare today for the perils of tomorrow
column4: and I believe we will.

column1: As I look to the future--and I assure you I intend to go on doing that for a good many years--I can say with confidence that the state of the Union is good
column2: but we must go on making it better and better.

column1: This gathering symbolizes the constitutional foundation which makes continued progress possible
column2: synchronizing the skills of three independent branches of Government
column3: reserving fundamental sovereignty to the people of this great land. It is only as the temporary representatives and servants of the people that we meet here
column4: we bring no hereditary status or gift of infallibility
column5: and none follows us from this place.

column1: Like President Washington
column2: like the more fortunate of his successors
column3: I look forward to the status of private citizen with gladness and gratitude. To me
column4: being a citizen of the United States of America is the greatest honor and privilege in this world.

column1: From the opportunities which fate and my fellow citizens have given me
column2: as a Member of the House
column3: as Vice President and President of the Senate
column4: and as President of all the people
column5: I have come to understand and place the highest value on the checks and balances which our founders imposed on government through the separation of powers among co-equal legislative
column6: executive
column7: and judicial branches. This often results in difficulty and delay
column8: as I well know
column9: but it also places supreme authority under God
column10: beyond any one person
column12: any majority great or small
column13: or any one party. The Constitution is the bedrock of all our freedoms. Guard and cherish it
column14: keep honor and order in your own house

column1: It is not easy to end these remarks. In this Chamber
column2: along with some of you
column3: I have experienced many
column4: many of the highlights of my life. It was here that I stood 28 years ago with my freshman colleagues
column5: as Speaker Sam Rayburn administered the oath. I see some of you now-- Charlie Bennett
column6: Dick Bolling
column7: Carl Perkins
column8: Pete Rodino
column9: Harley Staggers
column10: Tom Steed
column12: Clem Zablocki--and I remember those who have gone to their rest. It was here we waged many
column15: but always remaining friends. It was here
column17: that the distinguished Chief Justice swore me in as Vice President on December 6
column18: 1973. It was here I returned 8 months later as your President to ask not for a honeymoon

column1: I will always treasure those memories and your many
column2: many kindnesses. I thank you for them all.

column1: My fellow Americans
column2: I once asked you for your prayers
column3: and now I give you mine: May God guide this wonderful country
column4: its people
column5: and those they have chosen to lead them. May our third century be illuminated by liberty and blessed with brotherhood
column6: so that we and all who come after us may be the humble servants of thy peace. Amen.

column1: Good night. God bless you.@
